This time was often used for reflection or even secret activities. The poorest people benefited most from this quiet time, escaping their daily struggles. However, by the 17th century, as artificial light became more common, wealthier people began to adopt the more efficient sleep patterns we have today. The industrial revolution further changed sleep habits, making people work longer hours in lit buildings.

In many non-Western cultures, the old sleep patterns still exist. Some people go to bed for a few hours, wake up, and then sleep again. The idea of a solid night’s sleep is not universal. In certain tribal societies, noises from humans and animals, as well as the need to tend to fires and watch for dangers, make continuous sleep difficult. It appears that people around the world are in great need of more sleep.

We are talking about very expensive cowboy boots. I stood in my 800-dollar designer cowboy boots on the rocks in the Arizona desert. Money was not a concern. I wore a complete cowboy outfit, and if you have the outfit, you might look like a cowboy. But I was not one. I realized that I did not belong there. As I squinted into the morning sun, looking at the Arizona mountains, I had to admit that I was not at home in the wild. 

I had flown in from Denver just after dawn, and for a moment, I thought I might pass for a cowboy arriving from the sky. That feeling disappeared quickly when I saw a real cowboy at the Phoenix airport. He wore a dirty shirt, needed a shave, and was picking up a worn bag when he noticed my new cowboy boots. He raised an eyebrow and walked out without saying anything. 

I thought there should be a set of clothes that an ex-racing driver could wear without feeling out of place. Something that would make me feel comfortable wherever I went. I loved being a racing driver and driving fast cars. It was my passion, but I could not do it anymore. I wondered what I should do now. A racing driver should have other identities ready for when they stop racing. I thought I had some options, but they vanished when I tried to reach for them. 

I considered being a commentator at races, but there were many former drivers ahead of me. I also thought about selling classic cars, but that plan fell through because no one was buying them. In the end, I stepped back before I lost everything. Being an "ex" of anything is tough. Who wants to hear about how I almost became a World Champion? No one wants to hear a story that ends with "almost." Even if I had been the champion, you would probably only want to hear the story for a few minutes before losing interest. 

I don’t want sympathy, and I don’t get any. Why should I? I had a good career, made money, and saved enough. But I miss the thrill of getting into a powerful racing car, feeling the speed, and the excitement of racing. I miss the bright, interesting people and the reporters who cared about what I said. Being somewhat famous had its perks. Businessmen and politicians liked to say they knew me, and kids would sneak under fences to get my autograph. 

Now that I don’t race anymore, I have a lot of free time. Just last week, my phone rang twice. I have time in the morning and afternoon, and tomorrow looks empty too. I looked up at the clear blue sky. There were no buzzards flying above. Maybe Arizona doesn’t have them. But I noticed some small brown birds in a cactus nearby, warning me to leave their nest alone. I had never thought the desert had songbirds. It made me realize that a fake cowboy in fancy boots still has much to learn.

**Vancouver**

In the past ten years, many people from around the world have moved to Vancouver, a city in western Canada. In the evenings, residents enjoy walking through the city, and if you join them, you will likely hear many different languages. People are attracted to Vancouver because of its mild weather, beautiful location between the ocean and mountains, clean and safe environment, and good educational and job opportunities. Although some locals complain about the rapid construction of new buildings, it is clear that the new residents and growing tourism have contributed to a vibrant city revival. Vancouver was once called 'Terminal City' because it served as a gateway to other places. While this name is less common now, Vancouver is still a major gateway.

**Putting Pen to Paper**

Journalists, like me, often struggle with writing letters. Some say this is because we dislike writing for free, but I think it is more about how we aim for the best possible impact in our work, which makes the natural flow of a letter difficult. True creative artists, who do not focus on the effect of their words (even if they rewrite many times), do not face this issue. I believe that understanding the impact of their words is a key sign of a true artist. For example, when Shakespeare wrote his famous lines, he likely did not consciously think about how the use of longer words made them powerful and showed his talent.

**Supermarket Opening**

In Britain, the opening of a new supermarket used to be a big event. You could expect a celebrity, like a soap star or a member of the royal family, to cut the ribbon. Now, new supermarkets seem to open every day, and celebrities are no longer needed. Why pay a famous person when anyone can open it for free? Last week, elderly people waiting for the new Superbuy store did not care who opened it, as long as they were at the front of the line. According to one customer who had inside information, the first five men to enter would receive a bottle of aftershave, and the first five women would get a bouquet of flowers. This news quickly spread through the crowd, making those at the front feel proud and causing envy among those who arrived later.

**Citizen Kane**

When the film *Citizen Kane* was released in 1941, it created a lot of excitement, but it was not a financial success. The release was delayed because the distributors were worried about the possible negative reaction from William Randolph Hearst, who was thought to be the inspiration for the main character. Despite the film receiving very positive reviews, it did not do well at the box office. It was only when it was shown on television that people began to appreciate it again. *Citizen Kane* is considered one of the most influential films, inspiring many to become filmmakers. This is surprising because it was Orson Welles's first film. Welles believed that its success came from his lack of knowledge about the rules of filmmaking; he simply created the film as he wanted. He also had a talented team, including cameraman Gregg Toland, screenwriter Herman J. Mankiewicz, and special-effects expert Linwood Dunn. When Welles and Mankiewicz decided to create a story about a newspaper tycoon who resembled Hearst, Welles realized he had found the perfect role for himself as both director and actor, and he approached the project with great enthusiasm.

**Dermot and Carmel**

That morning, Dermot thought Carmel seemed a bit strange. He had mentioned twice that he might be late and that he might stop by the golf club on his way home to talk to someone. Carmel had nodded politely, as if she didn’t really understand. He asked her, “Will you be okay? What are your plans for today?” She smiled and replied, “It’s funny you ask. I was just thinking I have nothing to do today, so I’ll take a walk downtown and look at the shops. I feel like it’s almost wrong to waste the day like this.” Dermot smiled back and said, “You deserve to enjoy yourself. And if I’m late, I won’t need any food, so don’t worry about it.” “That’s fine,” she replied.

**Title Race**

“Tea boy? Do you mind? I’m a mobile lukewarm beverage resource facilitator.” Human nature often leads to amusing situations. A recent study revealed that job titles are a major source of jealousy and dissatisfaction at work. A survey by a well-known recruitment firm found that 90% of employers and 70% of employees believe that job titles create divisions among coworkers. Surprisingly, 70% of office workers said they would give up a pay raise for a more appealing or professional job title. If our desire for status is so strong that it overshadows our basic need for money, we are in a troubling situation. In the early twenty-first century, no one wants to be called “subordinate.” The job titles being discussed focus on skills (like specialist or coordinator) but are really just fancy words.

**The Vienna Assignment**

I was in Vienna to take photographs, which was usually my main reason for being anywhere. Photography was not just my job; it was a big part of my life. The way light fell on different surfaces always inspired me. I believed that a single photograph could capture the essence of a moment, a place, or a person. I always hoped to take the perfect picture, as long as I had film in my camera. My approach was simple: finish one roll, load another, and keep my eyes open. This had been my way of working for a long time.

Once, I got lucky when a photo of a smoke plume from a burning oil well became very popular, appearing in newspapers and magazines worldwide. It was a brief moment of fame, but I realized that luck plays a role in both good and bad outcomes. After that, I decided to work as a freelance photographer, which seemed like a smart choice. However, life took some unexpected turns, and the mid-nineties were not as successful as I had hoped, especially after my photo made the cover of Time magazine. That’s why I found myself in Vienna instead of a more exciting location. But I was still taking photographs and getting paid for it, which I didn’t mind.

This assignment came about by chance. I had previously taken photos for a coffee-table book called *Four Cities in Four Seasons*, which featured London, Paris, Rome, and Vienna. I had received a good commission for capturing my city in different seasons. I had my own unique style, showcasing daffodils in Hyde Park and the heat haze in Piccadilly. However, I accepted that much of my work would be overlooked since it was just a picture book, not meant to challenge anyone’s views.

After a cold snap over Christmas, I submitted my winter photos of London and learned that the Austrian photographer, Rudi Schussner, had left his job in Vienna for unknown reasons. Instead of hiring someone new, they offered me the chance to take his place. The Austrian publishers liked my work, and I was available, unlike the French and Italian photographers. I was eager to go because things at home were not going well. A week in snowy Vienna was a welcome change.

They arranged for me to stay at the Europa hotel in the old city. My last visit to Vienna had been a busy summer trip with my wife, where we rushed through many palaces and museums. It was hot and chaotic, and I hadn’t taken many photos. This time, being alone in the cold January weather would be different. I felt it the moment I arrived and saw the beautiful light over the snow-covered roofs. I was excited to take great pictures.

On my first day, I didn’t rush to take photos. Instead, I rode the trams around the Ringstrasse, getting on and off to experience the city’s atmosphere. The weather was cold and still, reflecting the grand history of the city. I hadn’t seen what Schussner had captured in the other seasons, and I didn’t want to. This was going to be my Vienna, and I was ready to let it reveal itself to me. 

A photograph captures a moment, but you must wait for the right moment to come. So, I took my time, observing everything until I felt ready. The next morning, I woke up early. Overnight snow had made Stephansplatz beautifully white and almost empty. I struggled to find a way to capture the cathedral in one shot. Its tall spire reached into the grey sky, while at ground level, it was massive and imposing. I realized I might have to focus on just part of it. In that weather and at that time, it could still be magical.

Photography has always had a sense of magic. Even the early photographers, before they understood the science behind it, felt this wonder. You can watch a blank sheet of paper transform into a photograph in a dark room. Even when you know how it works, the mystery remains. Perhaps that’s why what happened at Stephansplatz that morning didn’t surprise me in a strange way.

**Kinetic Art**

Exciting news: London's Hayward Gallery has changed from a serious place into one full of wonder. This transformation is not due to a big-budget show, but rather a unique exploration of a lesser-known part of the last 60 years. A new exhibition looks at the history of kinetic art, which is art that involves movement, throughout the twentieth century. It shows that creating art that moves on its own or explores the idea of movement has been a consistent, though often overlooked, theme in some of the most interesting creative work of this century. 

Curator Guy Brett, who has studied this subject for many years, has gathered a wonderful collection of paintings, drawings, documents, and films about kinetic art. These are mostly presented without much text, allowing visitors to enjoy discovering and connecting ideas on their own.

**David Hockney**

David Hockney's art attracts many people who might not usually be interested in art. This could be because his work is figurative and easy to understand, or because it deals with themes of leisure and escape from daily life. Some might even be drawn to Hockney's lively personality and clever comments, which make him popular in the media. However, this raises the question: does this popularity mean his art lacks serious purpose? 

Some respected critics view Hockney as an overrated minor artist. Yet, one could argue that his popularity today might be seen as a negative rather than a reflection of his artistic value. Hockney himself is aware of his limitations and believes it is not important to dismiss his work just because it does not fit a traditional idea of greatness. He does not claim to be a great artist and understands that only future generations can truly judge his significance.

**Window-shopping - An Art Exhibition**

In recent years, I have attended many contemporary art exhibitions, some brilliant and others mediocre. What frustrates me are shows that seem to push a specific agenda, suggesting a common viewpoint among certain artists. Sometimes this approach works, revealing new trends in seemingly unrelated works. More often, it highlights a questionable angle or a forced concept. 

As a curator, I wanted to create a show that opposed this trend. Along with seven artists, I took over an empty warehouse space for an exhibition called "Window-shopping." This was meant to showcase individual artworks that connected only by being labeled as art. For example, Sam Cole's knitted cats playfully chased each other on a toy train track, while Matthew Crawley filmed a video camera, opening it up and poking around until it broke, creating a flickering display on a monitor. 

These works did not fit into a specific theme and would not usually be shown together, but I believe they complemented each other through their differences. While I did not make grand statements about contemporary art, I think it is important to recognize that art is an individual activity where artists set their own rules.

**Art History**

People who enjoy paintings sometimes hesitate to analyze them, fearing it will ruin their enjoyment. Some believe that art historians, who focus on theory rather than practice, overlook the joy of viewing art and the special act of creating it. This idea is similar to thinking that knowing a recipe and cooking methods takes away from the enjoyment of a dish. 

Understanding the importance of enjoyment does not mean we cannot also have a deep knowledge of what we appreciate. In fact, knowing more about an artwork can enhance our pleasure. Additionally, pleasure is complex. How we sense and recognize pleasure is influenced by our history and society. Our preferences for certain characteristics in art are shaped not just by our genes or personalities, but also by the values of the society we live in. 

While we should not underestimate the importance of our instinctive responses to art, the belief that intellectual understanding diminishes enjoyment is an outdated idea that once promoted art as a substitute for thought.

**Metals**  
Stone Age people may have been interested in metals because they wanted to decorate themselves. While sitting by a river, one of our early ancestors might have found a shiny yellow pebble and picked it up. This pebble did not feel like stone, but it was beautiful. This could be how gold first became important to early humans. Because gold is easy to shape, it quickly became a popular material. Copper may have also been discovered by chance. Once people realized how useful copper tools were, they actively searched for copper ores and ways to extract the metal. This led to the development of metalworking, which improved the lives of our ancestors.

**St Ives**  
We walked down a narrow, cobbled street towards the town, struggling with our heavy bags against a strong wind and trying to avoid the cold waves crashing over the walkway. The streets were empty, and every cottage by the water had its shutters closed tightly against the storm. We had seen the weather get worse as we arrived in St Ives on a small train. With the dark clouds gathering, visiting Cornwall in the off-season without a car didn’t seem like a good idea anymore. I had convinced my friend to come with me by promising beautiful walks along the Cornish coast and cozy evenings by the fire.

**Computer Modelling**  
Studying the past is challenging because it is gone. The people who lived in times of peace and those who faced hardship are no longer alive. The reasons they settled in certain places or formed families and communities have been forgotten. Archaeology gives us some clues, but we cannot test our ideas with experiments on past cultures. We cannot rewind time to see what happened. However, computer modelling allows us to recreate ancient landscapes and environments, filling them with virtual communities that have some needs and abilities like real humans. We can set rules for these communities and simulate social groups. Then, we can change the weather or the population and observe how these digital cultures and their artificial people respond.

**Vervet Monkeys**  
Cheney and Seyfarth studied vervet monkeys and observed a dominant male who noticed a strange male nearby. The stranger wanted to join the group, which could lead to the dominant male losing his position. To keep the stranger away, the dominant male cleverly made an alarm call that signaled the presence of a leopard whenever the stranger approached. This caused the stranger to retreat back into the trees. However, the dominant male made a mistake by using the alarm call while walking across open ground himself, which could have put him in danger.

**What Cats Catch**  
In a survey in the English village of Felmersham, residents recorded what their cats caught over a year. Seventy cats caught over 1,000 prey items, leading a professor in America to estimate that cats in Britain kill around 100 million birds and small mammals each year. However, this number is misleading because most cats live in towns and catch fewer animals than those in the survey. The important question is whether these numbers are sustainable. The answer seems to be yes, as many people feed birds in winter, and gardens provide nesting sites, keeping bird populations above natural levels. The survey shows that while cats are significant predators, they are not destroying Britain's bird population.

**Buffalo's Day**  
Buffaloes are very important to the marshmen, who care for them deeply. Each morning, the buffaloes, after sleeping near their owners, slowly make their way to the distant reed beds. They often groan about their tiredness before the leader finally steps into the water. Once in the water, they seem to forget their purpose and wallow there, making low sounds of complaint. Their movements away from the house are so slow that they go almost unnoticed, but eventually, they are swimming, appearing to struggle to keep their noses above water. They spend the day among the reeds, grazing on green shoots at their eye level.

**Picasso, Pablo**  
In early spring 1940, while in the fishing port of Royan, Picasso painted several still lifes of fish. One painting shows a fishmonger's slab with a crab and some soles. Despite their situation, the fish appear alive. The painting is complex, with overlapping transparent shapes and delicate colors, creating a calm underwater feel. However, there is tension as the fish seem to be preparing for a fight with the crab. The sharp shapes in the painting, including a chain around one fish, suggest a sense of danger and hidden violence, giving the artwork a deeper meaning.

**Photography**

Over the last 150 years, photography has been a powerful way to capture all parts of human life. In this relatively short time, photography has improved its ability to record moments in time and space, allowing us to see both large and small things. It has given us images from faraway places, distant parts of our solar system, and the complex social issues of modern life. Photography has become one of the most important ways to express what it means to be human.

However, the idea of recording events visually has a much longer history. The first known images date back to the Upper Paleolithic period, around 35,000 years ago. We are not entirely sure why early cave paintings were created. They might have recorded actual hunting events, served as magic to help with hunting, acted as religious symbols, or simply been made to brighten daily life. Regardless, visual images have always been closely connected to human culture.

Throughout history, people have questioned how accurate visual images are and what role they play in society. The saying "seeing is believing" has given special importance to visual images. When photography was invented in the mid-1800s, it seemed to promise a way to create truthful visual records. The camera was thought to work like the human eye, capturing images that closely resembled what we see. The chemical process used to fix images allowed for the capture of what we consider natural phenomena.

At the same time, photography was seen as a sophisticated cultural achievement, producing images that artists had long tried to create through skill and effort. Ironically, because photography seemed so realistic, it was believed that everyone could easily understand photographs. This led to the idea that photography might be a "universal language." For instance, in 1933, photographer August Sander suggested that even the most isolated person could understand a photograph of the sky, whether it showed the sun, moon, or stars.

However, as global communication increased in the late 20th century, we must consider how well photographs can cross cultural boundaries. Is photography limited by cultural norms like any other form of communication, such as language? Has our familiarity with photographs made us overlook the complex ways they convey vivid impressions of reality? Photography is often seen as providing convincing evidence, making it seem like a clear window into reality, blurring the line between our perception of the world and its photographic representations. It is common for someone to show a photograph and say, "This is my grandson."

Since its invention in 1839, photography and the attitudes towards it have changed significantly. This change may be partly due to photography moving into what we might call "mythic time." Its original role as a record-keeper has evolved, and photographs, once closely tied to the photographer and subject, have become historical documents. These images often reveal as much, if not more, about the people and society that created them than about the subjects themselves.

I aim to show that the camera is not just a silent recorder of events. Photography does not merely reflect culture; it can inspire social and political change. For example, it is hard to imagine the cultural shifts of the Italian Renaissance without recognizing how the development of perspective changed visual representation. Similarly, photography has played a significant role in shaping the media culture of our time, while also bringing the harsh realities of the world into our everyday lives.

**How to Write Poetry**

Teaching people how to write poetry can be tricky. While creativity is important, making one mistake can lead to confusion. I believe that for beginners, the best way to learn is through reading a lot, writing often, and allowing your imagination to flow freely, as long as it doesn’t become chaotic. Some people need a stable life to write poetry, while others can express their feelings through writing during tough times. Some writers follow a schedule, while others wait for inspiration to strike. All approaches are valid, as long as they don’t follow strict rules. The key is to find your unique voice, nurture it, and let it grow. Eventually, it will become strong enough to stand on its own.

**The Short Story**

In a short story, it’s important not to overcrowd it with too many characters or lengthy descriptions. Flashbacks should be brief and only used when necessary to clarify a point. One effective method is to show a memory in the main character's mind, which can help move the story forward without slowing it down. Dialogue is also very useful; it can show different perspectives quickly and keep the reader engaged. Avoiding excessive writing is crucial, but this doesn’t mean the story should be too short. A short story should maintain conflict and action just like a novel, but every word must be meaningful in a limited space.

**Screenplays**

Writing a screenplay is similar to playing chess. Most players make moves without knowing exactly what will happen next. They might see a few moves ahead, but often play without a clear plan. Over time, players learn that chess is more about long-term strategy than short-term tactics. They start to see the game as a whole, recognizing patterns and strategies. The same applies to screenplay writing; the more you practice, the more you understand its complexities.

**Looking at Writing**

Humans naturally learn to speak, as seen in young children, but they do not instinctively learn to write. Charles Darwin noted that while language is a natural human instinct, written language is not. All societies have language, and while languages evolve, they do not necessarily become better. Children learn to speak without formal lessons, and when they lack a common language, they create their own. In contrast, writing systems have been developed only a few times in history and often started as simple codes. Until recently, many children did not learn to read or write, and even today, some struggle. A group of children is unlikely to invent a writing system on their own. Children are naturally inclined to listen and speak, but learning to read and write requires effort and guidance. It’s important to understand how writing works and how to help children learn it effectively.

I have never started a novel with so much uncertainty. I call it a novel only because I don’t know what else to call it. I have a small story to tell, and it does not end with a death or a marriage. Instead, I leave my reader hanging. This book is about my memories of a man I met only occasionally, and I know little about what happened to him in between our meetings. I could invent details to make the story more complete, but I do not want to do that. I just want to share what I know.

To avoid embarrassing people who are still alive, I have given the characters in this story names I made up, and I have taken care to ensure that no one can recognize them. The man I am writing about is not famous, and he may never be. When his life ends, he might leave no more mark on the world than a stone thrown into a river leaves on the water's surface. If my book is read, it will be for its own interest. However, it is possible that his way of life and the unique qualities of his character may influence others, so that long after he is gone, people may realize that a remarkable person lived in this time. Then it will be clear who I am writing about, and those who want to know a bit about his early life may find something useful in this book.

I believe my book, despite its limitations, will be a helpful source for my friend’s biographers. I do not claim that the conversations I recorded are exact. I never took notes during our talks, but I remember well what matters to me. Although I have put these conversations in my own words, I believe they accurately reflect what was said. I mentioned earlier that I have invented nothing, but I have taken the liberty that historians do by putting words into the mouths of my characters that I did not hear. I did this to make the scenes more lively and believable, as they would be dull if simply told. I want my book to be engaging, and I think I am justified in making it readable. A thoughtful reader will easily see where I have used this technique and can choose to ignore it.

Another reason I feel anxious about this work is that the people I mainly discuss come from a different culture. It is hard to truly know people, and I believe we can only really know those from our own country. People are shaped not only by who they are but also by where they were born, the places they grew up, the games they played, the food they ate, the schools they attended, the sports they followed, and the poets they read. All these experiences shape who they are, and you cannot understand them just by hearing about them; you must live them. You can only know them if you are one of them. Because you cannot fully understand people from a different nation except through observation, it is challenging to portray them convincingly in a book. I have never tried to write about anyone but my own countrymen, and if I have done so in short stories, it is because those allow for a more general treatment of characters. You can give broad hints and let the reader fill in the details. In this book, I do not claim that my characters see themselves as they truly are; they are seen through my own perspective, just like my main character.

**POETRY RECITALS**

Throughout history, the world of literature often seems confusing to those experiencing it. However, future generations can see clear patterns and important figures in literature. Currently, there is a complex mix of poetic styles, different types of poetry, and various opinions on how poetry should be presented, criticized, and taught. 

A major discussion in contemporary poetry is the tension between serious 'literary' poets, who write poems meant to be read on the page, and 'popular' poets, who prefer to perform their work for an audience. This division is not strict. Over the last twenty years, public poetry readings have become more common in many forms. Small literary groups in towns hold readings in community centers or members' homes. Schools and colleges invite poets to read and discuss their work with students, and arts festivals often feature readings by well-known poets.

The impact of these events, where poets often have to perform publicly, is varied and uncertain. For 'pop' poets, whose work is designed for live audiences, public performance is beneficial. Their poems are usually simple and can be understood easily in one hearing. However, when these poems are read on the page, their weaknesses in thought and creativity become apparent.

On the other hand, dedicated poets, who strive to continue the best traditions of poetry by packing deep emotion, thought, and creativity into a few words, may not be appreciated by audiences hearing their work for the first time. The risk is that these poets might choose to read only their simplest pieces to connect quickly with the audience, which may not represent their true style.

Attending poetry readings cannot replace reading poetry from the page, but it can be a fun and educational experience. Hearing skilled poets read their work, even if they are not great speakers, helps the audience understand where to place emphasis. It is best if the audience has the text in front of them or knows the poems beforehand.

The main reason for popular poetry readings, sometimes combined with music (like jazz), is to help audiences enjoy poetry and see it as an art form accessible to everyone, not just a select few.

**Oral History**  
Historians increasingly use oral evidence, but this approach has challenges. It is overly simplistic to think that a person's story is a clear reflection of their past. In an interview, both the interviewer and the interviewee influence each other. The historian chooses who to interview and what topics to discuss. Even if the historian only listens, their presence can change how the informant remembers and shares their experiences. The final account is shaped by the historian's social status and their understanding of the past, which may be communicated to the informant. Thus, historians must acknowledge their role in creating new evidence. The challenges continue even after the historian leaves. The informant's memories are not direct connections to the past; they can be influenced by other sources, like the media, or colored by nostalgia or feelings of loss from their childhood. The emotions and attitudes expressed can make the testimony seem convincing, but they may actually reflect later experiences rather than the time being discussed.

**Animal Science**  
Animal science has two main approaches: physiological and whole animal. Physiologists focus on how the body functions, studying how nerves, muscles, and senses work together to create complex behaviors. Those who take the whole animal approach study the behavior of animals in their natural state and the factors that influence it. Within this approach, there are psychologists and ethologists. Psychologists often work in labs, studying learning in a few species, like rats and pigeons. Ethologists study natural, unlearned behaviors of animals in the wild. While this distinction still exists, there is now a productive blending of the two fields. Physiologists often claim their methods are more fundamental, but understanding behavior also requires studying it at a behavioral level. Behavior has its own structure and units that must be used for its study. For example, explaining a bird's nest-building behavior by only looking at individual nerve cells would be like trying to read a book with a powerful microscope.

**The Social Sciences**  
Students studying social sciences for the first time face a dual challenge. They must learn both the content of their new subject and the methods used to study it. This means they need to understand not only the knowledge found in textbooks but also how that knowledge is gathered and organized, which forms the logical foundation of the subject. These two aspects are interconnected. Although we all have experience with social life, social sciences go beyond common sense. Each discipline focuses on specific aspects of social life, uses particular research methods, and has its own concepts. These basic ideas form the logical foundation of the subject, allowing social scientists to move beyond everyday understanding and differentiate one discipline from another.

**Classical Architecture**  
In the classical world of Ancient Greece and Rome, architecture was more than just building structures. According to the Roman architect Vitruvius, architecture involves order, arrangement, proportion, symmetry, propriety, and distribution. He also provides Greek equivalents for some of these terms, likely based on earlier Greek sources that are now lost. While utility and function are not part of his initial definition, Vitruvius later discusses the best forms and arrangements for different types of buildings. At the start, the focus is on aesthetics, viewing architecture as an art. The origins of classical architecture are complex, with a long history of simple structures in Greece and Italy that did not meet Vitruvius' artistic standards. Although these early forms were not artistic, they contributed essential elements that influenced later architectural concepts. Despite its elaborate appearance, the classical temple essentially resembles a simple, single-room hut.

The two sisters kept Lily's driving a secret from Chen for a while. Lily would drive around the gardens and the railway, even jumping over a small bridge, which was her only mistake. After that, they would pass by the gasworks, where there was a strong smell. Surprisingly, Chen found it funny that Lily was driving without telling him. "So you can really drive, Lily? Well done!" he said. Mui thought it was strange that her brother-in-law was not upset. Instead, he was excited and made plans with Lily for a trip. They decided to go on a Monday at the start of next month, the quietest day of the week, leaving early and returning by noon to avoid losing customers. Meanwhile, Lily would practice driving. Despite her doubts, Mui bought a road map and got a ten percent discount, which impressed Chen, but Lily felt a bit insulted by Mui's lack of trust in her navigation skills.

Within an hour of leaving home, they were looking at the English Channel. Lily drove very well. Even Mui, who was in the back seat ready to give directions, had to admit this. Lily even overtook some slow cars confidently, making Mui hold back her concerns. Chen even applauded her. After passing the gasworks and the lagoon with its small boats, they drove smoothly along the empty promenade. Lily parked in a quiet street with empty spaces. She was unsure about the road signs and preferred to pay for parking rather than risk getting a ticket. 

Lily noticed her sister's worried face in the mirror and decided not to add to her worries. She locked all the van doors carefully. "Don't worry," Chen joked. "No one will want that old thing." The sisters were offended. Lily accused Chen of being ungrateful, and Mui scolded him for being too quick to judge by appearances. Surprised, Chen took Man Kee, their son, to look at the grey sea. He held Man Kee close, who was warm and responsive, and placed his tiny hand on Chen's sleeve. In that moment, Chen decided to raise his son his way, giving him a good education in business, which was Chen's own weakness.

As Chen looked at the sea, he felt a mix of sadness and hope while planning Man Kee's future. He saw smoke on the horizon and then a ship appearing in the sunlight on the water. The sparkle of the waves changed Chen's mood. He put a coin in a telescope and tried to find the ship. At first, he struggled, but then he finally spotted it—a large, rusty tramp steamer. He lifted Man Kee to the telescope. "Do you see the ship, Son?" he asked gently. "It's a special little ship for people like us. It's small and old, but we know it will take us back home when we are done here. It will take you to your homeland, which you have never seen." Chen kissed Man Kee's head. 

Lily and Mui joined them. Lily put her arm around Chen's shoulders. "The little old ship," Chen said. "Let your mother see, Son." Man Kee didn't want to let go of the telescope, and when he finally did, the view was just a blurry circle of light. By the time Chen found another coin, the ship had disappeared over the horizon, leaving Lily watching seagulls searching for food in the water.

**THE WELL**

I once read that if you dig deep enough, you can see the stars on a clear day. I convinced you to help me with my idea. You watched, surprised, as I pulled up the well bucket, balanced it on the wall, and then climbed in. I asked you to lower me down. I didn’t consider that the bucket would be heavier, or that you might not be strong enough or willing to just let things happen. You held the handle, helping me as I pushed the bucket away from the well's edge. As soon as it was free, I fell straight down. You screamed and tried to stop the handle, but then you let go. I fell into the well and hit my head. At that moment, I didn’t realize I had achieved part of my plan. I saw strange lights, confusing and odd. Later, I connected these lights to the cartoon stars I had seen when characters got hurt. At first, I was dazed, then scared, then relieved, and finally angry at you for letting me fall, worried about what Mother would say. 

You called down to check if I was okay. I opened my mouth to shout, but then I heard panic in your voice, and I couldn’t speak. I lay still, peeking at you through my eyelashes. You disappeared, calling for help. I waited a moment, then quickly climbed back up and pulled myself over the edge, landing on the courtyard stones. I heard alarmed voices from the castle's main door. I ran away, down to the passage leading to the moat bridge, and hid in the shadows. Mother and Father came with you and old Arthur; Mother was screaming and waving her hands. Father shouted for Arthur to pull on the winch handle. You stood back, looking pale and shocked. I crouched in the shadows, feeling a rush of excitement. Then I noticed the drops of water I had left behind, from the well to where I stood. I looked in horror at the dark spots of dirty water on the dry stones. At my feet, the water had formed a small puddle. I looked back into the courtyard, where Father was shining a flashlight down into the well. The drops sparkled in the sunlight. I couldn’t believe no one had noticed them. Mother was now screaming loudly, a sound I had never heard before. It shook me deeply. What should I do? I had gotten back at you, but what now? This had quickly turned into something much more serious than I expected, going from a fun prank to a situation that would lead to serious punishment, likely for me. I regretted not thinking this through. 

In a moment of inspiration, I gathered my courage and left my hiding place, staggering out and blinking. I called out softly, one hand on my forehead, then yelled louder when no one responded. I stumbled a bit further and then dramatically collapsed on the stones. Sitting up, comforted by my crying mother, I sighed and said, "Oh dear," smiling bravely. I claimed that I had found a secret tunnel from the bottom of the well to the moat, and that I crawled and swam through it until I got out, climbed up the bridge, and walked through the passageway. I thought I was almost getting away with it until Father squatted in front of me. He made me repeat my story. I hesitated. His eyes narrowed. Thinking I was filling in gaps, I said the secret passage had collapsed after me; there was no point in sending someone to look for it. I insisted the well was dangerous and that I had barely escaped with my life. 

Looking into my father's eyes felt like staring into a dark tunnel with no light at the end. It seemed like he was seeing me for the first time, and I was looking down a path to adulthood, understanding how the world and children's lies would appear to me when I grew up. My words got stuck in my throat. "Don't be ridiculous, boy," he said, his tone full of contempt. He stood up and walked away. Arthur looked down at me, his face showing regret and concern. He seemed to want to shake his head, not because I had a scary adventure and was unfairly disbelieved by my father, but because he could see through my sad lie. He worried about the character and future of a child who lied so easily. His pity felt like a harsh rebuke, even more painful than my father's words. It made me realize that this was the mature judgment of my actions and my father's, something I couldn’t ignore. It affected me deeply.

**REMOVAL DAY**

Now that her children are grown, Susan, who is a widow, must leave her family home. The van had the words 'Removers of Distinction' on it, and indeed, everything that made the house special was being taken away. Fred, the removal man, with his large fingers, carefully packed all the fragile items, while his helpers were not as gentle. Susan was leaving a beautiful four-story house that overlooked a small harbor. The memories of her children growing up there lingered in the air, like dust.

When they first bought the house, her son Robert, who was five at the time, had asked, "Mum, how do you get a house home?" It was easy to miss the little boy he used to be, especially now that he was an adult helping with the move. He was particularly focused on making sure Susan didn’t forget about the piano. Francesca, their daughter, was also there, helping in her usual bossy way, convinced that only she could take care of the valuable Steinway piano.

Fred noticed Susan was not crying. "Do people cry?" she asked, curious. "You'd be surprised," he replied. "They seem happy while packing, but then they cry in an empty room. They are fine once they reach the new place; it’s just hard to see everything taken apart." Susan understood this feeling well. If it were up to her, she would have warned the movers about the piano before they started. But Robert insisted it was the movers' responsibility to notice such things.

The piano stood alone in the best room of the house, and they planned to move it last. Sitting on the bottom stair, with all the chairs gone, Susan remembered the day they moved in. Today felt like that day, but in reverse—the piano had been the first thing brought in, and it had gotten stuck on the stairs. The movers struggled for nearly two hours to get it up, while little Robert watched in awe and Francesca cried, "We can't live in a house without a piano!" They had to find a way to get it inside, and her late husband, Peter, had solved the problem. They left the piano in the garden while they moved in the other furniture. The next day, a builder removed the first-floor window, and a crane was borrowed to lift the piano through the opening. The children were overjoyed to see it come in, but it had cost a lot, and they had to wait months to have it tuned.

"That's that," Peter had said. "That's there forever." But forever is a long time. The children were too busy to visit often, and Susan found it harder to move around the house. She thought about the stairs and how the banister rails had never been perfectly fixed. She should have warned the movers, but it was too late now. 

Fred asked if she was okay. "Just the piano left now, and then we’ll be done," he said. Susan moved away from the stair, her heart racing. Robert and Francesca appeared in the hallway to watch. "No tears then?" Fred asked casually. In truth, she was close to crying. It was strange how moving things made them feel so important. Chairs, cups, and countless items that seemed unimportant before now felt full of emotion, and she felt she might cry.

Just then, the piano appeared at the top of the stairs, with Fred guiding it down. "Easy does it!" he called out, and they carefully brought it down and out the front door, placing it behind the van. Robert was the first to laugh, and soon they were all laughing, relieved that it was over. They leaned against each other, gasping for breath and laughing uncontrollably. "What’s the joke?" Fred asked, but his question only made them laugh more. As they walked down the path for the last time, the only tears Susan shed were tears of laughter.

**Online Literary Criticism for Everyone: Is DIY Literary Criticism Just Fun?**

From the beginning, one of the main ideas behind the Internet was to make information accessible to everyone. In theory, anyone could publish their thoughts or share music online. However, in the early days, some technical skills were needed. Still, one area that truly opened up to the public was literary criticism. By visiting Amazon.com, the first popular online bookstore, anyone could try writing book reviews. 

Amazon's approach to book reviews was simple: anyone could share their opinion and give a book up to five stars. Each book had its own page, and when a reader wrote a review, it would appear automatically. This allowed Amazon to fill its site with free reviews, helping potential buyers see what other readers thought, rather than just relying on publisher descriptions or professional critics.

Other online bookstores, which also had physical locations, offered similar features. However, Amazon was the largest, controlling over 80% of the online market. This meant it had the most customers and received the most reviews, but it also faced issues with dishonest practices. Thousands of reviews were submitted daily, making it impossible to check them all. Instead, a team of editors ensured that reviews followed Amazon's rules, such as banning one-word reviews or personal attacks on authors. However, since reviewers could remain anonymous, inappropriate reviews were only removed if noticed by Amazon's staff.

This anonymity allowed for some mischief. For instance, authors could write glowing reviews of their own books. One author, Lev Grossman, was upset by the negative reviews of his first novel, so he wrote several positive ones under a fake name to balance things out. His trick worked until he wrote an article revealing his deception, after which the fake reviews were removed.

Authors had a way to share their thoughts too, by clicking a link that allowed them to comment on their books. Most authors used this feature to encourage readers to buy and enjoy their work. Some even shared their email addresses for direct communication. However, Amazon did not verify that these comments were genuinely from the authors, except for well-known writers. For example, a lesser-known author pretended to be famous writer John Updike in a comment, but it was quickly identified as fake and removed.

The real drama often came from readers, not writers. When James McElroy's book about a cheerleading team was published, it received good reviews from the press. However, many people mentioned in the book felt hurt and expressed their anger through negative reviews on Amazon. These reviews often disappeared after a few days. Despite this, Amazon saw the large number of reviews as beneficial for business. 

Amazon aimed to keep reviews focused on discussing books rather than casual chatting, especially for bestsellers. This meant that silly reviews were more likely to appear on pages for less popular books. For example, a classic children's book called *The Story about Ping*, which tells the tale of a duck, inspired humorous reviews that compared its plot to Internet technology. One review even made a complex analogy between the book and networking concepts. However, such silliness was rare. 

Most reviews on Amazon were taken seriously by their writers. Overall, these reviews provided a good indication of whether a product was worth buying. The writer George Orwell once said that reviewing too many books made it hard to have genuine feelings about them. This highlights the importance of allowing everyone to participate in the review process.

**Art in Modern Times**

In recent years, especially over the last two hundred years, we often think that every artist must challenge the art of their time. Art is celebrated for being unique, revolutionary, and sometimes shocking. We enjoy admiring artists whose work was not valued in the past. However, when it comes to contemporary art, we often hesitate and claim that some artists have gone too far, suggesting that their work is no longer art. The media often expresses these views for us, and we tend to agree because we expect art to be confusingly new. This expectation makes us overlook the traditional themes, methods, and qualities that are still present in today’s art. We want artists to be different from us, with special talents and energy that break free from conventions. In the past, people commissioned artists for specific purposes, and art was part of everyday life. Today, we leave artists to work independently and sometimes become frustrated if they try to connect with us.

**Picture This**

I will describe a situation and then ask an important question. An artist selects a text from an art book that discusses the variety of pictures. The text asks, "What are they all about?" and concludes, "There is no end to the different kinds of pictures." This may sound childish, but bear with me. The artist then asks someone to prepare a canvas and take it to a sign painter. He instructs the sign painter to write the chosen text on the canvas in simple black letters without any fancy designs. The sign painter follows these instructions. My important question is: is the final product a painting?

**Underground Encounters**

At the Mercury Gallery in London until June 26, there is an unspoken rule in the art world: once an artist finds success in a particular style, they should stick to it. Collectors expect artists to continue producing similar work, and if they try something new, it often leads to disappointment among the public. I’m not sure why this is the case. Gallery owners prefer safe choices, and perhaps art buyers feel more secure with familiar styles. However, some artists break this pattern and succeed, like Picasso and Hockney. Eric Rimmington is another artist who is trying something different, and it will be interesting to see if he succeeds. His new exhibition replaces the still lifes he is known for with paintings inspired by the London Underground. Rimmington finds a unique charm in railways. His earlier drawings of Kings Cross Station led him to explore the underground world, resulting in "Underground Encounters," an exhibition of 40 paintings and drawings that capture the fascinating atmosphere of this hidden environment.

**Extract from a Novel**

I have come to this island with a few books. I use the word "escape" because the villagers jokingly say that only someone unwell would choose such a remote place to recover. So, I have come here to heal myself. Besides an old peasant who visits daily to clean, I am quite alone. I feel neither happy nor sad; I exist in a state of reflection. I mentioned the uselessness of art but did not speak of its comforting aspects. The true comfort of my work lies in the ability to reshape reality through art. Our everyday actions often hide the deeper meaning of life. For artists, art offers a joyful way to confront the challenges of daily life, allowing us to fulfill our true potential through imagination. Otherwise, why would we cause each other pain?

**Family Business**

"Listen, this isn't good!" my Dad said. We were driving back to London. He had just picked me and my trunk up from the fancy girls' school I attended, after sitting through Parent's Day. I had received the Latin prize and the award for the best end-of-school exams. He had a long talk with my headteacher, and now we were heading home for the holidays.

"What isn't?" I asked, though I had a feeling I knew what he was thinking because he was unusually quiet. Normally, he talked a lot. "You can't trick me. You'll do what you want now," he said. "With all those certificates, I heard you might get a scholarship to Oxford."

"So?" I replied, trying to act tough. "Wouldn't that be useful?" he continued. "I also heard you want to be a barrister. A barrister!" My father knew a lot about lawyers and the law. "I just said that," I explained. "I couldn't think of anything else!"

"And apparently," he continued, "you have the right personality. You can quickly understand complex information, you’re good at speaking, and you enjoy performing." "I don't know about that," I said. "I only know what I see on TV dramas."

"Regardless," he said, gathering himself, "I feel like your heart isn't in the family business anymore. You'll go to Oxford, and after that, I can't see you wanting to join us." The truth was, like many children in family businesses, I felt trapped by my father's expectations. I saw many career options and wanted to explore them. But, like a coward, I didn't want to upset my father. I wasn't as scared of him as my brother Maurice was—I was the favorite—but I still found him intimidating.

"It's too soon to know," I said weakly. "You're not going to want to join us," my father insisted, who often turned out to be right about such things. "It's a shame because you have the talent—brains, courage, and vision." "There's still Maurice," I said, feeling down. My father scoffed. We both knew Maurice disliked the business.

"Anyway," I added, "you could always use me as a consultant." My mother had passed away when I was young, and my father raised me and Maurice. I was two years older than Maurice, and since he was motherless, I took care of him. It wasn't a burden; I loved him. Because the business was successful, we lived comfortably—in a big house in London, attended nice schools, wore good clothes, and enjoyed parties, theaters, and operas. My father knew many interesting people—politicians, actors, and businessmen—and our home was always lively.

"I have an idea," my father said. "You can help us during holidays until you leave Oxford, and then if you want to leave, you can. It will give you some pocket money and help me." "Okay," I replied, relieved to avoid immediate decisions and the sadness my father would feel if I disagreed. This was how he controlled us.

So, it happened. In my last term at school and during university breaks, I helped out, never more than twice a year and always with easier tasks. I became one of the top students, had a small house, a nice white car, designer clothes, and a black dress from Paris for my final exams.

In my last term, my father visited me and took me to a village for a meal and a chat. With only a few weeks left, my tutor predicted I would earn a First Class degree in Law. I knew that if I focused and organized my thoughts, he might be right. I felt ready and confident. But then my father told me he needed me to do one last important task for the family business, the biggest one they had ever attempted, and he promised it would be worth my while.

"But Dad," I protested, "I have my final exams coming up, and I need to focus on that. It's really important, and I don't want to think about anything else right now." I could tell my father didn't understand this pressure (or maybe he was jealous of my life away from him), and he would see my refusal as a betrayal in his time of need.

As he explained the task, I realized more than ever how determined my father was—the clarity and resourcefulness he had in his work, his energy, and self-control. In his way, he was a genius, and I respected that. It made my own plans seem less significant. "All right," I said. "I'll do it."

Simon Costello realized that buying the house in Pembroke Square was a mistake within a year of moving in with Lois. Owning something that requires strict budgeting is often not worth it. At the time, however, it seemed like a smart and appealing choice. Simon had been winning cases regularly, and Lois had returned to her job at the advertising agency just two months after giving birth to their twins, receiving a salary increase to thirty-five thousand. Lois strongly advocated for the move, and Simon did not resist her arguments, which seemed convincing at the time: their flat was not suitable for a family, they needed more space, a garden, and separate living quarters for an au pair. They could have found these in a less trendy area of London, but Lois wanted more than just extra room. Mornington Mansions was not a suitable address for a rising barrister and a successful businesswoman. Even saying the name made her feel it lowered her social and economic status.

Lois decided that one of them should save money by using public transport, and it was clear that Simon would be the one to do so since her office was on the other side of London. The crowded tube rides became a frustrating thirty minutes of resentment and reflection on their problems. He often thought of his grandfather's house in Hampstead, where he had spent time as a child, remembering the comforting smells of dinner and his grandmother's care for her husband after a long day in court. She had been a supportive lawyer's wife, active in legal causes and content in her role. But that world was gone. Lois had made it clear before they married that her career was just as important as his. This was a modern marriage, and both of their jobs were crucial for their lifestyle, which depended on two incomes.

Now, their fragile situation could be threatened by Venetia, who had come to their office in a bad mood. Something had clearly upset her, and her anger was intense. Simon regretted not leaving his room earlier; if he had, the confrontation might not have happened, and Venetia could have had time to calm down. He remembered her accusations clearly: she claimed that a client, Brian Cartwright, had told her that Simon knew about jury bribery four years ago but did nothing. Simon denied it, but his response felt weak even to him. He felt guilty and ashamed, recalling the fear of punishment from his school days. Looking into Venetia's eyes, he saw her disbelief. He wished he had said that Cartwright had told him after the trial, but he had instead told a more dangerous lie, which she recognized.

He wondered why Venetia was so angry and what her past actions in court had been. Was she justified in threatening his career? He was uncertain about what she could do, but if rumors spread, it could ruin him.

I chose to live in this place because I thought I could be anonymous among people who didn’t mind if their rented homes were falling apart or if their gardens were messy. I was wrong. The shopkeepers, who are living their real lives, soon start to recognize me, even if I try to stay hidden. The beautiful roses from my neighbor’s garden remind me that gardens can be loved. Usually, I stay inside to forget about the summer outside, but tonight I am watching the swifts flying between the trees and roofs. I have trimmed some herbs to make space for a chair, and my arms are stinging from scratches. 

It’s a small London garden where plants have to grow tall or spread out to survive. My upstairs neighbor, Jaz, leans out of her window and comments on my gardening. She is a writer with several unpublished works, and I sometimes help her with them as an English teacher. I have her latest manuscript with me. “How’s the writing going, Jaz?” I ask. She complains about how people constantly ask her about her work. “I have something to drink in the fridge. I’ll bring it down,” she says. I don’t want her in the garden, and I realize it looks messy. Jaz knocks on my door. 

“So, you’re on holiday now, lucky you,” she says, sitting in the chair while I place a cushion on what used to be a small lawn. “Cheers,” she says, pretending to be young. “I should’ve become a teacher – writers don’t get holidays. But you know what they say, those who can, do; those who can’t, teach.” And then there are those who can do neither. “What are your plans for the holidays?” she asks. I feel overwhelmed by the empty days ahead. 

“Actually, I’m going to Stonebridge tomorrow. Can you feed my cats?” I ask. My heart races as I speak. “Of course,” Jaz replies, knowing she will be around. “Where will you stay? A fancy B and B?” “No, I’ll be with my oldest friend, Ruby, at the Rising Sun. We’ve known each other since we were kids.” This isn’t true, but I often deal with fiction. 

“Going back to your roots. What do you think of my manuscript?” Jaz asks about her story, The Cruelty of Red Vans, which I haven’t read much of. I like the title and tell her so. I can see how red vans could be cruel, always bringing gifts to other homes. I decide to be honest for once. “Let me give you a little advice,” I say. “What?” she asks, looking offended. “Try writing about nice people for a change, those who want to be good: a bit less self-centeredness, more fiction…” 

“Teachers!” Jaz responds like a rebellious student. “I keep a journal where I write something good about each day,” I say, sounding a bit old-fashioned. “Keep a journal! Nice people! Get a life, Ann.” Oh, I have a life. I work, go out sometimes, and read on the tube. When we finally go inside, my calm kitchen gives me a moment of comfort, but then I suddenly remember my old geography teacher, Miss Tarrantine, who was about my age now. She once winked at us and said, “I’ve had my moments.” We were shocked.

**Heritage**

Heritage is important because it connects people and communities to their past. We often feel connected to our personal heritage, knowing about our grandparents and hearing stories about their lives. However, there is also a broader need to understand our history to help us shape our future, both individually and nationally. Heritage represents our desire for continuity; knowing about the past helps us feel secure about the future. Just as we inherit our genes, we also inherit a culture that has been passed down through generations. While there may be aspects of our national heritage that we do not like, it is still a part of us, and it is comforting to belong to something larger. Heritage teaches us a lot and is essential for our well-being, influencing everything from traditions to material culture. 

In the past, we learned about our heritage through stories and legends from our ancestors. However, in modern industrial societies, many of these oral traditions have been lost as communities and families have become less connected. Now, we often rely on places and buildings to remind us of our past. It is crucial to preserve and restore these connections as a tribute to our ancestors' identities.

**The Fens**

Some time ago, I started writing a novel called *Waterland*, where the landscape of a region in England known as the Fens became very important. After the book was published, people often asked why I, a Londoner with no personal ties to the area, chose to write about it. The simple answer is that I found the Fens interesting because they seemed plain and empty, providing a blank canvas for my story. However, I soon realized that the Fens are not truly flat or empty. They are uniquely English yet also strangely captivating. It is surprising that in the heart of England, there is a place that many English people find oddly foreign, especially since many other distinct areas of Britain have become part of the national culture. The Fens are both empty and full, cultivated yet wild, seemingly simple but deeply mysterious.

While writing my novel, I did not explore the Fens extensively; I have not yet visited places like Wisbech or Prickwillow. As a fiction writer, I prefer to create imagined worlds rather than seek strict factual evidence. However, this imaginative approach makes sense because, as shown in Edward Storey's scholarly work, the Fens are not just a landscape but also a way of thinking.

**Museums**

Museums need to make their collections easy to access. In the past, this meant simply putting items in display cases with long descriptions that were hard for most people to understand. Today, accessibility should involve more than that. Displays can be engaging and use creative techniques to attract visitors and evoke emotions. However, museums should offer more than just displays; they should reach out to the widest community possible. For example, some museums provide loan boxes of objects for teachers, and recently, similar materials have been made available to help elderly people with memory loss.

Museums focus on real artifacts and specimens, not replicas. They exist to provide an authentic experience, showcasing items that have historical significance. This authenticity is what sets them apart from heritage centers, theme parks, books, and digital media. Museums that embrace this challenge and create exciting, accessible displays and outreach programs will find that their competitors in "virtual history" can actually help spark interest in the real experiences that museums uniquely offer.

**Architecture and Environment**

The desire to preserve our surroundings is not new, but the rapid changes in our towns affect everyone. This can lead some people to become passionate about preservation while encouraging others to think more deeply about the nature of our towns and their future. It can be argued that people who have lived through significant events, like world wars, are more inclined to value preservation, as anything that represents stability becomes important. If there is a psychological need for preservation, planners must consider it. Change is not necessarily bad if we learn how to manage it. Physical changes in our towns reflect social changes, including shifts in population, welfare, and demands.

**Einstein**

If you stop someone on the street and ask them to name a scientist, they will likely mention Albert Einstein. His image is often used to promote products that suggest intelligence, such as computers and encyclopedias. Most people know little about Einstein's work, except that he created complex theories called 'relativity,' which are famous for being difficult to understand and for making strange predictions that seem to contradict everyday experiences. Einstein was part of a major shift in scientific thought, a revolution that marked the beginning of modern science in the twentieth century. Physicists and mathematicians were trying to develop a new, more logical understanding of the universe by examining the relationships between matter and natural forces. Einstein made significant contributions by rethinking the basic concepts of time, space, matter, and energy. Earlier theories were based on Isaac Newton's idea of a universe where stars and planets moved in a fixed framework of space and time. Einstein challenged this idea, arguing that time and space are not fixed but relative.

**Young Readers**

As children, Lydia and I were skeptical of any book that won awards because we believed it would be serious and, therefore, boring. While our mother disapproved of our lack of appreciation for such books, our father would happily give us small coins for each chapter we read, encouraging us to look at some worthwhile books. He would also include a few superior books among our Christmas and birthday gifts, clearly marked as 'This Book is NOT Literature.' Although we often dismissed his choices as 'boys' books,' he did introduce us to some shorter works of good fiction and, on one occasion, to a famous collection of poetry.

**Language**

Jacob Grimm wrote in 1851, "The origin of human language is truly secret and marvellous." This fascinating mystery has led to many unusual ideas. For example, Charles Caller suggested in 1928 that early humans might have made sounds like "meuh" when they sensed danger. This sound is quite sad. The early human who traveled through dangerous lands filled with terrifying animals might have made desperate noises, and some words have kept a trace of this sorrow, such as 'malaria,' which means "fever," or the Latin word 'mors,' meaning "death." Because of such strange theories, many people avoided discussing the topic, seeing it as a place for odd ideas. However, recently, the origins and evolution of language have become important areas of research. Language likely began in East Africa about 100,000 years ago. Initially, speech was mainly used for friendly communication and played a crucial role in power struggles. Sharing information was probably not its primary purpose, which goes against the views of philosopher John Locke, who described language as a 'great conduit' for sharing knowledge.

**Writing Reviews**

Frank Kermode discusses the art of writing reviews from the perspective of someone who practices it. Most reviews are created and shared in ways that limit their lifespan. They often have strict deadlines and length restrictions, and once published, they are only relevant for a short time—usually a day, a week, or at most a month. The temporary nature of reviews often affects how they are viewed. Many people, including the writers themselves, believe that reviewing is a task done out of necessity, often due to financial reasons, or because writers need a break from working on their main projects.

However, writing reviews is a skilled and complex task. Writing a concise review of six to eight hundred words for a newspaper is different from crafting a detailed review of six to eight thousand words for an international journal. A review of fifteen hundred words in a weekly magazine combines challenges from both short and long formats. Length is not the only factor to consider. Reviewers must think about their audience, ranging from casual readers to those who are deeply interested in the subject.

Additionally, a reviewer needs to have knowledge about various topics and must write in a way that is clear and enjoyable for intelligent readers. It is common for reviewers to also write other types of content. For example, American novelist John Updike, who is somewhat critical of criticism, still engages in reviewing while writing his novels. He collects all his reviews, no matter how brief, into books with modest titles.

Some might think that less prominent writers should accept the temporary nature of their work, but it is understandable if they wish to have some lasting recognition, especially if they feel their best writing is found in reviews. I share this sentiment about my own work. My main focus has been academic writing, and my serious books are typically academic in nature, which is what professors are expected to produce.

In the English-speaking world, there is no strict separation between reviewing and literary study, unlike in some other cultures. It is common for the same individuals to engage in both activities. The past stigma against professors who write reviews has diminished, and complaints from non-professors about professors taking opportunities away from them are less frequent. This is partly because there are more reviewing opportunities available now, allowing many people to participate.

I believe this situation benefits both readers and professors. Readers can trust that reviewers have some expertise, and for professors, reviewing helps maintain their mental well-being. It also serves as a reminder that they should communicate clearly with non-professors. While they may enjoy using complex language among themselves, they need to ensure they are understandable when addressing a broader audience.

Ultimately, despite its value, reviewing is often a secondary activity. It is something that can only be done well if one is also engaged in other meaningful work.

Ralph unlocked the door to his apartment and, as he stepped into the dark, quiet hallway, he felt a brief sense of ownership that still surprised him after three years. When he first bought the flat, he would come home excited and curious, wondering what had happened in his absence. The flat felt like a welcoming space where he could focus without distractions. He thought he should worry about possible intruders or broken pipes, but his flat always seemed to wait for him, reflecting either independence or neglect, depending on how tidy he had left it.

Over time, he began to see it as an extension of himself, a place where his thoughts and feelings overflowed. He grew frustrated with its inability to change. There were always a few letters piled up by the door and the answering machine blinking with messages when he returned. He was thankful that his windows were intact and that nothing had been violently disturbed, though he often wondered what the flat would look like if it had been.

From his dull office on the third floor, Ralph looked forward to his quiet evenings at home. After leaving the busy office and starting his bus ride home, he no longer wanted to be alone, even though he often craved solitude while at his desk. The relief of escaping work left him feeling empty, making him question who he really was. He would read or listen to music at night, but he began to wonder for whom he was doing these things. His sense of direction in life had faded, and thoughts would come and go without making sense.

He remembered a time when he felt more in control of his life. He had wanted to improve himself but found that he only wanted to get by. He applied for jobs he heard about from friends, following their paths without thinking about his own happiness. He attended one interview with gratitude, not considering the job's details. When Neil, his future boss, offered him the job on the spot, Ralph took it as a compliment, not realizing it would lead to many more long conversations.

**Goat Racing**

I was about to see goat racing on Easter Monday in Buccoo Village. I pushed my way through ice-cream vans, large crowds, food stalls, and loud music. Although everyone was moving towards the racecourse, I tried to find a good spot to watch. An area was set up for the race, not as fancy as regular racecourses, but similar in that spectators lined both sides of the track where the goats would run. It was a challenge to keep a few selected goats in line, especially since goats are known for eating almost anything they find.

**Canoe Trip**

As the day ended, I began to worry about the night ahead. The canoe was too wet to sleep in, there were no places to stop, and we hadn’t seen any villages or huts since early morning. In the dim moonlight, we could barely see the cliffs, and when we changed the batteries in our torch, they didn’t work. We realized we wouldn’t be able to find a place to camp. A few miles later, Lesley shouted that she saw a flickering light, and we felt hopeful. But the light was just the moon reflecting on the waves. Soon, we heard the loud sound of rushing water, but we couldn’t see what was happening. Time seemed to stop as we continued on.

**How to Be Presentation Perfect**

I am not naturally good at making presentations, but as managing director, I often need to present to my colleagues and major shareholders. How can I improve my presentation skills and confidence? You are not alone. Presenting requires different skills than running a company, but many senior executives are expected to be good at it. To convince your audience, you must first believe in what you are saying. Show your belief through your passion and enthusiasm during the presentation. This means you need to prepare well. Test your ideas beforehand and ask colleagues to help identify tough questions your audience might ask. You should also create a positive atmosphere from the start. Begin with something everyone can relate to and gradually lead to the conclusion you want to reach.

Some activities cannot be rushed; they require their own time. If you are late for a meeting, you can hurry. However, if you are impatient with mayonnaise and add the oil too quickly, it will spoil. Similarly, if you pull on a tangled fishing line in frustration, the knot will only get tighter. The mind also works at different speeds. Some functions happen very quickly, while others take longer—seconds, minutes, hours, days, or even years. We can improve our speed in some tasks, like solving crossword puzzles or doing math, but other processes cannot be hurried. If we try to rush them, they may fail, just like the mayonnaise or the fishing line.

The idea of "Think fast; we need results" can sometimes be as unhelpful as trying to shorten a night's sleep.
