Additionally, coaches often change frequently, leading to instability in the women's team. Despite these challenges, I enjoy rowing and staying fit, and I appreciate the social aspect of the sport."

**D. Ffyona, 24, Long-Distance Walker**  
"When I was 13, I dreamed of walking around the world, not realizing how vast it is! I found Britain too confining and safe. I was very determined and disliked being controlled. Each walk has been unique. My walk across Australia was the most painful experience, covering 50 miles a day with little sleep and many blisters. But I set a record! I had to succeed because my sponsorship would end after 95 days. Some men believe women are more likely to fail, making them hesitant to sponsor us."

**E. Lisa, 26, Saloon Car Racer**  
"Some men have big egos when driving, which is evident on the roads. When I perform well, they often ignore me. Being a woman has its challenges; men often feel they must beat me, leading to many tough moments. You need to be competitive and assertive. It's hard to earn money in this sport, and what I do make goes back into racing. Women have been racing since the 1920s and have often been seen as unusual. It's encouraging to see more women joining the sport each year. For me, the thrill of saloon car racing lies in striving for perfection and achieving the perfect lap."

**F. Alison, 28, Triathlete**  
"I wake up at 5:30 AM three mornings a week to swim. I need Tuesday and Thursday mornings to catch up on sleep. In the evenings, I either cycle or run. Yes, I sometimes fall asleep at my desk! There is a lot of pressure before races, and I really push myself during competitions. I often wonder why I do this. The answers are: a) I feel happier when I stay fit, b) I would be lazy if I didn't force myself to train, and c) racing is very social. Men and women usually compete together, but when events are covered in the media, 90% of the focus is on the men's events, with only 10% mentioning the women's results. The prize money is also less for women. However, we have established an International Triathlon Women's Commission to address these issues."

**The Day I Met Picasso**

Richard Cork remembers the day he met Picasso when he was 78 years old. Even from a distance, he recognized Picasso, who was having lunch at an outdoor restaurant in Cannes. At that time, I was an 18-year-old student traveling around Europe and Morocco in an old van. I had run out of money and found a job painting boats by the waterfront. However, I spent a lot of my time drawing and had my sketchbook with me when I saw Picasso.

Picasso was known to be a private person, usually working in the hills. So, I was surprised to see him sitting at a table with his wife, Jacqueline, and some friends. I would not have approached him if my friend hadn’t encouraged me. Nervously, I introduced myself and asked for his signature, and to my surprise, he agreed. He wrote his name at the top of my sketchbook and then added a lively drawing below it. His art often reflected real things, so the lines he drew might have represented a cloud, the sea, or the shape of Cannes harbor.

I thanked him and started a hesitant conversation. Since Picasso's English was not very good and my French was even worse, an American woman at the table helped translate. She kept calling him "the Maestro," which made it hard for me to speak. Still, I managed to tell Picasso how much I loved art and admired his work. After a while, I went back to my boat and proudly showed my friend what I had. But he noticed that Picasso was still having lunch and urged me to go back and talk to him again. 

With my sketchbook in hand, I returned to Picasso's table. I decided not to ask if I could draw his portrait, fearing he might say no. Instead, I stood by the table, set up my pad, and began to draw. When Picasso saw me, he smiled mischievously and made it hard for me to draw by making funny faces and gestures. Despite his antics, I felt he was testing my determination. Eventually, he settled down and allowed me to study him closely.

I noticed how strong and alert he looked, dressed in a blue-and-white striped shirt. He seemed much younger than his age, with bright, dark eyes that were full of life. Even though he was surrounded by friends, he appeared to be in his own world, quietly focused on his thoughts. When the American woman told me that Picasso wanted to see my drawing, I felt shy and thought it wasn’t good enough. But he insisted, and when I showed it to him, he nodded approvingly.

Then, to my surprise, he said it was his turn to draw. I quickly gave him my crayon, and he made a few quick strokes on the paper. In seconds, he sketched a bearded face that looked very different from my careful drawing. He had humorously placed one of my eyes on my nose and captured my smile with a single lively line. I looked like a character from one of his playful artworks. 

I thanked Picasso and asked if he would sign my drawing. The American woman explained that he said I already had his signature. So, he had limits to his generosity! Still, I feel incredibly lucky to have met Picasso and received his attention. It meant a lot to me.

**Talking Shop**

Have you ever gone into a store and ended up buying more than you planned? This article explains the strategies that shops use to encourage you to spend more money.

**A. The Image of Freshness**  
Supermarkets understand that customers value fresh food. To create this impression, they often place fruits and vegetables at the entrance of the store. They might also have a bakery that fills the air with the smell of fresh bread. The colors in the store, like green, are chosen because they remind people of fresh produce. However, most items sold in supermarkets, like frozen foods and cleaning products, do not fit this fresh image.

**B. Displaying to Advantage**  
The placement of products in a store is crucial for sales. Supermarkets use technology to find out which areas attract the most shoppers. They place high-profit items in these spots, while also using eye-level shelves to catch attention. Special offer bins are placed strategically to attract bargain hunters. Additionally, they often place related items together, like desserts near ice cream, to encourage more purchases.

**C. Spreading Staples Around the Store**  
Supermarkets often place low-cost essentials like bread and sugar far from the entrance. This way, shoppers must walk past more expensive items, which may tempt them to buy. Chain stores also position their popular products away from the entrance, hoping loyal customers will search for them and encounter other tempting items along the way.

**D. Less Sells More**  
In recent years, chain stores have changed how they display their products. For example, the Next chain has moved away from a crowded display style to a more boutique-like approach, showcasing limited fashion items. This gives the impression of exclusivity, even though their clothing is still mass-produced. Their success is due to both good store design and appealing clothing.

**E. Tempting Totals**  
Shoppers often focus more on the total cost of their shopping rather than the price of individual items. Supermarkets mix low-cost staples with higher-priced items to attract customers. They may even sell some staples at a loss to draw people in, a strategy known as "loss leaders." They achieve low prices by buying in bulk and negotiating discounts with manufacturers.

**F. The All-Important Price Tag**  
Customers tend to buy fewer items in chain stores and pay more attention to individual prices. For example, pricing a blouse at £14.99 instead of £15 can make a difference. This pricing strategy also helps reduce theft, as employees must ring up sales to give change.

**G. Lighting to Effect**  
Both supermarkets and chain stores carefully consider their lighting. Chain stores aim for lighting that resembles natural light, helping customers see the true colors of clothing. Supermarkets use special lighting and mirrors to highlight fresh produce.

**H. Walk This Way**  
Many chain stores use different carpet patterns to guide shoppers through the store. These paths, known as the "Yellow Brick Road," encourage customers to explore. Some stores, like Marks and Spencer, use more inviting carpets in sales areas to encourage shoppers to venture off the main paths.

**I. In-Store Promotion**  
As you enter a supermarket, you are often greeted by large, colorful images of delicious food, which can be hard to resist if you are hungry. In the U.S., some supermarkets are testing "video trolleys" that display advertisements as you shop. These trolleys aim to attract impulse buyers and claim to increase sales by about 30%.

**Sea, Ice & Rock**

Chris Bonnington, aged 58, is famous for reaching the summit of Everest in 1985. He has also created new climbing routes in Britain and the Alps and has written several books, such as *Quest for Adventure* and *Everest the Hard Way*. Robin Knox-Johnston, who is 53, started his career at sea in the Merchant Navy. In 1968-1969, he became the first person to sail solo around the world in his yacht, Sunhaili. He also set a record for crossing the Atlantic Ocean, taking just 10 days to sail from New York to the Lizard in England. 

Chris and Robin worked together to sail and climb in Greenland, documenting their journey in their new book, *Sea, Ice and Rock*. In 1979, while I was working on *Quest for Adventure*, I called Robin for an interview. He invited me to join him for a sailing trip. I could teach him some climbing techniques, and he could teach me the basics of sailing. It was my first experience on a yacht. We sailed for a while and then anchored. Robin's wife and daughter stayed on the boat while we paddled to shore to practice climbing. The route was challenging, but I was impressed by how steady Robin was in difficult conditions. 

Eventually, we reached a steep drop. I asked Robin if he had ever climbed before, and he said he hadn’t, so I showed him how. After I finished, Robin politely asked if he could descend using the ropes from his boat. He was used to using his arms, while I wanted him to use his legs. I was a bit uneasy, but he managed to lower himself safely. During that trip to Skye, Robin and I formed a strong friendship. His suggestion that we combine our skills for a trip to Greenland was a natural progression from our Skye adventure.

I was very impressed by Robin as a leader. Normally, the captain makes all the decisions, but Robin always consulted the crew first. Most of the time, no one dared to give him advice, but it felt good to be part of the decision-making. Honestly, I found sailing quite challenging and boring. The moments of crisis were easier to handle because they brought excitement. However, I struggled with spending day after day in the middle of the ocean. I prefer being on land and am not very handy. In contrast, Robin is a natural sailor who enjoys fixing the engine or repairing the toilet. I realized that Robin didn’t really need my help, which sometimes made me feel useless.

The crew was also cramped, with six people on a 32-foot yacht designed for four. On a mountain expedition, you can get away from each other, but that wasn’t possible on the boat. When we arrived in Greenland and it was my turn to lead the expedition, I found it hard to take responsibility for Robin’s safety. There were many moments while climbing when if Robin had fallen, he could have taken me down with him. I had to be very careful. I underestimated how difficult the Cathedral, Greenland's highest mountain, would be. Robin is not a natural climber, which made his efforts even more impressive. 

The first time we tried to reach the top, we were active for 24 hours. On the way down, we were so tired that we almost fell asleep on steep slopes, 1,500 feet above the ground. Robin faced many challenges, but he completely trusted me and followed my lead. When it became too difficult and I realized we had to turn back, he accepted my decision. I also knew that Robin was concerned about the boat: whether it could get through the ice and if it was still intact. Yet, he was eager for us to try climbing the mountain again.

The only time our relationship almost faced a crisis was on the yacht on the way home. We were taking turns keeping watch. I was supposed to wake up at 4 am for my shift, but Robin decided not to wake me, thinking he could handle it alone. The night before, I had nearly fallen asleep. I felt he didn’t trust me, which made me insecure, and I expressed my feelings. Robin quickly reassured me that I had misunderstood the situation. While we enjoyed our trip to Skye, we truly got to know each other during the Greenland expedition. I discovered that beneath his tough exterior, Robin is a kind-hearted and sensitive person.

**A History of the Apple**

Apples have been part of human life since ancient times, appearing in many colors, shapes, and sizes. However, in the late twentieth century, we risk losing this rich heritage.

**Prehistoric Times (8,000 BC)**  
Humans have eaten apples since prehistoric times. In neolithic Britain, they would spit out apple seeds. Around 10,000 years ago, people left apple remains near their homes by lakes in Switzerland and Italy. In these areas, ancient humans even stored dried apple halves for winter. These early apples were wild crab apples, small and shriveled, quite different from the apples we know today.

**Norman Influence (1000 AD)**  
The French learned advanced fruit-growing techniques from the Romans, which were further developed in monasteries. This knowledge, including cider-making, was brought to Britain. One dessert apple, called Decio, was thought to have been introduced by the Roman general, Etio. However, many Roman apple varieties did not thrive in Britain, and soon Norman varieties became more popular. British monks continued to experiment and create new apple types, which are the ancestors of most Western apples today.

**Medieval Favorites (1200)**  
During the thirteenth century, several apple varieties became popular in Britain. The Old English Pearmain, noted in 1204 for its pear-like shape, was the main dessert apple until the eighteenth century. The Costard was a cooking apple sold in Oxford markets from 1296 until the late seventeenth century, giving rise to the term 'costermonger,' meaning a street seller of fruits and vegetables. However, the country faced challenges like droughts, the Black Death, and the Wars of the Roses, leading to fewer apples being produced and more being imported. This trend continued until the sixteenth century when King Henry VIII sent his chief fruit expert, Richard Harris, to France to learn about apple growing. Harris returned with many grafts, including the famous Pippins, and established the first modern orchard in Teynham, Kent.

**Settler Treasures (1750)**  
By the seventeenth century, apples were so beloved in Britain that the first settlers to Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand took apples and seeds with them, considering them precious. Captain Bligh of the Bounty brought the first apples to Australia, Jan van Riebeeck took them to South Africa, and the Pilgrim Fathers carried them to America. In North America, the well-known apple planter was John Chapman, known as 'Johnny Appleseed.' Born in 1774, he planted apple nurseries from Pennsylvania to Indiana. Native Americans viewed him as a medicine man, and his love for apple trees, unique clothing, and religious beliefs led to many folktales about him, including stories of him sleeping with bears.

**Modern Delicious (1850)**  
Around this time, a Quaker farmer named Jesse Hiatt in Iowa discovered a new apple tree growing from the roots of a dead tree. He named this apple 'Hawkey.' After presenting it at a fruit show, a judge tasted it and exclaimed, "Delicious!" In 1895, this apple was introduced to the market as 'Delicious' and became one of the most widely grown apples globally.

**Granny Smith (1850)**  
Another famous apple, the Granny Smith, was found in Australia by Maria Anne Smith. The daughter of convicts, Maria was independent and worked as a midwife in Eastwood, New South Wales. She was known as 'Granny Smith' because she managed the family farm and orchard. In 1868, she discovered a small tree growing among discarded fruit. She transplanted it, and soon she was harvesting the first major crop of green apples, which became famous worldwide. When asked about the tree's origin, she remarked, "Well, it's just like God to make something useful out of what we think is rubbish," referring to both the fruit and her own background.

**Uniformity Issues (1950)**  
Today, apples are grown worldwide, from northern India to luxury orchards in Africa. However, most apples are commercially produced and come from only a few varieties, often chosen for their appearance or ability to travel rather than their taste. This trend of uniformity is dulling our taste and reducing genetic diversity. While amateur gardeners in the UK have preserved many old apple varieties, the US has lost most of its apples from a century ago. Fortunately, consumers are beginning to seek more variety. We cannot rely solely on amateur gardeners to preserve diversity in apples or any food. We must advocate for a world that values and protects natural diversity for everyone's benefit.

**Explore Worldwide - Small Groups, Big Adventures**

Explore Worldwide is a leader in adventure travel, offering trips for those who want more than just a beach holiday. We focus on unique and interesting destinations with original itineraries. Our brochure features over 100 adventures, including tours, treks, safaris, and expeditions, in more than 60 countries. Most trips last between 1 to 4 weeks.

**Small Groups**

Our groups are small, averaging 16 people, and are led by experienced guides. This allows you to truly explore the places we visit and connect with the local culture and people. It’s a rewarding experience for all travelers.

**Variety of Travel**

We use many types of transport during our trips, often on the same journey. You might travel by coach, local bus, train, minibus, boat, canoe, raft, camel, light plane, or even on foot. Each trip reflects the local environment.

**Who Travels with Explore?**

Our travelers are interesting individuals who are ready to embrace new experiences. Most come from the UK, Europe, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, and the USA. Our trips are designed for anyone in good health, who is reasonably fit and adaptable. Most participants are between 25 and 55 years old, with many traveling as couples or solo.

**Activities and Interests**

Each trip with Explore Worldwide is unique, so we categorize our adventures into eight groups based on main activities and interests. Each category highlights special features of the tours, but many other factors contribute to the overall enjoyment of your holiday, such as unique places, cultural encounters, and unexpected events.

**Cultural/Adventure**

Most of our trips have a strong cultural focus. Some tours emphasize local cultures, ethnic groups, and historical sites. Destinations of cultural interest include Egypt, Jordan, Syria, Yemen, Turkey, Greece, India, Bhutan, Thailand, China, Peru, Bolivia, Guatemala, and Belize. Many trips include short walks to visit less-known sites.

**Wildlife and Natural History**

Our wildlife safaris take you to some of the best game parks in the world, allowing you to see animals in their natural habitats. In Africa, you might even step outside your vehicle to explore the wild. Activities could include tracking gorillas in Zaire, hiking with tribal guides in Uganda, or canoeing on the Zambezi River. Most safaris involve camping, but some offer hotel accommodations.

**Ethnic Encounters**

A highlight of our adventures is meeting ethnic or tribal groups, such as the Tuareg of the Sahara, the Maya of Mexico, or the Huli of Papua New Guinea. Many of these cultures are under threat, and we aim to promote understanding and respect while minimizing cultural and environmental impact.

**Easy/Moderate Hiking**

Many trips include easy walking through beautiful countryside, often staying in rented accommodations or hotels. Some involve village-to-village hiking, where you might stay overnight in local homes or simple huts. Destinations include Spain, Greece, Morocco, and many more. On longer hikes, your main luggage is transported separately, so you only carry a daypack.

**Major Treks**

We offer a few challenging treks for experienced hikers, sometimes at high altitudes. You may stay with local people or camp in stunning mountain ranges like the Himalayas or the Andes. Support vehicles and porters are usually provided, so you won’t need to carry heavy gear.

**Wilderness Experience**

Exploring remote wilderness areas is an exciting adventure. These places, like the Amazon Rainforest or the Sahara Desert, offer unique experiences for adventurous travelers.

**Sailtreks/Seatreks**

These relaxing holidays involve traveling by local boats. We sail through Upper Egypt on traditional feluccas, use wooden yachts in Turkey, and explore the Galapagos Islands on a small motor yacht.

**Raft and River Journeys**

Our river trips can last from a few hours to several days, ranging from easy inflatable rafts to thrilling whitewater rafting. No prior experience is needed, and safety skills are taught quickly. Our river journeys in India, Africa, and the Amazon provide a unique view of beautiful landscapes and wildlife.

Richard Nerurkar, a long-distance runner and one of Britain's best in the 10,000 meters, visits a high-altitude training camp in Kenya. Located ten miles south of the equator, a sunny mountain path leads from a quiet road in Nairobi to Mount Kenya, the highest peak in the country. This beautiful but remote place, called Nanyuk, has been my base for winter training in Kenya's Central Highlands for the past three years. However, I had never trained with Kenyan runners until my fourth winter trip to Kenya. This time, I decided to change that tradition. I participated in my first race in Kenya's thin air and stayed at the national team training camp, where the best runners prepare for the World Cross-Country Team Championships. I received an invitation from the national team coach after finishing fifth in the World Championship 10,000 meters race, behind three Kenyans and a Moroccan. It was an opportunity I could not miss.

Training at high altitude increases the number of red blood cells, which helps carry more oxygen. This has been proven by the success of many Kenyan runners. My first race in Africa, which took place before my time at the training camp, was also significant because it was the first international cross-country race held on the continent. It was a humbling experience, as 41 runners finished ahead of me, and all but three were Kenyan. I felt I had run well, but I believe Kenyan success is not only due to the altitude. Kenyan runners are known for their simple approach to the sport. Their running style looks effortless, their diet is straightforward, and they seem to enjoy competing.

One important aspect of Kenyan success is their training. My time at the national team camp revealed their methods. The camp is located at St Mark's College, 6,200 feet up the southern slope of Mount Kenya, surrounded by beautiful fields and tropical plants. The facilities are basic, with athletes living in shared dormitories with regular students. Their daily routine includes three workouts: a relaxed morning run, interval training in the late morning, and a steady run in the afternoon. Each day starts at six in the morning, and we gather for a briefing from the coaches. They remind us to take it easy in the morning because a tough workout awaits. We run about 40 kilometers each day, except on Sundays when we only run 20 kilometers, which is a welcome break.

Life at the camp is simple. A splash of water on the face and brushing teeth is enough for morning preparations. Breakfast consists of tea, bread, and boiled eggs in a small dining area. Lunch and dinner are similar, featuring ugali (a maize dish), stew, cabbage or spinach, and tea. After running, we would drive to one of the streams from Mount Kenya's glaciers to bathe. By the end of my stay, I gained a deeper appreciation for Kenyan success. It cannot be explained by genetics, upbringing, or altitude alone. I began to think that the simplicity of life in the mountains, the hard training, and the passion for success might be the true reasons behind Kenya's dominance in long-distance running.

**The Challenges of Mass Marketing**

Almost everyone knows that advertising is struggling. This issue is not just due to the recession; advertising began to decline in early 1989, before the recession really affected the economy. The problems with advertising are deeper and are happening all over the world. The sad truth is that advertising has not adapted to the fast changes in the economy. Advertisers often think about large markets and broad media, but as brands and media options have increased, target audiences have become more diverse. Even campaigns for well-known brands should focus on smaller audiences, but they usually do not. This is a major reason why advertising is not working well.

Consider your own shopping habits. When you go to a supermarket, you might buy 30, 40, or even 50 items. Most of these items are not from advertised brands, and you may buy several of the same brand. In total, you probably only buy a few advertised brands from the thousands available in the store. Over a year, you are unlikely to purchase more than a few hundred different brands. For durable goods, you might buy about a dozen brands a year. If you buy a new car, it is likely provided by your employer, and if not, you may only buy one every three years. You also do not buy many clothes, and most of them are not from advertised brands. Even when you consider all the other products and services, it is likely that you do not buy more than 400 different brands in a year. 

In contrast, there are about 32,500 branded goods and services that are advertised. If we ignore the 23,000 brands that spend less than £50,000 a year on advertising, we can focus on the 9,500 brands that are individually listed and analyzed. The average consumer buys only 400 of these 9,500 brands, and not all of these purchases are influenced by advertising. This means that only about 4 percent of the advertised brands are actually bought. 

You might think you are different and not influenced by advertising, but most people feel the same way. The reality is that most people do not buy the brands they see advertised. There is always waste in advertising because not every person who sees an ad will buy the product. It is unrealistic to think that every reader or viewer will rush out to buy all the advertised brands. People only remember a small number of ads and ignore the rest, so some waste is unavoidable. However, this does not mean that advertising is not effective. Many ads have shown that it can work. 

Advertising needs to reach a large audience to connect with the smaller group that will respond, as advertisers cannot predict who will be interested. Media advertising is a cost-effective way to communicate with many people, even if it seems expensive. With better targeting, advertisers can reduce waste by reaching more people who are likely to respond, but they can never know exactly who will. Even the best direct mail campaigns do not achieve a 100 percent response rate. This is a key difference between media advertising and personal selling. A salesperson might succeed with every potential client they meet, but this is not possible with media advertising. If advertisers knew exactly who would respond, they would communicate with them directly.

Any advertiser who can attract one million new customers, which is about 2 percent of the adult population, is considered successful. For popular products like soap powder, the top brands would be thrilled to gain a million extra customers. Therefore, any advertising campaign that can reach more than 2 percent of the population is very successful, and this is just a small part of the overall market. While mass media can be an effective way to reach these customers, advertising needs to be more focused than ever to succeed again.

**Solar Survivor: Charles Clover Explores Britain's Most Eco-Friendly Home**

Charles Clover visits a unique home in Southwell, Nottinghamshire, known for its environmental friendliness. Southwell is home to the lesser-known Southwell Minster, an ancient cathedral admired for its carvings of 'green' men made by medieval craftsmen in the thirteenth century. The second surprise is the 'autonomous house,' created by Robert and Brenda Vale, which is considered the greenest home in Britain.

The Vales have designed their home to be self-sufficient. They collect rainwater for drinking and washing, recycle sewage into compost for their garden, and use waste heat from their appliances and their own bodies to warm the house. Their three teenage children and two cats, Edison and Faraday, also contribute to the warmth. The house, which looks traditional with its clay tile roof, is located 300 yards from the Minster and blends in with the town's historic buildings. It was approved by planners even though it is in a conservation area.

When you ring the solar-powered doorbell, you will notice complete silence. The house is extremely well-insulated, with special windows that keep out noise. Inside, after removing your shoes as Robert requests, you will find a peaceful atmosphere. On a sunny summer day, the windows are closed, and the conservatory warms the air before it circulates throughout the house. Robert opens clever ventilation systems to create airflow, as the house is designed to be airtight. Even the cats have their own small air-locked door.

The Vales, who teach architecture at Nottingham University, have been committed to environmental issues since the 1970s when they wrote a book called *The Autonomous House*. They aimed to create a building that produced no carbon dioxide and eventually decided to eliminate the need for mains water. They installed composting toilets, rainwater tanks, and copper gutters to keep drinking water clean, filtering it before use. Water from washing goes into the garden, and they do not use a dishwasher to avoid harsh detergents.

Robert explains that they want to show that it is possible to design a house that is much less harmful to the environment while still being comfortable and modern. The only medieval feature is the design of the hall, which includes the fireplace and staircase, extending to the top of the house. The Vales do not pay for water, and last winter, their electricity usage was only nine units a day, costing about 70p—much less than typical four-bedroom homes.

Soon, they will install solar panels worth £20,000 in the garden, which will allow the house to generate more electricity than it uses. They will still rely on mains electricity for cooking and appliances but expect to have enough surplus energy to eventually charge an electric car. The only source of heat is a small wood-burning stove, which they rarely use except during the coldest days.

When asked if the house stays warm in winter, Robert shared that during a visit in February, it was too warm to light the stove. The temperature on the first floor was 18°C, which is lower than usual for living spaces, but he found it comfortable due to the lack of drafts and consistent temperatures throughout the house. He notes that people in the past were comfortable at lower temperatures because of their clothing. He suggests that those living in older homes might consider returning to simpler living, though this idea may not be popular.

The success of the house lies in its low-tech design, which minimizes potential problems. Most materials were sourced from local suppliers and installed by local craftsmen, making it affordable to build—comparable in cost to low-income rental housing. Unsurprisingly, commercial builders are resistant to this innovative approach.

Text: 'The Camera Never Lies

Arthur Conan Doyle, the writer of the Sherlock Holmes stories, considered himself a rational and scientific person. However, in 1920, he saw photographs of fairies taken in a garden and believed they were real evidence of these tiny creatures. He published these photos with an article, accepting fairies as supernatural beings. It was not until 1939 that the two women who took the photos confessed they were fake. They had simply cut out pictures of fairies from a book and placed them among flowers. The images are undeniably beautiful, but the simplicity of the trick challenges a key idea about photography: that the camera cannot lie. In fact, it can, and always has been able to. Nowadays, we often use computer software to edit our digital images, and it is a misconception that photography ever had a time when it was completely honest. From the very beginning, when cameras started capturing reality, that reality was being changed.'

**Blacksmiths**

Throughout history, iron has captured human imagination, and blacksmiths, who work with it, have often been seen as more than just skilled workers. Before the Industrial Revolution, blacksmiths held a respected position, similar to doctors and astrologers, because they were the only ones who made weapons, armor, and farming tools. They were also celebrated as artists. In the 18th century, blacksmiths created beautiful ironwork for St Paul's Cathedral, and the elegant metal designs in French and Belgian Art Nouveau architecture were crafted by talented blacksmiths.

However, by the late 1960s, the number of blacksmiths in Britain had greatly decreased. Heavy industry no longer needed their skills, and modern architects rarely used the beautiful wrought iron handrails that blacksmiths made. In the last ten years, there has been a revival of interest in decorative architecture and a more open-minded approach to interior design. Still, much of the work produced seems repetitive, with manufacturers labeling their gates and balconies as "classical" or "Victorian-style." You can hardly enter a trendy design store without seeing rusty candlesticks with unnecessary decorations.

Fortunately, there are new opportunities for blacksmiths, and a series of events in the coming weeks aims to promote their craft. The first event, an exhibition of forged ironwork by members of the British Artist Blacksmiths Association (BABA), opened last week at the Fire & Iron gallery in Leatherhead, Surrey. Alan Dawson, the secretary of BABA, believes we might be entering a new Iron Age, as both the public and blacksmiths are becoming more aware of the craft. Modern power tools have made it easier for blacksmiths to shape metal without the hard labor of working over a hot anvil. Dawson explains, "These artists now have a material that allows them to express themselves."

About 250 pieces have been created for the exhibition, including bookends and a spiral staircase. Prices start at £90 and can go up to several thousand pounds. Most of the money will go to the individual artists, but a portion of each sale will be kept by the Association to promote quality ironwork. Dawson's contributions include an eight-foot gate and a lamp with a hand-blown glass shade. He describes his style as allowing steel to bend and flow into shape when it is hot, comparing it to drawing with metal in space.

Many artists are fascinated by iron. Unlike most metals, which are soft when cold, iron and steel are tougher and more challenging to work with. Susan May, a trained jeweler, says, "It's quite magical because it's incredibly soft when hot, but as soon as it cools, it becomes rigid and unmovable again." Ann Catrin Evans creates mild steel door knockers and handles inspired by the dark castles often seen in horror films. One of her designs looks like a ball and chain, and another resembles a Celtic cross. She loves the cold, hard feel of steel and how it seems to last forever.

No other metal has provided as much visual pleasure or a greater sense of security. It is likely that iron will continue to be used decoratively for the next thousand years, as long as we can avoid seeing any more rusty candlesticks!

**The Day I Gave Up Smoking**

I thought everyone would be happy when I quit smoking, but one of my colleagues was very angry. She shouted, "What do you mean? If it was that easy, why didn't you stop years ago?" I found it hard to explain how I went from being a heavy smoker to not smoking at all in just a few hours. It was a bit annoying, even for me. 

The stop-smoking session I attended was a mix of group therapy and hypnotherapy, and it happened two months and three weeks ago. I hadn’t planned to quit, and I didn’t really want to. I felt pressured by anti-smoking groups, which I still resent. I also had low blood pressure and a healthy family, and I didn’t feel sick or cough often. In fact, I seemed to recover from colds faster than my friends who lived healthier lives.

On that ordinary Thursday afternoon, I went to a session in Birmingham called The Easy Way to Stop Smoking to write an article about others trying to quit. I clearly stated, "I won’t be trying to stop; I’m here to write, not to quit, so it wouldn’t be fair to expect your method to work on me." I was very reasonable because I genuinely enjoyed smoking; it brought me real pleasure. 

The counsellor seemed to understand me. We were encouraged to smoke as much as we wanted, and the room was so full of smoke that we had to open the windows. I noticed that when I was told to smoke, I didn’t want to, and neither did the others. I think the messages about quitting started to make sense to me. Just as smoking had become a challenge against opposition, the idea of stopping began to feel appealing. The thought of not being a smoker started to make me feel strong. It was a personal feeling that didn’t involve anyone else. Could I also achieve other things?

In many ways, quitting was easy. The physical cravings for nicotine, which felt like hunger, faded after a minute or two and lasted only four or five days. I thought my work would be the hardest part without cigarettes, but it turned out to be fine. I had believed I wouldn’t be able to meet deadlines without nicotine and that I would fail to write a story. Surprisingly, the hardest part was just relaxing at home on weekend mornings, and it still is. 

I am starting to realize that smoking helped me deal with boredom; having a cigarette was an activity in itself. Yes, I do miss smoking, but not too much. Every new experience as a non-smoker is something I have to get used to—like eating out, waiting for a flight, checking into a hotel, or during a theatre break. These are all moments when I would have previously smoked.

**Dorothy Who?**

Dorothy Hodgkin is the only British woman scientist to win a Nobel Prize, yet many people in Britain do not know her name. For the past four years, I have been testing my friends to see if they know about her. When I tell them I am writing her biography, I watch their reactions. If they seem excited and say things like, "Surely there’s already a biography!" they pass the test.

Why should people in Britain know about Dorothy Hodgkin? She is the only British woman scientist to have won a Nobel Prize, which should make her famous. If someone in literature had the same achievement, they would be well-known. Hodgkin, who passed away in 1994, was an extraordinary person, as complex as the crystals she studied. Her life reflects significant changes in the 20th century, including the progress of women's education and the globalization of science.

When I started my research, I wanted to read scientific biographies. A friend of Hodgkin suggested I look for a biography of Linus Pauling, who was a close friend of hers and shared her commitment to peace. I went to the main bookstore in my university town, but I found no biographies of Pauling. I was surprised that he was not considered interesting enough for British readers, even though he was a highly influential chemist and a Nobel Prize winner in both chemistry and peace.

Even scientists sometimes think that biographies about scientists are not interesting. Peter Medawar, a Nobel laureate, once said that the lives of scientists are often dull. If scientists believe this, it is not surprising that publishers and booksellers do too. This idea that scientists are different from other people is part of the "two cultures" mentality, which suggests a divide between the arts and sciences. Only a few famous scientists make it into the biography sections of bookstores.

It is not true that scientists lead less interesting lives than artists, writers, or politicians. Some scientists are very careful about their public image. For example, a leading geneticist told me he would only be interviewed if he was not quoted or photographed, as he did not want to seem like he was promoting himself. This reluctance to share personal stories can create a false impression of science and may discourage young people from pursuing scientific careers.

Fortunately, things are changing. Nowadays, scientists often appear in public in ways other than just scientific interviews. For example, Professor Richard Dawkins presents awards on a TV quiz show, and geneticist Steve Jones appears in car commercials. These activities help make scientists more relatable to the public.

The publishing world is also changing. Scientific biographies used to be very serious and dull, often ignoring the personal lives of scientists. However, this has changed with books like Richard Feynman's "Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman?", which is both funny and touching. Recently, even famous scientists like Isaac Newton, Charles Darwin, Albert Einstein, and Marie Curie have been portrayed with their flaws, making them more human.

Dorothy Hodgkin was dedicated to her scientific work. She made significant discoveries, including the structures of penicillin and vitamin B12, which earned her the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1964, and insulin in 1969. She achieved these successes by pushing scientific techniques to new levels. However, she also raised three children and had a husband who was often away due to his job as a historian. While her personal life may not seem directly related to her work, it shows how she balanced different aspects of her life.

There is much in Hodgkin's life that is interesting to everyone, but her scientific achievements are also important. Scientific inquiry was her passion, which is essential for any successful scientist. The challenge for biographers is to communicate this passion effectively. Many readers may not have the scientific background to understand complex ideas without detailed explanations. However, understanding science is not harder than reading Shakespeare or learning a new language; it just requires effort.

It is unfortunate that educated people who would feel embarrassed for not knowing a famous literary figure often remain unaware of the significant contributions of scientists like Dorothy Hodgkin.

**Margaret and Her Water-Finding Skills**

Margaret Wilkins is known for her unique ability to find water. She uses a forked hazel stick to detect underground water sources. Farmers whose wells have dried up often seek her help. Along with her husband, she runs a well-drilling business that uses modern equipment like drilling rigs and air-compressed hammers. However, when it comes to finding water, she relies solely on her hazel stick. The couple has a success rate of over 90%.

This skill, known as dowsing, allows people to locate water, minerals, and lost items underground. There are various theories about how dowsing works, ranging from physical explanations like magnetism to spiritual beliefs. One popular theory suggests that everything on Earth vibrates, with water vibrating more than other materials. Some dowsers claim they can sense these vibrations, while others say they can smell water, as smell is a very strong sense.

In recent years of drought, Margaret has been very busy, sometimes having a waiting list of almost six weeks. Most of her clients are farmers with dry wells. She explains, "We usually see customers only once because wells last a long time." Other clients include owners of remote cottages or barns, where installing long water pipes is too expensive, and developers of golf courses who need water for their facilities.

Margaret typically looks for water at depths of 50 to 70 meters. She emphasizes the importance of avoiding areas where waste could contaminate the water supply. The water she finds is usually in cracks of solid rock, and as long as it is brought up directly, it should be clean. However, she notes that Cornwall has many minerals, so they must be cautious about iron in the water. 

Electricity is also necessary to operate the pump, but running power lines across long distances can be costly. Therefore, it is best if the well is close to existing power sources. Once these factors are considered, Margaret begins her search for water.

For large areas like golf courses, she starts with a map and a pendulum. She holds the pendulum still and moves it over the map. It will swing when she is above a water source. After identifying potential areas on the map, she walks the fields with her hazel stick, which is forked and equal in size on both sides. 

"When I am above water, I feel a strange sensation and sway slightly. Once that feeling goes away, I use the stick to find the exact drilling spot," she explains. By holding the two forks of the stick and applying slight tension, she can tell if water is directly below. "If the straight part of the stick rises, it means water is there. It’s crucial to drill exactly where the stick indicates. If we drill even a little off, we might miss the water completely."

Margaret and her husband often dowse the same area. Usually, they agree on where to drill, but if they disagree, they will keep searching until they find a consensus.

Margaret's skills are not just a local tradition; they have intrigued anthropologists and writers for a long time. She describes her ability as an "intuitive perception of the environment," which is the best way to explain how she finds water so accurately. If she did not have this special skill, it would be difficult for her family to sustain their well-drilling business year after year.

**We Changed Lives for a Day!**

Have you ever thought about living someone else's life for a day? It might be exciting to try something completely different. We arranged this for four people - here’s what happened.

**Amanda's Story**

Amanda, 23, is a young mother with two daughters. She swapped lives with her friend Cindy, 30, who works as a waitress in a fancy London restaurant. 

Amanda had never been in a place like that before. It was dark, loud, and crowded, which was very different from her hometown. She felt nervous and overwhelmed. Being a mother is busy, but waitressing was a whole new challenge! She had only fifteen minutes to learn how to carry a tray of drinks. The other waitresses made it look easy, but when Amanda tried, the drinks slipped off the tray and spilled everywhere. She felt embarrassed, but the other waitresses laughed and reassured her that everyone makes mistakes at first.

By 11:30 am, a line of customers was waiting outside, and Amanda felt anxious about remembering their orders. Luckily, the ordering system was automated, which made things easier. After a few hours, her feet hurt, and she struggled to hear customers over the loud music. She often had to ask them to repeat themselves, which was embarrassing. By the end of her shift at 5 pm, she was exhausted and just wanted to soak her feet in hot water. One waitress told her it had been a "quiet" day, which surprised Amanda. She realized waitressing was much harder than she thought. She used to think it was an easy job, but it actually requires a lot of energy and a friendly attitude, especially during busy times. Amanda felt relieved to return to her children, as being a mom seemed much easier after her day as a waitress.

**Cindy's Story**

Cindy, who is 30, was nervous about being a mother for a day, but she was also excited. She had heard that Amanda's daughters could be mischievous, but she thought she could manage. 

After Amanda left for the restaurant, Cindy had to get the two girls dressed and fed. After dropping Sophie at school and Katie at nursery, she thought she would have three hours of peace. But she was wrong! A note from Amanda reminded her that she still had to make the beds, clean the house, and do the laundry. 

At 1 pm, Cindy picked up Katie, went shopping, and then took her home for lunch. The real chaos began when she brought Sophie home from school. The girls turned the couch into a trampoline and played a loud game. Cindy tried to stay calm, thinking they would tire out soon, but they had more energy than she expected! After much effort, she finally got them to bed by 8 pm, but then the fun continued. The girls kept asking for glasses of water, which was just a trick to get them downstairs to watch TV. Cindy spent the whole evening negotiating with them, and she realized how tiring it is to take care of two small children. There was no time for herself, and the responsibility felt overwhelming. Despite the challenges, she enjoyed the day.

**Rosemary's Story**

Rosemary, 42, runs a dairy farm. She swapped lives with Hilary, 30, a primary school teacher. 

On the farm, Rosemary usually wakes up at 5:30 am, so sleeping in until 7 am felt like a treat! She was unsure how to dress for school and hoped she wouldn’t stand out. At assembly, she faced about 400 students and hoped to blend in. 

In math class, the children worked in small groups, which was different from her own school experience. She helped with a nature project, identifying and feeding snails. By lunchtime, she was tired and looking forward to a break, but teachers only have about five minutes to eat. There was so much to do before the next classes. She attended a staff meeting and helped with athletics trials. After lunch, there was a silent reading lesson, which she enjoyed, followed by a French lesson where the children practiced on her. Finally, they had Physical Education, and by then, she was exhausted, while the children seemed full of energy. Speaking in front of the class was the hardest part for her. Although teachers have more holidays, Rosemary decided she preferred farming.

**Hilary's Story**

Hilary arrived at White House Farm at 8:30 am, only to find that Rosemary had been working for three hours already! Rosemary's farm is large, with many cows and sheep. She also makes ice cream, yogurt, and cream to sell.

Hilary spent most of the morning in the ice cream shop, filling containers with milk and making ice cream. It was hard not to taste the treats! At lunchtime, she checked on the sheep and helped a ewe that had fallen over. If sheep are not checked daily, they can die, which is especially tough in winter. After feeding the calves, Hilary started milking, which took two and a half hours. Rosemary does this twice a day, every day of the year! 

Hilary found the day lonely and missed being around children, as animals don’t talk back. The hardest part of farming is that there is no time off; the cows need to be milked twice a day, making it hard to plan vacations. Rosemary only gets about three days off this year. Farming may seem romantic, but the reality is very different, with an unpredictable income and dependence on the weather.

A trumpet isn't just for Christmas... It is surprising how many musicians, even famous ones, come from families without music. Hakan Hardenberger, the only son of non-musical parents in a rural area of southern Sweden, has become a unique trumpet player at the age of 30. His recordings introduce new music, including concertos by lesser-known composers from the baroque and classical periods, as well as new pieces. When you meet him, he looks youthful and has a bright personality, much like the sound of the trumpet. Recently, he performed the Hummel Trumpet Concerto in one of London's top concert halls, and a television feature was made about his work, filmed in both London and Sweden.

Hardenberger was born near Malmo and began his musical journey with a Christmas gift when he was eight years old. His father, who did not play music but enjoyed Louis Armstrong, decided to buy him a real trumpet instead of a toy. The gift was a success, and the boy played constantly. His mother arranged for him to take lessons from the second trumpet player in the Malmo Symphony Orchestra, Bo Nilsson, who recognized his natural talent. Hardenberger is grateful to have had such a dedicated teacher from the beginning, someone who was passionate about the trumpet and always looking for ways to improve.

Hardenberger explains that the trumpet is a simple instrument, and it is impossible to create a perfect one. There will always be some flaws, and no two mouthpieces are exactly alike. He believes it is important to understand these imperfections and learn to work with them. From the start, he had a unique sound that was recognizable, which he considers his first achievement. Unlike John Wallace, a prominent British trumpet player who came from a brass band background, Hardenberger has always seen himself as a solo artist. He admired the French trumpeter Maurice Andre and bought all his records. His parents supported his dream of becoming a professional trumpet player.

At 15, it was time to decide where he would study. Although Bo Nilsson suggested America, it was considered too far and dangerous, so at 16, he went to Paris to study with Pierre Thibaud. Thibaud discouraged him from joining an orchestra, saying that playing in one was like "digging in the garden." Hardenberger knew he played better than many of his peers, but it was only after entering a competition at 17 that he realized he had a special ability to connect with the audience. Thibaud had encouraged him to enter the competition for experience. Hardenberger prepared only for the first round but advanced to the second. He was familiar with most pieces in that round, but in the final, he faced a concerto that intimidated him. He did not win first prize, but he enjoyed the performance and realized that even if he felt he played poorly, people were still listening.

Hardenberger's honest view of his talent might seem arrogant, but that is not the case. He thoughtfully avoids analyzing what makes his communication with the audience special, believing that trying to explain it could ruin it. He feels that the true power of music lies in its ability to move people.

**New In Paperback**

A. The story of Tristan Smith, a citizen in the made-up republic of Efica, is a remarkable tale about human power, history, and humor. The author skillfully creates a world with its own history, traditions, and customs. The book is also known for its humor and the author's unique perspective, combined with deep psychological insights, making it a challenging but rewarding read.

B. Harriet is a composed, middle-class woman with an architect husband and her own business. Normally, she would not have met Sheila, a traditional working-class woman who cares for her elderly father and has raised her grandson, Leo, since he was three. Their lives change dramatically when Leo violently attacks Harriet's son, Joe, in the street. After the court case, both boys refuse to discuss what happened. Leo, who had always been a good student and never fought before, cannot explain his actions, while Joe physically recovers but becomes withdrawn. Harriet is deeply affected by her son's situation, and caring for him consumes her life. Sheila feels so guilty that she asks to meet Harriet, leading to an unexpected friendship. The author excels at showing how people respond to major changes in their lives and captures the mother's feeling that she can never do enough for her son.

C. This book, shortlisted for the Booker Prize, tells the story of one of the most isolated Scottish Orkney islands and its people over a long, quiet history. The narrative is set against important moments in Scottish history, vividly imagined through the daydreams of the young character, Throfinn Ragnarson. He suddenly disappears from the story but returns after World War II, having learned to appreciate the simple lives of his ancestors.

D. After his recent success, the author has written a sequel filled with the same gentle irony and sharp observations of family life that made the first book popular. Fifteen years after her daughter's death, Aurora Greenway approaches her seventies with her lively friend, Rosie Sunlap. Aurora's outlook on life remains a mix of vanity, charm, and reluctant kindness, while Rosie supports her in her enjoyable manipulation of friends and suitors. By the end of the book, Aurora must face the passage of time and the arrival of a new generation. The author skillfully reveals the sadness that lies beneath the ordinary aspects of life, focusing more on the shadows than the bright moments.

E. Six very different people are brought together by millionaire Logan Urquhart to sail around the South Pacific islands on his yacht, the Ardent Spirit. The author uses beautiful descriptive language to explore the personal journeys of self-discovery that each sailor experiences, returning home with renewed spirits after their time adrift on "the desert cities of waves." The author employs striking images to express themes of memory and awareness, which are both isolating and enlightening.

**Take Five Careers**

Rebecca Cripps meets five women who share their different jobs, discussing the positives, negatives, and what a typical day looks like for them.

**A. THE BRAIN SURGEON**  
**Name:** Anne  
**Age:** 34  

**ANNE'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 6:30 am, go to the gym at 7 am, and arrive at work by 8 am. I start surgeries at 8:30 am. I perform surgeries all day on Mondays and Wednesdays, and sometimes on Friday afternoons. Most brain surgeries last about three hours, but some can take all day. Occasionally, I work for ten hours straight without eating or taking a break. Deciding when and how to operate can be stressful. While I don’t feel stressed during surgery, I sometimes worry about the next day’s tasks. Brain surgery is often a last option for patients, but when it succeeds, it is incredibly rewarding, making up for the times it doesn’t. From 10 am to 1 pm, I run an out-patients' clinic where I explain the surgeries to patients. I enjoy this and find it easy to talk to them. If they get upset, I try to comfort them, but time constraints can make this hard. I usually leave work between 6 pm and 8 pm. Some nights and weekends, I am on call and carry my bleeper. During holidays, I often worry about my patients for the first few days, and I sometimes dream about operating. I struggle to relax."

**B. THE SENIOR DESIGNER**  
**Name:** Marita  
**Age:** 31  

**MARITA'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 7:45 am, leave home by 8:20 am, and take the train to work, arriving by 9:15 am. On Mondays at 10:30 am, we have a meeting to discuss our projects and any issues. I work in a team of three senior designers, a partner who oversees everything, and a junior designer. My work is mostly production, with only 10 to 15 percent being actual design. I receive a brief from the client, and if they have clear ideas, I spend three to four weeks designing and developing the project. After that, I present my ideas to the client. Once they approve, we create estimates and budgets, and I start hiring photographers and illustrators. I also coordinate with printers to ensure everything is done on time. Managing multiple projects can be very stressful, especially with tight deadlines. Lunch is at 1 pm for an hour, and we often go to a pub. If the client is happy with my designs, it feels great, but it’s disappointing when a project I worked hard on gets rejected. I usually get home by 7:30 pm, but it can be as late as 8:30 pm or later. I find it hard to relax after a busy day."

**C. THE CHAUFFEUR**  
**Name:** Linda  
**Age:** 42  

**LINDA'S DAY**  
"I usually wake up around 7 am, but on two or three mornings a week, I have to get up between 4:30 am and 5 am for long-haul flights from Heathrow or Gatwick. At 10:30 or 11 am, I might go for a bike ride or swim. Since chauffeuring is a sedentary job, I need to be careful about my diet and exercise. I usually have a big breakfast and snack throughout the day. Clients often ask for recommendations for restaurants or shops, so I need to know the area well. Many jobs are pre-booked, allowing me to plan my routes. While some passengers can be rude, most are polite, and I have good relationships with my regular clients. I sometimes hear conversations in the car and have to focus on driving. I work seven days a week, up to fifteen hours a day, so I must be careful not to get too tired. I try to go to bed by 11 pm."

**D. THE LANDSCAPE GARDENER**  
**Name:** Tracy  
**Age:** 27  

**TRACY'S DAY**  
"I wake up around 7 am, leave home at 7:30 am, and start my first job. My assistant and I mainly maintain gardens we designed. We do some commercial work, but most is in private gardens, spending about an hour and a half at each location. Around 11 am, we take a break for a big breakfast at a local café. I often wish time would slow down. In summer, I may work until 10 pm; in winter, until 4:30 pm. I run the business from home, so when I return, I check messages and return calls. If someone wants a new garden design, I usually schedule a consultation in the evening. We focus on using old materials to create gardens that look historic. Sometimes clients have specific ideas that aren’t great, but it’s very satisfying to see a garden we designed bloom. I find it hard to relax in the evenings because I can always hear the business phone. I sleep well because my job is physically demanding, leaving me exhausted at the end of the day. I may not be very strong, but I am fit. It’s a tough job, but it allows for creativity."

**E. THE CIVIL ENGINEER**  
**Name:** Zena  
**Age:** 27  

**ZENA'S DAY**  
"I arrive at the construction site by 8:30 am. As the assistant resident engineer, I oversee the building of bridges and a retaining wall. I check that contractors are following the schedule and safety guidelines while minimizing environmental impact. I help coordinate the site professionals and solve any problems. The contractors start work at 6 am, so my first task is to find out what happened since I left the night before. The rest of my day depends on their updates. I usually have paperwork to review or design questions to answer. Lunch is typically from 2 pm to 2:30 pm, but I often eat on the go. Since we monitor the contractors' work, it can lead to conflicts, so we need to maintain a good relationship. I see the duty resident engineer once a day, but I act quickly if something urgent arises. I usually leave the site around 6 pm and am on call all the time."

**Careers: Six People Discuss Their Typical Workday**

**A. Credit Card Executive**  
I wake up at 6 am and reach the office by 7:30 am. My job involves managing customer development programs for our credit card users. I am responsible for launching and overseeing the Membership Rewards scheme in major European markets. I maintain contact with current card users, attract new ones, and build partnerships with other companies. I spend the first 45 minutes organizing my day and then respond to emails. I handle all advertising for the membership program across Europe, which requires meetings with marketing staff and advertising agencies to create strategies and plan future projects. I have meetings throughout the day, but I keep my door open for anyone who has questions. I travel to different European markets once or twice a week to address any issues. When I am in London, I usually leave work between 6:30 pm and 7:00 pm.

**B. Record Company Executive**  
I arrive at work by 10:00 am and start by reviewing the mail, which includes ten to twenty demo tapes daily, letters from producers, concert information, and invoices from musicians and studios. The phone starts ringing around 10:30 am with calls from producers and publishers, and I have meetings throughout the day to discuss campaigns or projects for artists. I listen to demo tapes carefully, knowing that they represent people's hard work, and I aim to provide constructive feedback. Once I sign a band, we begin working on their first album, selecting songs, producers, and additional musicians. I also communicate my vision for the album to the marketing team. I manage budgets and expenses as well. I typically leave work by 7:00 pm, and most evenings I attend concerts, sometimes seeing up to five new bands in one night. After a concert, I might visit an artist in the studio. My social life often revolves around my work, and I usually get home around 1:00 am, where I listen to music to relax.

**C. Sales Director**  
I wake up at 8:00 am and drive to work, arriving by 9:30 am. I start by opening the mail and checking the schedule for client meetings. I enjoy showing customers around the showroom and feel satisfied when I sell a piece of furniture, knowing it will be appreciated. We sell antiques priced between £1,000 and £6,000, sourcing them from auctions, private clients, and overseas. Many items need restoration, so I work closely with our full-time restorer and other specialists. I read the Antiques Trade Gazette while enjoying coffee to stay updated on the industry, and I often visit the Victoria and Albert Museum to compare furniture. I handle the accounts once a month and complete tax returns every three months. I usually leave work at 5:30 pm and it takes me about an hour to unwind.

**D. Air Traffic Controller**  
I work on a set shift schedule. On early shifts, I leave home at 6:00 am and start my shift at 7:00 am, taking over from the night shift. I manage one of four control positions in the tower. We have a rotating schedule, working for about an hour and a half at one station, then taking a half-hour break before switching to another station. The air traffic controllers, a supervisor, and the watch manager work closely together to manage aircraft movements. In winter, we handle around 1,000 movements daily, and even more in summer. Night shifts are quieter, allowing me to read about new air traffic regulations. This job requires full attention, so I don’t hesitate to take sick leave if I’m not feeling well. The work can be stressful, and it takes time to relax after a shift. I hope to become a watch manager and eventually the general manager of the airport.

**E. Shop Manager**  
If I have an early shift, I leave home by 8:00 am. My first task is to set up the electronic point-of-sale system. I ensure someone is at the register and coordinate lunch and break times for staff. In the morning, I assist customers in finding and ordering books. I enjoy helping customers, although it can be challenging when they come in with reviews and expect me to gather many books quickly. From 2:00 pm to 4:00 pm on weekdays, publishers' representatives visit, and I discuss upcoming titles with them. I need to estimate how many copies of a new title we might sell. When we want to feature a new book, I ensure it arrives on time. My early shift ends at 5:45 pm. On two days a week, I work a late shift, during which I close the computer system, lock up, and go home.

**F. Financial Analyst**  
I listen to the news at 7:00 am, then get up and take a taxi to work, arriving by 8:45 am. My first task is to contact freelance reporters to learn about events in my area of responsibility. I assess financial risks for multinational companies operating abroad, aiming to warn clients about potential issues in those countries. I provide three services: an online executive preview, a security forecast, and a travel information security guide. From 9:15 am to 9:30 am, I meet with editors to discuss the stories I will follow. My first executive preview must be online by 10:00 am, and my second deadline is at 11:00 am, so I need to work quickly. I write the stories, send them to my editor for approval, and make any necessary changes before they are published. I travel to Africa about three times a year to report on specific events and stay updated. I usually leave work around 6:00 pm, and it can be hard to relax afterward; I often find myself awake until 1:00 am.

**Career Power: Take Control at Work**

A. **What Makes a Good Leader?**  
A good leader inspires others and drives change. Leadership is not about physical traits like height or just intelligence. According to Pat Dixon, author of *Making the Difference: Women and Men in the Workplace*, leadership is about making things happen with the help of enthusiastic people. A good leader should express enthusiasm clearly and confidently. Dixon emphasizes the importance of saying "I believe" instead of "I think."

B. John van Maurik, who directs a Leadership in Management course, believes that most people have more leadership potential than they realize. Becoming a leader involves recognizing and developing your hidden talents. In a way, we are all born leaders; we just need the right environment to grow. While it’s easy to see leadership in famous figures like Emmeline Pankhurst or Mahatma Gandhi, it can be harder to see it in our own workplaces. However, leadership is now seen as essential for effective management.

C. Think about the best and worst boss you’ve had. They might have been equally good at setting goals and meeting deadlines. But how did they achieve these goals? The best leader motivated you and provided support, while the worst made you feel unimportant and withheld information, blaming you when things went wrong. The first was a great leader; the second was a poor manager.

D. Leaders and managers are different. Managers prefer to work within set limits, while leaders create new possibilities. Micheal Shea, author of *Leadership Rules*, states that a good manager can keep a struggling company running, but a good leader can revitalize a discouraged organization, whether it’s a business, a sports team, or a country.

E. Whether you are the boss or a middle manager, improving your leadership skills can be beneficial. Here are some lessons to consider:  
- Leadership works best when you choose to lead. Discover your passions and act on your inspiration.  
- Start seeing yourself as a leader. Your ability to lead is a valuable part of you.  
- Collaboration is important, but sometimes strong leadership is necessary. Try different leadership styles. If you usually negotiate, take the lead instead and see how it changes the outcome.  
- Set goals and strive to exceed them. Identify areas in your job where being a leader can improve your effectiveness and career opportunities.

F. Leadership does not happen by itself. It develops through taking the lead, taking risks, and learning from mistakes. Learn to delegate, motivate, organize, and provide feedback.  
- Don’t assume your leadership style will immediately win over your colleagues; it might even push them away. Keep improving your communication skills. You don’t need to be liked, but your ideas and achievements should be respected.  
- Be visible and approachable to those who matter. Remember, you don’t have to lead all the time. Understand when your leadership is essential and how you can help others grow as leaders.

**Films on Video: Reviews by Film Critic Nick James**

**A. Abyss**  
Before "Titanic," director James Cameron created this intense Cold War thriller about oil workers and navy experts trying to save a nuclear submarine trapped deep underwater. The friendly banter and brave attitude of foreman Bud and his team remind us of similar heroes in films by Howard Hawks. The film's visuals and special effects are outstanding, but the dialogue and character development feel weak. Despite the skill in filmmaking, the story is basic B-movie material.

**B. The Thin Red Line**  
This video version of James Jones's novel about the Guadalcanal battle, directed by Andrew Marton, offers a different perspective compared to Terrence Malick's recent film. While Malick's style is mystical and poetic, Marton's film is more traditional, focusing on a single soldier and his tough sergeant. Malick's film is richer and more complex, but Marton's version has its strong moments, especially in a flashback where the soldier dreams of his wife, which is portrayed more harshly than Malick's softer imagery.

**C. On Guard**  
This entertaining swashbuckler, inspired by Paul Feval's 1875 novel, stands out among musketeer films. Fabrice Luchini plays a cunning villain who secretly causes chaos. Vincent Perez is a lively hero, though his role is brief. Daniel Auteuil, while perhaps too serious for a light-hearted film, also shines as an acrobat-turned-swordsman. The filmmakers use familiar costume-drama clichés with such charm and energy that it doesn't feel like a problem.

**D. Character**  
Set in early 20th-century Rotterdam, this serious film features detailed production and costume design that make it look like a museum piece. Jan Decleir plays the grim bailiff Dreverhaven, who is harsh when evicting tenants. His troubled relationship with his son is central to the story, but the filmmakers focus too much on historical details, neglecting the dark and powerful message of the tale.

**E. The Good, the Bad and the Ugly**  
This newly remastered video release highlights director Leone's skill, especially in sound editing, where every sound is clear. The storytelling is harsh, and whenever it slows down, Morricone's powerful music brings excitement back. Morally, there is little difference between the good (Clint Eastwood), the bad (Lee van Cleef), and the ugly (Ell Wallach), as they all act unscrupulously in the post-Civil War West.

**F. The Longest Day**  
Promoted as featuring "forty-eight international stars," this three-hour war epic by Darryl Zanuck has four directors and 23,000 extras, making it feel overly complicated. The early scenes, where battle-hardened veterans wait for news about the invasion, drag on for both the audience and the soldiers. While it is an impressive logistical achievement, it is best experienced on the big screen. Watching it on video diminishes the impact.

**BOOK A** Steve Martin's *Compelling Evidence* is indeed very engaging. The story follows a lawyer who is trying to start a new practice after leaving a powerful law firm. He unexpectedly has to defend his boss's wife when she is accused of murdering her husband. The trial scenes are exciting, with the outcome uncertain until the very end, and there is a surprising twist in the final pages. This is a strong debut in a popular genre.

**BOOK B** *Curtains for the Cardinal* starts with an exciting event and follows the charming Sigismondo, a problem-solver for the Italian Renaissance aristocracy. He gets caught up in a mix of politics, church intrigue, and serious murder, but we are confident he will uncover the guilty parties. The plot is complex, and the book is a bit long, but it is still very enjoyable.

**BOOK C** *File Under: Deceased* introduces a unique new detective from first-time author Sarah Lacey. Leah Hunter is a tax inspector who seems well-suited for some detective work when a strange man collapses at her feet. Despite facing criticism from various people—perhaps tax inspectors are used to this— and the disapproval of a handsome local detective sergeant, brave and adaptable Leah proves to be a strong character.

**BOOK D** *Double Deuce* by Robert B. Parker features the intelligent private investigator Spenser, who helps his friend Hawk remove drug dealers from a troubled neighborhood in Boston. The dialogue is quick and sharp, and while there are fewer deaths than usual, there is more philosophical discussion. As always, Parker provides high-quality entertainment.

**BOOK E** *False Prophet* by Faye Kellermann features her regular detectives, Pete Decker and Marge Dunn, as they investigate an attack and burglary at the home of a famous film star's daughter. The author's straightforward writing style and keen observation of unusual human behavior make this an enjoyable mystery.

**BOOK F** *Blood Red, Snow White* is written by the husband-and-wife team Diane Henry and Nicholas Horrock. It features another lawyer and a female client, but the action takes place outside the courtroom, and the lawyer becomes a victim as the story unfolds. The book skillfully combines elements of romance, money, and violence to create a gripping suspense novel.

**BOOK G** *Dead for a Ducat* by Simon Shaw presents actor Philip Fletcher in a new role as a target. A funny group of characters comes together to film a story about Robin Hood, but Philip feels that this is not the right direction for his career. Simon Shaw usually entertains, but in shifting his star actor from dark comedy to farce, he delivers a performance that is not up to his usual high standard.

**BOOK H** *Fall Down Easy* is Lawrence Gough's best work in a while. Canadian police are on the hunt for a clever bank robber who targets female bank tellers. The slow and expertly crafted build-up of tension, along with the portrayal of the intelligent but disturbed robber, elevates this book above the typical detective novel.

Text: "I might be too old for this adventure, but here I go! At 34, Tim Pozzi has left a good job to go backpacking. He thinks about why he and others his age have decided to take this leap. This summer, I quit my job and decided to rent out my flat to travel in South East Asia for a year. You might think I'm lucky, but I'm 34 years old and feeling nervous. It's not like I haven't traveled before. After university, I spent two years backpacking in North and South America, and when I returned, I promised myself I would do it again someday. But then life happened: I fell in love, started a career, bought a flat, and got used to earning a salary. Gradually, I realized I was sacrificing my own happiness for my salary. When I handed in my resignation, it felt like I was taking control of my life again. I have no ties now. Many of my friends are married with children, and while they wouldn’t trade places with me, they envy my freedom. I’m no longer in a relationship and don’t have strong career goals. I feel I should make the most of this freedom, at least for my friends' sake! 

Why am I so nervous? First, I need to make all the arrangements. How can I let someone else live in my home? How do I organize the rental? And I still need to decide where to go. I tend to procrastinate and am already behind my planned schedule. I thought, 'I might as well enjoy the summer in England,' and then, 'Why not wait for the start of the football season?' Letting go of emotional ties makes it harder. I’m delaying because I wonder if I can handle backpacking again. Will I adjust to a simpler way of life? Will I feel out of place among younger backpackers? Maybe not. I’ve noticed that more Britons in their late twenties and thirties want to break free from their established lives and travel abroad.
