Jennifer Cox from Lonely Planet says there’s a growing realization that adventure is available: 'People who always say "I wish I had that opportunity" are realizing they can have it whenever they want. They just need to be brave, organized, and confident enough to do it.'

For Danny, a 30-year-old accountant, and his girlfriend Tammy, a 28-year-old teacher, this trip is a chance to enjoy life before settling down. They bought a round-the-world ticket for a year. 'I’m willing to give up job security for this trip,' says Danny. 'There’s always a worry that I won’t move up in my career and will return to the same position, but I think it’s a risk worth taking. When I left the office, I threw my calculator into the river as a symbolic act of defiance!' For Matt, who just left the Army, his year of travel was a time of change. 'In the military, there’s a strict way of doing things. I needed to break free from that to live well as a civilian.'

While there are many reasons for traveling at this age, some common factors exist. 'Today, we have a more flexible workforce,' says Angela Baron from the Institute of Personnel Development. 'More people work on short-term contracts, so if your contract ends, you have nothing to lose.' Larger companies are even allowing career breaks. 'If you’ve invested time and money in training someone, it’s good to know they’ll return instead of going to a competitor.' Dan Hiscocks, managing director of Travellerseye, a company that shares stories of 'ordinary' travelers, says more thirty-somethings are reassessing their lives. 'If you’re not happy with your job—and many aren’t—it’s no longer just about sticking it out. People now know that opportunities exist and that a job isn’t permanent. Travel allows you to reflect and think about your life.'

Is giving in to wanderlust just another sign that my generation struggles with adulthood? Jennifer Cox doesn’t think so. 'It shows a better-educated, more stable society where we care less about just paying bills and more about living a balanced life. We’re taking the time to ask, "Is this what I want?"' Ben, a 32-year-old picture researcher going to Central America for a year, believes he’s not running away. 'It’s more about running towards something. I want to pursue my own goals.' But he feels some anxiety. 'I’ll miss my comfortable routine—going to the office every day, saying "hi" to everyone, and having my morning coffee.' I share Ben’s concerns about leaving behind a structured life with few challenges, and I’m not sure I would be making this journey if I hadn’t found my boss so unbearable. As Jennifer Cox points out, 'This is common. There’s often a trigger, like a breakup or job loss, that pushes people to travel.' 

It may have taken a push to get me moving, but I’m now looking forward to the next 12 months with growing excitement. No matter what happens, I’ll take pride in having embraced life. I believe many of us older backpackers feel the same way."

**Transforming Home into a Workplace**

Georgina McGuiness took a long break from journalism and felt disconnected from the technological changes. In this passage, she shares how she turned her home into an efficient workspace.

The Christmas before last, I turned 37 and realized I needed to revive my journalism career, which I thought was fading away due to technology. A quick look at my resume showed I was stuck in the 1980s, when typewriters were the latest technology. I felt that no one would trust me with a computer in a newsroom. Many job ads required experience in desktop publishing, which I lacked. I thought I had a better chance of hosting a seminar on nuclear physics than learning to design a page on a computer. I was known as the family technophobe; even calculators confused me, and I still didn’t know how to use the timer on the video.

I knew I had to act quickly to fill the gap in my career. I thought leaving home before my children would be difficult, but then I entered a competition in a local newspaper. To my surprise, my family won a computer package. We received a laptop for my husband and a personal computer for the family. We jumped into this new world, and terms like cyberspace, Internet, and surfing became part of our everyday language. We started chatting online with strangers from around the world. The children stopped watching television, and I set up a small office in the kitchen with a phone, a fax machine, a CD-ROM, and a modem connecting me to the Internet. I had everything I needed to work from home while still taking the kids to school.

The children were already comfortable with computers from school, but I was nervous, fearing I would lose my work by pressing the wrong button. I was wrong. Although I wasn’t very skilled, I learned the basics. It turned out to be logical and straightforward. With practice, I improved a little each day. I recently started freelancing for a magazine, writing about two articles a month, and I feel proud to have the best of both worlds.

How has the computer helped me? Since school, my desk was always a chaotic mess, and I often lost important papers. The computer has made me more organized, especially with office tasks. Spreadsheets help me track income and expenses, and ready-made invoices and letterheads save me a lot of time. For a journalist, being online allows me to research stories, ask for information in journalism forums, and discuss working from home with people worldwide.

However, there are downsides to working from home. I can feel isolated without physical contact with others. There are also distractions, like household chores, and when the children are home, we sometimes argue over who gets to use the computer. Yet, many people are buying multimedia PCs not just for education and entertainment but also for convenience, avoiding the daily commute to the city.

As we move into the next century, what defines home workers? A report called PC Usage in UK Homes describes the typical computer user as 38 years old and well-educated; 93% own a personal computer, 32% have a CD-ROM, 38% have a laser printer, and 50% have a modem. Considering this, I feel I am ahead of the game. Who knows, one day I might be emailing a column to a newspaper in Melbourne or even publishing my own magazine from home. It seems that the possibilities are endless in this digital age.

**The Tartan Museum**

The modern buildings of Scotland's national museum stand out against the historic backdrop of Edinburgh. But are the exhibits inside just as impressive? Sally Varlow visited the museum just before it opened.

You can't miss the new Museum of Scotland, located at the corner of Chambers Street in Edinburgh. It features a large yellow sandstone tower and unique, wedge-shaped buildings topped with a hanging garden. Last winter, the building received mixed reactions: some called it a "masterpiece" or "stunning," while others were more critical. Now, as the inside prepares for its opening, the exhibitions may face similar opinions.

Forget debates about whether the museum tells a national story or follows a timeline. The answer is yes; it presents a rich tapestry of stories linked to important historical objects. There is a timeline to help visitors navigate, but it does not restrict the displays. The museum does not let its valuable treasures, like Mary Queen of Scots' jewels and the silver from Holyrood chapel, be overshadowed by national pride.

The main concern, assuming the collections are well-preserved, is whether visitors will find the museum engaging enough to return. Dr. David Clarke, the head of exhibitions, believes that a visit should be enjoyable and visually appealing, aimed at those with little prior knowledge. Despite this openness, Clarke insists on a strict approach to what is displayed. He believes that recreations of the past that rely on imagination are misleading. He states, "The public deserves the truth."

At this museum, what you see is based on expert knowledge. However, the challenge for visitors is whether the stories of the objects can be communicated effectively through explanation panels, captions, and multimedia displays, with only about 30 computers available throughout the museum. Just days before the opening, it remains uncertain.

Some aspects are clear, though. The stunning views of Edinburgh Castle are breathtaking. Inside, visitors notice a series of interconnected galleries of various sizes and shapes, with pale walls designed to resemble large stone blocks and deep display cases. Natural light pours in through narrow windows and roof lights, creating a space for visitors to reflect on each item.

Thanks to a 12-member Junior board made up of 9- to 12-year-olds from across Scotland, the museum also features a Discovery Centre. The group wanted to create an interactive experience, but instead, they secured a dedicated hands-on area for children in what was supposed to be a temporary exhibition gallery. Consequently, the Twentieth Century gallery on the top floor is the only temporary exhibition, set to change every three years. It showcases items chosen by Scottish people and notable figures that have significantly influenced life in Scotland during the twentieth century. Suggestions included an electric guitar, televisions, thermos flasks, and favorite toys. While this idea is entertaining, it feels somewhat superficial and does not fully address more serious topics. However, the computerized collection of personal stories and memories will be available next week.

Overall, Dr. Clarke is correct in saying that "objects open windows on the past more vividly than anything else." As for the modern architecture, it is impressive from the inside and the top, but whether it fits well in its location is still up for debate.

**The Future of Print Media: A Complex Transition**

The term "transition" suggests a smooth change from one state to another. While change can be daunting for some, it usually implies a gradual movement from the present to the future. However, the shift of newspapers to the online world is not straightforward and can be quite uncomfortable. Many believe this change is inevitable, as print newspaper sales are declining while online visits are increasing. For instance, major newspapers like The Daily Telegraph and The Guardian have seen their print sales drop by 8% to 10% each year, while their website traffic continues to rise.

Yet, the situation is not entirely clear. A recent survey by the World Association of Newspapers revealed that global newspaper circulation actually increased by 1.1% last year, reaching 512 million copies daily. While sales in Western countries have decreased, Asia has compensated for this decline. Interestingly, news magazines, which many thought would struggle in the digital age, reported a 5.4% increase in sales.

The same trend is seen in the book industry. E-readers like Kindle are becoming very popular, with significant sales growth this year. However, when bookstores assessed their sales of physical books over the past six months, they found only a slight decrease of 0.4%. This suggests that both digital and print formats can coexist.

The idea that young people are completely abandoning newspapers is exaggerated. According to the latest National Readership Survey, nearly 5 million people aged 15 to 35 still read major national newspapers. Different countries in Europe show varying trends: Britain has seen a 10.8% drop in newspaper sales, while Germany's decline is only 7%, and France has experienced a mere 3.1% fall.

These differences indicate that the situation is more complex than the advocates of digital media suggest. In the past, analysts believed that rising online advertising revenues would support the transition to digital newspapers. However, with digital ad revenues now declining, this assumption seems outdated. Many US newspapers have introduced paywalls to charge for online access. Interestingly, offering a print subscription along with digital access appears to be an effective strategy to attract paying readers. Print editions still play a vital role in selling online subscriptions, as print advertising generates significantly more revenue than online ads.

Maintaining both a print edition and an online presence is challenging and costly for newspaper companies. However, print media still holds a strong presence, and being noticed online can be much more difficult.

**Photographing People**

People are the most fascinating subjects to photograph. A picture that includes a person is usually more interesting than one without. However, photographing people can be challenging. Besides technical skills, photographers must pay attention to actions, gestures, and expressions. The presence of a camera can sometimes change how people behave.

**A. Grouping People**  
When taking group photos, avoid straight lines. Have people stand at different angles and distances, and if possible, at different heights. You can also have some people sit or kneel in front so that all faces are visible, or raise your camera to get a better view.

**B. Posing for Pictures**  
People often feel stiff in front of a camera. Help them relax by suggesting comfortable positions, like folding their hands or putting them in their pockets.

**C. The Right Approach**  
Do not pretend you are not taking a picture when it is obvious. This can create tension. Most people will agree to have their picture taken, even if they hesitate at first. They may feel self-conscious, so you might need to guide them. A picture can be less interesting if the subject looks away from the camera.

**D. Eye Contact**  
A photo is more powerful if the subject looks at the viewer. Ask them to look into the lens, and they don’t have to smile. They might not be able to do this for long, so remind them just before you take the picture. You can also say something funny to get a natural reaction.

**E. Candid Concentration**  
Instead of direct eye contact, you can have the subject focus on something in the picture. This can make them feel more comfortable, and it allows the viewer to see what the subject is looking at. Candid shots can be very engaging, and the subject's expression is important.

**F. Expressions and Gestures**  
Expressions and gestures reveal a lot about a person. For example, a laughing child can make viewers smile, while a sad face can evoke sympathy. Look for common expressions like shrugs, winks, or smiles; they communicate feelings instantly.

**G. Situation Interest**  
While close-up shots of a person can be striking, the background can add context and interest. When including a background, avoid irrelevant details or blur them to keep the focus on the subject. A wide-angle lens can help make the subject appear larger compared to the background.

**H. Interaction**  
Capturing moments where people are interacting—like talking, laughing, or working together—can lead to great photos. Couples, mothers with babies, and teams are all good subjects. Look for eye contact or physical connections, like a hand on an arm, to show relationships.

**I. People and Places**  
Many photos of people are taken during trips. To improve these pictures, use a standard or wide-angle lens and step back to include the background, like a building or landscape. Position your subjects close to the camera while ensuring the background is visible. An elevated camera position can help achieve this balance.

**J. To Pose or Not to Pose?**  
Decide why you want to take the picture. If it’s to remember someone you met briefly, a clear posed picture is best. However, family photos can become boring if they are all formal poses. Candid shots of events are often more lively and can capture genuine moments, creating lasting memories.

**Under Sarah's Spell**

Sarah Janson is a trompe-l'oeil artist, which means her paintings create an illusion of reality that tricks the eye. In this interview with Joanna Watt, we learn more about her unique perspective on art.

Not many artists choose not to sign their work unless asked, but Sarah Janson is one of them. She believes that the artwork itself is more important than the artist. "It's not the artist who is important, but the work," she says. Sarah is very humble and almost wants people to think her paintings create themselves. This attitude makes for an interesting magazine interview. "I just don't like to shout about myself," she admits, and she becomes nervous when asked to be photographed.

After some time, Sarah relaxes, and the interview turns into a fun and engaging conversation. She has been a trompe-l'oeil artist for sixteen years, following two years of intense drawing at art school, a degree in graphic illustration, and work at a publishing house. However, she found illustration unfulfilling and joined a specialist decorator named Jim Smart. He asked her to create one trompe-l'oeil piece, and that sparked her passion. "Suddenly my interest got channelled," she explains. She started her own business, unsure of where it would lead but feeling it was the right path.

Sarah's keen observation skills and attention to detail, developed through her illustration work, are crucial for her trompe-l'oeil art. She often gets asked where to learn this technique, but she believes it cannot be taught. "Trompe-l'oeil is the school of life. It's all about observation," she insists. She remains humble, saying she is still learning. "The moment you think you've mastered a field, you might as well give up."

She is also honest about her weaknesses, like her inability to paint bread convincingly. When faced with a large project for a chapel ceiling, she struggled with the measurements and questioned her abilities. "You're not Michelangelo. Who do you think you are?" she thought. This self-doubt leads her to speak about her work in the third person, saying things like, "When I finished that ceiling, I thought, 'Well, I didn't do it; she did.'"

Sarah's trompe-l'oeil art stands out from others, especially as the style has become popular again, but not always successfully. She has completed many significant projects for both businesses and private clients. Much of her work is inspired by architecture. For example, she created a trompe-l'oeil dining room based on a Venetian palace and a painting that makes a hallway look like it leads to two more rooms.

However, trompe-l'oeil art has a challenge: once people understand the trick, they may lose interest. Sarah knows this well. "Trompe-l'oeil has to do two things. First, it must draw you in; it has to trick you. Secondly, it has to hold your attention and engage your imagination. That is the most important part."

Sarah believes that trompe-l'oeil should also be personal to the client. "I love the interaction with clients; that is where the ideas are born," she says. Some clients have clear ideas, while others do not, so she listens carefully to understand their vision. Many clients become friends, especially since she often works closely with them on-site. 

Sarah appreciates her clients, saying, "I am very grateful for the mad ones who have let me loose on their walls." They seem happy with her work, which keeps her busy, despite her modesty. "I really don't like to shout about myself," she repeats. "Like my work, I am very restrained. I don't want it to shout. You become bored with things that shout." While this may be true, it is hard to become bored with Sarah or her art. Her work deserves more recognition, and I am willing to promote it, even if she might not like it.

**Emotional Intelligence - The Key to Success**

Daniel Goleman explores the important 'people skills' needed to succeed in our careers.

A. The rules for work are changing. We are now evaluated not only on our intelligence and training but also on how we manage ourselves and interact with others. This new way of judging is increasingly used in hiring decisions and promotions. It helps identify who is likely to excel and who may not. These skills are important for our future job prospects, regardless of our current field. The ability to perform well in exams is becoming less relevant. The new focus assumes we all have the necessary knowledge and skills for our jobs. Instead, it emphasizes social skills and personal qualities like initiative, empathy, adaptability, and persuasiveness—collectively known as emotional intelligence.

B. In a time when job security is uncertain, personal qualities are becoming more important in the workplace. For years, these qualities have been referred to by various names, such as 'character' and 'soft skills.' Now, we have a clearer understanding of these abilities, which we call 'emotional intelligence.' This is defined as the ability to understand and manage our own feelings and those of others, using emotions to guide our thoughts and actions. In the workplace, emotional intelligence includes self-awareness, self-regulation, motivation, empathy, and social skills. Some people mistakenly think it just means being nice. However, it can sometimes require being direct and honest, even if it’s uncomfortable. Emotional intelligence is about managing feelings so they are expressed appropriately, allowing people to work together effectively towards shared goals.

C. More businesses recognize that promoting emotional intelligence is vital for good management. In complex jobs, emotional intelligence becomes even more important because a lack of these skills can limit the effectiveness of a person's technical knowledge. While some individuals have succeeded despite lacking emotional intelligence, as work becomes more collaborative, companies that foster teamwork gain a competitive advantage. In today’s work environment, which values teamwork and customer focus, emotional intelligence is essential for success in every job around the world.

D. Unlike IQ, which changes little over time, emotional intelligence can develop as we gain life experience. Studies show that most people become better at managing their emotions, motivating themselves, and improving their empathy and social skills as they grow older. This growth in emotional intelligence is often called maturity. We can learn these skills and add them to our toolkit for success, especially in a time when job stability is uncertain. While emotional intelligence is not a guaranteed solution for struggling organizations, ignoring the human element can prevent everything else from functioning effectively.

Text: 'Should the media profit from content they do not own? Digital cameras and camera phones have made it easier to capture important news events, but social media has changed citizen photography significantly. As news often breaks on social networks, some journalists are now using these platforms for images during fast-moving events. Unfortunately, some reporters have shared user-generated content (UGC) without asking for permission. Although there are guidelines stating that images on social media can be used without permission in special cases or when there is strong public interest, there is still debate about whether this is ethical. Research shows that about one in ten people would film or photograph a news event, indicating that UGC will play a significant role in the future of the media. However, to maintain a good relationship with the public, the media must ensure that individuals are fairly compensated for their work and that permission is always obtained.'

**Ancient Chinese Medicine in the West**

Acupuncture is a practice that is over two thousand years old and is part of traditional Chinese medicine. This system also includes herbal remedies, massage, diet, physical manipulation, and exercise. While acupuncture can treat various health issues, it is particularly noted for its effectiveness in pain relief. Many general practitioners, midwives, and physiotherapists in the West use it for this purpose.

**A. Understanding Traditional Chinese Medicine**

Traditional Chinese medicine views health as a balance of energy in the mind, body, and spirit. This energy, called Qi (pronounced "chee"), flows through the body along pathways known as meridians. There are twelve main meridians, each connected to a specific organ, and many smaller ones that deliver Qi to every cell. If the flow of Qi is blocked or disrupted, it can lead to weakness or illness. During a consultation, an acupuncturist will assess where these imbalances occur by checking your pulse, examining your tongue, and looking at your overall health. They will also ask about your medical history, current health, mental state, and lifestyle habits like eating and sleeping.

**B. Acupuncture Points**

The acupuncture points correspond to the meridians and may not be located near the area of pain. Patients often report feeling a mild ache or tingling when the needle is gently moved. This can be done manually or with an electro-acupuncture device. Practitioners believe this sensation indicates that the needle has reached the Qi in the meridian. There are over three hundred acupuncture points on the main meridians, with many more used less frequently.

**C. Scientific Understanding**

Even without accepting traditional Chinese medicine's principles, many Western doctors recognize that acupuncture can help relieve pain. Scientific explanations suggest that stimulating certain nerves can block pain signals from reaching the brain. Additionally, some researchers believe that acupuncture may trigger the release of natural pain-relieving chemicals in the body, known as endorphins.

**D. Types of Pain Treated**

Many individuals with chronic pain turn to acupuncture when other treatments have failed. Commonly treated conditions include back pain, sports injuries, arthritis, headaches, migraines, and pain after surgery. Acupuncturists also claim to help with menstrual pain, facial nerve pain, and pain experienced by terminally ill patients.

**E. Modern Applications of Acupuncture**

Although acupuncture has been practiced in China for over two millennia, its use as an alternative to anesthesia in surgery began in the 1950s. This development helped persuade some doctors outside China of acupuncture's effectiveness. Today, acupuncture is used in various surgical procedures in China, including tonsillectomies and heart surgeries. Needles may be used alone, with electrical stimulation, or alongside medications. While pain relief varies from person to person, many report significant pain reduction. Acupuncturists argue that acupuncture has fewer side effects than traditional anesthetics, such as nausea, and allows for quicker recovery.

**F. Effectiveness of Acupuncture**

Conducting clinical trials on acupuncture can be challenging, but studies show that 50 to 80 percent of patients find it effective for chronic pain. Acupuncturists generally agree with this success rate, acknowledging that it may not work for everyone. They suggest that patients with long-term pain may need six to seven sessions to experience significant relief, although some improvement can often be felt after just two or three visits.

**G. A Holistic Approach to Pain**

Western and Chinese medicine have different perspectives on pain. Acupuncturists take a holistic approach, considering not just the symptoms but also the overall health of the patient. They spend time diagnosing the underlying issues related to Qi and consider external factors that may affect pain, such as weather conditions. This comprehensive view is less common in conventional medical practice.

**H. Traditional vs. Modern Practices**

Some medical professionals have training in traditional acupuncture, while others, including many general practitioners, prefer scientific explanations. Traditional acupuncturists believe that applying the principles of traditional Chinese medicine is essential for achieving lasting healing, which can be difficult to measure in studies. It is important to choose a qualified acupuncturist, who should refer you to a medical doctor for further evaluation if needed.

P.D. James is a well-known crime writer whose gentle appearance hides a deep and creative mind. Her full name is Phyllis Dorothy James, and she carries an air of quiet confidence. One can easily imagine her as a headmistress of a girls' school if she had not chosen to write detective stories filled with unexpected twists. However, it quickly becomes clear that her confident demeanor is a cover for her shyness. She admits that her main character, Adam Dalgliesh, the detective in her books, is based on herself, or how she might have been if she were a man. Dalgliesh prefers to solve crimes alone, just like James prefers to write in solitude. She needs complete privacy to write, no matter where she is.

Despite her success, she is too humble to agree that she is the most famous crime writer in Britain, even though millions read her twelve major detective novels worldwide. She admires her friend Ruth Rendell's psychological novels, written under the name Barbara Vine. The books she enjoys most are often by women writers like Iris Murdoch, Anita Brookner, and Penelope Lively, but she also appreciates male authors like Graham Greene and Evelyn Waugh, whom she considers great novelists.

P.D. James found success later in life. She was 42 when her first crime novel, Cover Her Face, was published. Born in Oxford, she grew up in Cambridge after her family moved there when she was 11. She met her husband, a university student, in Cambridge, which is why she set her book An Unsuitable Job For A Woman there. She shares that her life has had its challenges, including the struggles she faced when her husband, Connor Bantry White, returned from World War II very ill. To support him and their two young daughters, Clare and Jane, she worked long hours. Although she had many ideas for stories, she had little time to write. Thankfully, her husband's parents helped care for her daughters during those tough times.

While working full-time in administration for the National Health Service, she used her excellent organizational skills. At one point, she managed five psychiatric outpatient clinics. She then spent 11 years at the Home Office, first in the Police Department and later in the Criminal Law section, focusing on juvenile crime. While working in forensic science, she became used to seeing dead bodies, but her interest was not in death itself. Instead, she was drawn to the structure and creativity involved in writing crime novels. She has always loved reading detective stories and knew she wanted to be a writer.

James did not want to write about her own traumatic experiences. She saw writing detective stories as a great way to learn the craft of serious novel writing while keeping her personal life separate. Over time, she realized that it was possible to follow the traditional format of a detective story and still create a meaningful novel about human nature. She believes that writing detective stories helps bring order to chaos, and solving a crime affirms the value of life, even if that life is difficult. Ultimately, she notes that no one truly enjoys violence.

**The Pen is Mightier than the Psychoanalyst**

The study of handwriting to understand a person's character is becoming more popular. In some countries, if you apply for a job, you will likely be asked to provide a sample of your handwriting. This handwriting sample can significantly influence whether you are considered suitable for the position. Handwriting analysis, known as graphology, is recognized as a legitimate science in many places. Researchers suggest it can help identify certain health issues, like heart disease and cancer, and can also reveal emotional and psychological states.

Graphology is increasingly used for career guidance and as a supplement to job interviews. Many large companies now hire graphologists to analyze the handwriting of job candidates. However, many doctors and psychiatrists are skeptical about the effectiveness of graphology. Patricia Marne, a professional graphologist with over 20 years of experience, believes it deserves more attention. She argues that handwriting can reflect psychological traits and some medical conditions. According to her, "Handwriting is a strong indicator of social class and intelligence. It can also help assess mental abilities, whether someone should focus on arts or sciences, and whether they have a manipulative or honest character."

Ms. Marne claims that graphology can be particularly useful in identifying potential criminal behavior. She notes that criminals often have disturbed handwriting, which can be poorly shaped and sometimes childish. Many criminals come from difficult backgrounds and may show signs of emotional immaturity in their handwriting. She states, "I can determine if people are honest, manipulative, or trustworthy." 

Young male offenders often have tall letters, suggesting they live in a fantasy world and dream of success. Graphologists can also predict if someone is under extreme stress or has violent tendencies. Handwriting can even indicate suicidal thoughts. Ms. Marne explains that heart and lung issues can also be reflected in handwriting. While one sample may not provide enough information, changes in handwriting over time, such as a previously stable signature becoming shaky, can signal serious problems. A significant emotional upset may also temporarily alter a person's signature.

Ms. Marne describes how handwriting can reveal various psychological traits. For example, people whose letters connect like threads may be clever but deceptive. Those who write mostly in capital letters might be hiding their true selves. Light pressure in writing suggests sensitivity and low energy. Originality in handwriting shows confidence and creativity, while disconnected writing often indicates a person who prefers solitude. Small signatures can reflect feelings of inferiority, while circles over the letter "i" may indicate a desire for attention. Heavy crossing of the letter "t" can suggest intolerance and a condescending attitude.

Ms. Marne believes that it takes six years of study and experience to accurately analyze handwriting, along with empathy and intuition. She feels more research is needed to establish graphology as a scientific discipline, and she is optimistic that this will happen soon. She claims, "It is actually more accurate than psychoanalysis because it reveals a person's entire history, including emotional crises, without needing to ask potentially misleading questions."

Despite these intriguing claims, there is little solid evidence to support them. Some psychiatrists criticize graphology, arguing that handwriting is influenced by education, artistic skills, and the writing style taught, and does not hold any deeper significance.

**Is Your Office Working Well?**

Fresh air and comfortable chairs are essential for a happy and healthy workplace, according to a recent survey. We visited four different offices to see how healthy and happy they were as work environments. Our expert panel included a building health consultant, an ergonomist who studies working conditions, and an occupational psychologist. Here are their assessments.

**Office A: Advertising Agency**

- **Building Health Consultant:** This office is very basic; it has no central heating or mechanical ventilation, and the windows open directly to the street. Surprisingly, the small team of seven people seems happy. They adapt to the seasons by opening doors and roof panels or using electric heaters, similar to how they would at home. This may be the reason for their happiness: they have created a comfortable, homely work environment without unnecessary rules.

- **Ergonomist:** The furniture is mismatched and often creates poor posture. Many chairs are old, not adjustable, and some are broken. However, the staff has a varied work schedule that they control, which includes office work, client meetings, and presentations. This variety helps reduce fatigue and boredom.

- **Occupational Psychologist:** Employees enjoy the variety of tasks and the flexible office space. They feel the office is "just the right size"—small enough to know what others are doing, yet large enough to focus on individual work. The office is attractive and fun, showing both efficiency and creativity.

**Office B: News Service**

- **Building Health Consultant:** This office may not be very exciting, but it is comfortable and staff do not dislike it. The air quality and maintenance are good, partly due to a No Smoking policy.

- **Ergonomist:** The company has hired an ergonomist, so the chairs are excellent, and the lighting and computer equipment are good. The layout could be better, but the environment feels impersonal with plain grey walls.

- **Occupational Psychologist:** The walls are mostly bare, except for year planners and a poster about maternity rights. Most employees have been there for over five years, and relationships are satisfactory. The office could improve by rearranging desks to facilitate sharing information and displaying project updates on the walls.

**Office C: Bank**

- **Building Health Consultant:** This office receives mixed reviews. It feels like being in a glass case, surrounded by many similar spaces. Despite having both smokers and non-smokers, the air quality is acceptable.

- **Ergonomist:** The office is standard and uninspiring. The desks are barely adequate, and not all chairs meet ergonomic standards. Many computer screens are on low desks, which is not suitable for modern equipment.

- **Occupational Psychologist:** Staff support each other well and have good technology. The office has many awards on display, but the wood paneling and brown carpet create a dull atmosphere. However, the office is busy and active.

**Office D: Newspaper**

- **Building Health Consultant:** This office has many issues. The air conditioning is poorly controlled, leading to uncomfortable temperature changes. The space is cluttered, and most desks are too small. Dust is a problem, as it collects in many areas.

- **Ergonomist:** The furniture is more suitable for a workshop than a modern office. Many chairs are old and do not support proper posture, especially for shorter users.

- **Occupational Psychologist:** The office has old, dirty chairs and carpets, and it needs a thorough cleaning. Individual achievements should be recognized more, and the air conditioning needs immediate improvement due to many smokers. During our visit, there were few conversations, and everyone seemed stressed and focused on deadlines. The company should encourage teamwork.

**Chewing Gum Culture**

Chewing gum is popular, accessible to everyone, and Americans chew about 12 million sticks every day. This ancient practice has turned into a large business. Each stick of chewing gum has fewer than ten calories, but it is considered food and must meet the standards set by the American Food and Drug Administration.

Today, most gum is made from synthetic materials, including added pine resins and softeners that help maintain flavor and improve texture. However, this was not always the case. The ancient Greeks chewed a resin from the mastic tree, which grows mainly in Greece and Turkey. Greek women especially liked mastic gum for cleaning their teeth and freshening their breath. American colonists learned from the Native Americans in New England and chewed resin from spruce trees. In the early 1800s, pieces of spruce for chewing were sold in the eastern United States, marking the beginning of commercial chewing gum in the country.

Modern chewing gum began in the late 1860s with the discovery of chicle, a milky substance from the sapodilla tree found in Central America. Gum made from chicle was smoother, more enjoyable, and more elastic, leading to the growth of a new industry. However, attempts to grow sapodilla trees commercially have not been successful. As the demand for chewing gum increased, synthetic alternatives were created.

Today, the few remaining chicle gatherers, known as chicleros, struggle to make a living. They trek for miles to collect sap from scattered sapodilla trees in very humid conditions. The environment is dangerous, with poisonous snakes and many insects. One particularly troublesome insect, the chicle fly, lays its eggs in the ears and noses of the gatherers. Despite these risks, experienced chicleros can quickly climb trees to collect the sap, which they carry back to a camp where it is boiled and turned into bricks.

Life at the camp is difficult, with a boring and often inadequate diet based mainly on maize, accompanied by a local alcohol made from sugar cane. Despite these harsh conditions, chicleros worry about their jobs. Not long ago, the United States imported 7,000 tonnes of chicle each year from Central America, but last year only 200 tonnes were collected in Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula.

As chewing gum sales have increased, manufacturers have shifted to synthetic ingredients to lower costs and meet demand. Meanwhile, gum producers are finding creative ways to market their products. They claim that chewing gum helps people relax, boosts energy, and reduces stress. During both world wars, soldiers were regularly given gum. One of the main benefits of gum is that it can help reduce tooth decay. When we eat, plaque acid forms, but our saliva helps neutralize this acid and provides important minerals. Gum manufacturers say that chewing for 20 minutes can increase saliva production.

Research continues on new textures and flavors for gum. Glycerine and other vegetable oils are now used to create the gum base. Most new flavors are artificial, but some still require natural ingredients. Additionally, 137 square kilometers of land in America is dedicated to growing mint for the two most popular chewing gums in the world.

**REMOTE HOTELS**

**A. INDIA - GHANERAO HOTEL, RAJASTHAN**  
Ghanerao Hotel is located at the edge of the Aravalli Hills in a small village known for its craftsmen. It combines the calmness of an English country house with Indian culture. The Ghanerao family has lived here for 400 years, and now Sajjan Singh and his wife welcome guests into their home. The hotel offers basic facilities, with hot water provided by bucket, but these simple aspects enhance its charm.

**B. NEW ZEALAND - HERMITAGE HOTEL, MOUNT COOK**  
One of my favorite hotels is the Hermitage Hotel on New Zealand's South Island. I discovered it by chance while climbing. After being flown close to the top of a glacier and climbing to the peak, we had to walk down. To my surprise, we found this hotel at the bottom, set in stunning, wild countryside. Arriving tired and finding such luxury, with a pianist playing Cole Porter, was an unforgettable experience.

**C. MAURITIUS - PARADIS HOTEL**  
On the southwest coast of Mauritius, the Paradis Hotel is located on a quiet peninsula. The road to the hotel winds along the coast, passing empty beaches where only fishermen are present. Although the hotel is large and offers many free water sports, you can easily find solitude along its nine kilometers of private beach. Swim a little way out into the Indian Ocean, and the hotel becomes hidden behind palm trees. In the evening, when everyone has left, you can enjoy the peaceful beach as the sky darkens.

**D. ST LUCIA - LADERA HOTEL**  
The Ladera Hotel in St Lucia has one of the most stunning views in the Caribbean. It is quiet and located at 1,000 feet above sea level, with open rooms that look out between the twin peaks of the Pitons to the Caribbean Sea. The hotel features colonial-style furniture made of mahogany and greenheart wood, and has four-poster beds with muslin netting.

**E. TURKEY - THE SPLENDID HOTEL, ISTANBUL**  
The Splendid Hotel, located on Buyukada in the Princes Islands, is an ideal escape from the noise of Istanbul. The islands are just an hour away by boat and are very picturesque. There are no cars, only horse-drawn carriages and beautiful wooden buildings from the 1920s. The Splendid Hotel, painted white with red domes, is modeled after a historic hotel on the French Riviera. Although it is a bit worn down now, it still retains its charm.

**F. FRANCE - CHATEAU D'ETOGES, EPERNAY**  
In the small village of Etoges, in the Champagne region, there is a lovely seventeenth-century chateau surrounded by a moat with two swans. This chateau, which was a family home until recently, has 20 unique rooms, some with four-poster beds, and one even has a billiard table. They offer special weekend rates for two nights, including breakfast and dinner, along with complimentary champagne.

**G. KENYA - THE FAIRVIEW HOTEL, NAIROBI**  
The Fairview Hotel is a rare find in Africa—a comfortable hotel that avoids excessive luxury. It is a popular stop for travelers recovering from safaris and planning their next adventure. Guests often arrive, see the beautiful gardens and inviting rooms, and decide to stay longer. The hotel has apartments for those who want to settle in for a few months. Located on Nairobi Hill, it feels far removed from the busy city center. It’s a great place to enjoy the stunning African sunset while sipping beer and looking forward to a hearty dinner.

**H. ITALY - HOTEL SPLENDIDO, PORTOFINO**  
The Hotel Splendido was first signed into by the Duke of Windsor, and since then, many famous people have visited, including Lauren Bacall and Humphrey Bogart. Today, you might meet wealthy guests, but this former monastery turned villa still offers a splendid experience. The restaurant serves delicious, simple food, and the hotel features beautiful Persian rugs and homemade pasta.

Sue Brown is a hotel inspector who evaluates hotels for her job. Christopher Middleton observed her during an inspection at the Globe Hotel. Just one minute into the inspection, problems began to arise, although the hotel staff were unaware of it. The receptionist was busy giving room rates over the phone to a potential guest and did not notice Sue and Christopher. "She hasn't even acknowledged us," Sue whispered, noting this poor service. This is a common mistake that Sue has seen many times in her 11 years as an inspector. She expected better from a hotel with three red stars, which means it is among the top 130 hotels out of 4,000 in the guide she works for.

Before they even received a warm welcome, Sue noticed that the entrance from the car park was through an unmanned door with a buzzer, leading to a long, empty corridor. "This is not what I expected," she said. Things got worse when the receptionist informed them, in a cheerful tone, that there was no record of their booking. It turned out that most of the hotel’s 15 rooms were empty that night. The only available room was on the top floor, but Sue found it stuffy and noticed a large hole in the wall behind the wardrobe.

In her early career, Sue earned a reputation for being tough, even though she claims she is not. The next morning, after paying her bill, she revealed her identity to the hotel’s general manager, Robin Greaves, who looked terrified. He quickly apologized for a bad smell in the main lounge, explaining that there might be a blocked drain. Sue suggested that he should guide guests to another lounge instead of the one with the smell. Greaves, who had only been at the hotel for five months, took notes and seemed unsure about Sue's advice, even though she assured him that her feedback would help the hotel in the long run.

Not everything was negative; Sue praised Emma, the assistant manager, and Trudy, the young waitress, for their knowledge about the hotel’s 400-year history. The dinner also met the standards to keep the hotel’s two-rosette food rating, which encouraged Greaves to ask how they could achieve three rosettes. Sue's response was simple: "Don’t serve a pudding that collapses." Greaves’ enthusiasm faded at this suggestion.

Sue's job is to express the complaints that many customers are too afraid to voice. She recalled a time when a woman complained that Sue had gotten her son fired for serving apple pie with his fingers. She often receives letters with false accusations, which can be hurtful, but she has learned to expect them. Sue must provide both verbal and written reports of her findings to the hotel, as they pay for her expertise. Despite the challenges, being recognized with red stars makes her work worthwhile. It was good news for Greaves that Sue would not recommend taking away the Globe's red stars, but the bad news was that another inspector would return in two months to ensure improvements were made. "Good," Greaves said with a forced smile. "We’ll look forward to that."

**Seven Summits: A Mountaineer's Journey**

Doug Scott, an experienced mountaineer, shares his incredible experiences of climbing the highest peaks on each continent, known as the Seven Summits. He began this journey later in life and will describe each mountain in the order he climbed them.

**A. Mt. Everest, Asia (8,848m)**  
While resting in a snow cave 91 meters below the summit, Doug and his climbing partner, Dougal Haston, had a strange conversation about sleeping bags, even though they were alone. Doug felt the effects of low oxygen and began talking to his feet, which were getting cold. He remembered other climbers who had lost fingers and toes to frostbite. They were not just worried about surviving but about how well they could survive. Over the next two days, Doug reflected on their time on the summit ridge and felt grateful to have Dougal with him, as he inspired confidence. Doug focused on finding a better rhythm to reach the summit, which he successfully did.

**B. Mt. McKinley, North America (6,194m)**  
Considered one of the most dangerous mountains, Doug and Dougal arrived at the Kahiltna Glacier in April 1976. They spent four days carrying equipment and food to the base. After the first day of climbing, they realized how challenging their task was. They followed a route established in 1967 but decided to take a new path to the summit. They climbed with all their gear on their backs, which was a first for this area. After facing tough conditions, including a wet sleeping bag and strong winds, they finally reached the summit and celebrated their achievement.

**C. Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,895m)**  
In September 1976, Doug and his friend Paul Braithwaite planned to climb Mt. Kenya but ended up on Kilimanjaro after getting a free ride. They got lost in the dense jungle, which was concerning due to the lack of water. On the second day, they found a trail marked by arrows and some litter, leading them to a rock pool. They attempted a challenging climb but decided to take a safer route to the summit instead.

**D. Aconcagua, South America (6,960m)**  
In January 1992, Doug and his wife, Sharu, arrived at Punta del Inca and met fellow climber Phil Erscheler. Phil invited them to join his group, which was taking a less crowded route. After waiting for bad weather to pass, they set off. The Polish Glacier was icy and dangerous, so they chose to follow the standard route instead. Despite strong winds, they reached the summit just before dark and camped outside a refuge. At base camp, they met climbers from the Jakarta Mountaineering Club, who encouraged Doug to pursue the Seven Summits goal.

**E. Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897m)**  
Doug realized that climbing Vinson Massif was possible by guiding others to cover the costs. In late November 1992, his team traveled to the South Pole. During this time, the sun never sets, creating a unique atmosphere. On December 7, they set out for the summit. Despite harsh winds and freezing temperatures, they all reached the top within eight hours, although visibility was poor due to a storm.

**F. Elbrus, Europe (5,633m)**  
In the summer of 1994, Doug's team gathered in St. Petersburg and traveled to Terskol, near Elbrus. They faced a fee for bringing foreigners into the valley, but it was later waived. After acclimatizing, they took a cable car to 3,900 meters and then walked to a refuge at 4,200 meters. Two days later, they faced strong winds while climbing. They thought they had reached the summit but discovered there was still more to climb. They returned to the refuge and descended the volcano the next day.

**G. Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883m)**  
On their expedition to Carstensz, Doug and his team aimed to create a new route and spend time with the local Dani people. They were warned about potential dangers from bandits but decided to proceed. On May 12, they began climbing, and the weather improved. Two team members moved ahead while Doug and Sham, who was filming, climbed more slowly. They reached the summit by 11 am, and Doug received a standing ovation for completing his seventh summit. Mission accomplished!

**Style Merchants**

Style influences many aspects of our lives today, from clothing to home decor and accessories. Jo Foley shares the latest trends for fashion enthusiasts this year.

**Ned Ingham: Dress Designer**  
Ned Ingham creates beautiful, romantic wedding dresses. He advises people to steer clear of traditional, stiff designs and overly frilly styles, opting instead for simpler looks. Ingham has been sketching and designing wedding dresses since he was a child. At 16, he attended fashion school, where he learned how to cut and sew clothes. However, you don’t need to be a bride to wear an Ingham dress; he also designs elegant evening gowns, updated with modern colors and fabrics. For those who prefer classic styles, Ingham offers a timeless navy-blue summer suit, a staple in women's wardrobes throughout the 20th century, but he gives it a fresh, contemporary twist.

**Sally Quail: Jeweller**  
Sally Quail previously worked for an art dealer but has no formal training in jewellery design. She began creating her own engagement ring when she couldn’t find one she liked. This led her to start her own design business in 1990, and now her jewellery is popular among many celebrities. Her signature style features large semi-precious stones set in gold, creating stunning necklaces, bracelets, and rings inspired by 18th-century designs. Recently, she has started using diamonds, saying, "I reached that moment in every woman's life when she wants a diamond."

**Lily Grimson: Handbag Designer**  
Just four years after entering the competitive fashion industry, Lily Grimson has had two of her designs chosen for a major exhibition, despite only taking a basic art and design course. Her handbags are always noticed, as they are handmade in the UK and exude glamour, whether made from luxurious calfskin or rich silk. A Grimson bag combines elegance and attention to detail, making it truly special.

**Peter Little: Hairdresser**  
For over 20 years, Peter Little has styled the hair of many famous individuals. He understands that most women want a natural look that they can manage at home. His unique approach ensures that clients don’t look like they just left a salon. However, this relaxed style comes at a price—£250 for the first appointment, with a three-month waiting list. Leveraging his fame, Peter has launched his own line of hairdryers and styling tools, allowing those who can’t visit his salon to achieve their desired looks at home.

**Penny Pratt: Florist**  
Penny Pratt runs a small flower shop and works as a consultant for a large supermarket chain, providing floral ideas for top restaurants. Remarkably, she has no formal qualifications in floristry and left her teaching job ten years ago to pursue a new path. Her modern and simple floral arrangements have won numerous design awards, helping her establish her own London Flower School. She has also enjoyed successful lecture tours in Japan and the USA. Penny believes that flower arrangements today should be simple yet striking, avoiding excessive leaves, which can be too large and overpowering. For wedding bouquets, she emphasizes that all flowers should be of the same type.

**Five-Star Luxury with Modern Technology**

The new five-star Merrion Hotel in Dublin combines luxury with the latest technology. It was created by transforming four large 18th-century houses and took nearly two years of work. This approach allowed for the installation of advanced technology that benefits both staff and guests.

General Manager Peter MacCann expects his staff to know guests by name, but he uses a computer system to track guests' preferences. This system helps the hotel provide special treatment for returning guests. Although it cost £250,000 to set up, MacCann believes it will be worth it over time due to its efficiency. For instance, if a guest requests specific music CDs during their first stay, those same CDs will be ready for them on their next visit, thanks to the guest-history feature.

Room temperature is another common concern for hotel guests. The Merrion has a high-tech system that allows guests to adjust the temperature within three degrees of the normal 18°C. Additionally, the front desk can change the temperature in each room between 14°C and 25°C.

Business travelers will find the hotel particularly appealing, as MacCann estimates that about 65% of their business comes from this group. To meet their needs, the hotel has equipped each room with three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and video-conferencing capabilities. The hotel has also prepared for future technological advancements by installing extra cables and renting televisions, which can be easily replaced with newer models.

Despite all this technology, MacCann emphasizes that they want guests to feel comfortable, not overwhelmed. The hotel has 145 spacious and well-furnished rooms that are inviting and cozy. Guests can also enjoy a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a lovely garden.

The food at the Merrion is exceptional, thanks to Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who moved his two-Michelin-star restaurant to the hotel. This move has allowed him to create a modern kitchen and improve parking facilities. For the hotel, having a renowned restaurant on-site is a great advantage with minimal financial risk. With its combination of technology and skilled staff, the Merrion Hotel is poised for success.

**An Eye for Detail**

Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings, which are inspired by the large garden around her house. This garden is filled with her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread throughout the garden. The two long flower borders along the paved path that runs from east to west are beautifully arranged in terms of color, shape, and structure. This beauty is partly due to the previous owners, who were passionate gardeners and left behind plants that Susan loves. She also kept the gardener, Danny. "In fact, it was really his garden," she says. "We got along very well. At first, he would say, 'Oh, it's not worth it' for some of the things I wanted to add, but when I told him I wanted to paint them, he understood my vision."

Susan prefers to paint detailed studies of individual plants rather than the entire garden, although she sometimes paints groups of plants in their natural setting. More often, she picks the flowers and takes them to her studio. "I don't set everything up at once," she explains. "I take one flower out and paint it, which can take a few days, and then I bring in another one to continue the painting. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish."

Her busiest time is spring and early summer when the tulips bloom, followed by the poppies. "They all bloom together, and you're so busy," she says. However, she also finds beauty in the gradual decay of flowers. For example, with tulips, "you bring them in and put them in water, then leave them for a day, and they change shape. They open up and look amazing. At first, they seem dull, but they keep changing with twists and turns."

Susan has always loved plants. "I studied botany in school and used to collect wildflowers from the countryside," she recalls. "I wasn't really interested in gardening back then; I thought garden flowers looked fake, like silk or plastic ones sold in some shops. To me, only wildflowers were real. I was fascinated by how they could grow in tough places, like cracks in rocks or on cliffs."

Today, her garden features many plants from distant lands, but they thrive just as well as they do in their native places like China or the Himalayas. She has a relaxed attitude towards her garden, similar to a caring aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause serious trouble. With two upcoming exhibitions to prepare for and plenty of inspiration right outside her door, finding time to work in the garden has been challenging. She now hires an extra gardener, but she knows that to stay connected to her art, "you have to get your hands dirty."

**Title: Changes in Brackham**

In March, strong storms caused many trees in the Brackham area to fall. The town lost two large lime trees from the old market square. This change upset many residents who preferred the town's traditional look. Normally, Chief Inspector Douglas Pelham, the head of the local police, would have been among those upset. However, during the storm, he was too ill to notice because he was suffering from bronchitis for the first time in his life. 

When he first felt pain in his head and tightness in his chest, his wife, Molly, urged him to see a doctor. He refused, thinking the police needed him. As a result, he became forgetful and irritable. Eventually, his colleague, Sergeant Lloyd, took him to the doctor, and he had no energy left to argue. Soon after, he got his antibiotics and returned home, where Molly sent him straight to bed.

On Thursday morning, when Molly told him that the walnut tree in their garden had fallen, he was too weak to fully understand. Later that evening, he asked if the house was damaged and felt relieved to hear it was not. He then covered himself with the sheets. It was not until Saturday, when the antibiotics worked and he felt better, that he noticed how much the loss of the walnut tree changed the living room's appearance.

The Pelhams lived in a large house with a big garden, which they had bought without regrets. The garden had given them a sense of privacy. Before the storm, the walnut tree had provided a nice view from the living room, creating interesting light patterns that hid the worn furniture they had brought from their old home. Now, without the tree, the room felt too bright, exposing the shabby furniture. The view from the window was also unpleasant; the tall house next door, which had been hidden by the tree, was now visible, with its unattractive purple bricks and many windows that seemed to watch the Pelhams.

"Doesn't it look terrible?" Pelham asked his wife. But Molly, standing in the doorway, seemed more happy than upset. "I've been saying this since we moved in. We need to buy a new sofa, no matter the cost."

**Living in the Valley**

We had been living in our valley for sixteen months when we first understood the dangers that could come from the surrounding hills and threaten our survival. It was the year when the storms arrived early, even before November ended. Until then, we felt safe and protected in our valley below the hills. Soon, snow began to fall. Within a day, it was about 15 centimeters deep. It almost completely blocked our lane and made the path by the stream slippery and dangerous. However, in the hills, the snow was much deeper and lasted longer. Up there, the wind blew fiercely. In our valley, we only felt sudden gusts of wind; the trees swayed, but their branches stayed strong. Still, we knew we had reasons to worry. The snow and wind were annoying, but they did not truly trouble us. The real threat was the river, the Ryburn, which usually flowed gently but now posed a danger. It reminded us of what could happen if the water from the hills had not been controlled by a series of dams many years ago.

Soon, the snow began to melt. Day after day, we watched dark clouds gather over the hills to the west. These ominous grey clouds spread over the valleys, twisting and turning, warning us of what was coming. We had seen enough of the sky; now we focused on the river, which was becoming fuller and wilder each day. The snow was washed away as more rain fell from the clouds, but the reservoir in the hills was filling up and nearing a dangerous level. Then it happened – for the first time in years, the reservoir overflowed. It was like Niagara Falls, as water surged over the dam and poured into the stream below. The river seemed furious as the water rushed down towards its lower stretches. Just a couple of meters from our cottage, the stream looked wild beneath the bridge. It was deeper than we had ever seen it so close to our home, angrily pushing against its banks. For three days, we prayed that it would stay below its limits. Fortunately, our prayers were answered as the dam held, and the waters began to go down.

In the past, before the dam was built, the river had flooded nearby villages in such a rage. Now, the dam controls the river's flow, and usually, everything is fine. The large amount of water from the hills, caused by snow and heavy rain, stays behind the dam, with only occasional overflow. Because of this protection, we can enjoy the huge clouds over the valley and appreciate the great power of the river. Thanks to the dam, we feel that our home in the valley is still safe and secure.

Film critic Mark Adams reflects on his ten years of work for a newspaper called The Front Page. Writing film articles for The Front Page was my first real job. Before that, I had done some reviews of novels for other newspapers, films for a magazine, and various tasks for the radio. This is how I met Tom Seaton, the first arts editor of The Front Page, who also worked in radio and television. He hired me, but since Tom was not mainly a journalist, he was not very careful in choosing his team. 

Initially, he wanted a group of critics to cover art forms that didn’t need special knowledge, like books, TV, theatre, film, and radio. We would have a weekly lunch to discuss which topics to cover, and there would be guests to keep things friendly. At that time, it felt like a dream: a new newspaper, and I was part of the team. It seemed unlikely that a new paper could succeed in a crowded market. I even thought a millionaire was pretending to hire me. I lacked self-confidence. The first time I saw someone reading the newspaper on the London Underground and turning to a page with my review, I felt embarrassed.

Tom's idea for a team of critics did not work out as planned. Although it was a good idea, we didn’t meet as expected, and everything was done over the phone. It turned out that the public preferred to have a reviewer focus on one subject, so I chose to write about films. Without Tom's initial support, we might not have developed the current system, where I write a detailed weekly piece about one film. This way of working suits me well. I wouldn’t enjoy the typical film critic role, which requires reviewing every new film. That routine would quickly make me feel bored. I would dread sitting down on a Monday morning, thinking, "What terrible film do I have to watch now?" 

The freedom I have allows me to expand my arguments or, during a dull week, to create something interesting from little. But what is my role in the public eye? I believe people choose films based on stars, marketing, or the director. There is also loyalty to certain types of films. It is rare for someone who dislikes westerns to buy a ticket for one after reading a review, or for a romantic film lover to skip a love story because of a critic's opinion. So, if a film review isn’t really a guide for consumers, what is it? I don’t feel I need to be "right" about a movie. I also don’t think there should be a set number of "great" or "bad" films each year. My job is simply to present an argument. I am not a judge, and I don’t want to be one.

**Why would a schoolgirl want to swim 1500m, cycle 40km, and then run 10km? Because "it's fun."**

**Teenager with a passion for endurance**

**WANTED:** A sports-loving training partner for a triathlete, preferably female. This is a chance to work with a potential Olympic champion. You should be very enthusiastic about distance running (regular 15km sessions), distance swimming (enjoying winter training in cold rivers is a plus), and distance cycling (a love for 100km rides is helpful). You must be able to do all three activities without taking a break.

The triathlon is becoming one of the most popular Olympic sports. It has attracted large crowds who are both fascinated and shocked by athletes who swim 1500m, cycle 40km, and then run 10km without stopping. While it may be exciting for spectators, what drives triathletes to push their bodies so hard? What makes a talented 17-year-old, with great academic achievements, give up so much for the challenges of this sport?

Melanie Sears has not yet learned the common phrases about personal satisfaction, mental challenges, and setting higher goals that most athletes use when asked similar questions. "You swim 1500m, then run out of the water and jump on your bike, still wet. Of course, then you get cold. After the 40km bike ride, you have to run 10km, which feels long when you’re tired. But it’s really fun, and it’s all worth it in the end," she explains.

Melanie entered her first triathlon at 14. "I won the junior section, but I was the only junior competing. It felt so easy that I waved at my teammates as I went around." Feeling confident, she entered the National Championships. Although she had the second fastest swim and the fastest run, she did not place well. "I was following a man, and suddenly we reached the sea. We realized we had gone the wrong way. I ended up cycling 20 kilometers too far. I cried the whole time I was running."

But she did not give up and is determined to keep going. "Sometimes I wish I could stop, because then the pain would end, but I’m afraid that if I let myself stop just once, I would want to do it again." This determination earns her respect from Steve Trew, the sport's coaching director. "I just tested her fitness," he says, "and she worked so hard on the running machine that it finally threw her off into a wall. She gave it her all, while most people would step off when they realize they can’t go any further; she just kept going."

Melanie was the top junior in this year's European Triathlon Championships, finishing 13th. "I was almost as good as the top three in swimming and running, but much slower in cycling. That’s why I’m working very hard on it." She is trying to convince her supportive parents, who will pay the £1,300 cost of her trip to New Zealand for this year's World Championships, to buy a £2,000 bike (it’s a special deal, with £1,000 off) so she can compete in national 25 km and 100 km races later this year.

However, there is a cost to her dedication. Her intense training has made her somewhat of a recluse. "I don’t have a social life," she admits. "I’m not a party person anyway. After two hours of hard swimming on Friday nights, I just want to sleep. But I do call and write to the other girls on the team." What do they talk about? Boys? Clothes? "No, we discuss our times and achievements."

Where will all this focus lead? Melanie has tried other events, including the triathlon "sprint," where you only swim 750m, cycle 20km, and run 5km. She wants to enter even tougher competitions than the triathlon. "The big problem is, I have no one my age to train with," she says. It’s interesting, isn’t it?

**The Collectors**

Amanda Roy discusses her passion for collecting and why many people share this hobby. Collecting is a popular activity, with one in three adults participating. It is a world filled with excitement, envy, and joy. However, if you decide to collect, remember: only collect items you truly love.

Since ancient times, people have felt the need to collect. Early humans gathered pebbles and wore them as necklaces, attracted by their shapes and colors. This was their first attempt to collect objects for intellectual and spiritual reasons. Over the years, not much has changed; children still collect stones and seashells simply for their beauty.

I have been a collector all my life, gathering everything from flowers like tulips to pottery and paintings. My first collection was stones from my parents' garden. When I was six, I attended a school in a remote, cold part of England. When my parents visited, they took me to a local museum filled with objects collected by others. I was captivated by these items. Interestingly, I am not alone in my interest; many adults share this passion.

People collect for various reasons, and it has become a topic of interest. Some believe it is the only part of their lives where they feel in control. For me, it is simply a joyful activity. One famous collector was the Duc de Berry in France, who had a "room of wonders" filled with natural and man-made curiosities, like coconut shell cups and carved ivory beads. Catherine the Great of Russia collected over 4,000 paintings. However, you don’t need to be wealthy to start a collection. I have collected diverse items, from tulip bulbs to china cups, with great determination.

I remember convincing another tulip collector to sell me a special bulb. I planted it and cared for it, but one year it disappeared—stolen by another collector. I also collected 350 American rag dolls, searching across the USA for different designs. Sadly, this collection was lost in a house fire. The next morning, I stood in my front hall, looking at the ruins of my furniture and collection, unsure which loss hurt more.

I have always been fascinated by how collections change hands. A silver spoon that belonged to a king or a poet adds value to items traded in markets. As certain small objects become popular among collectors, their prices rise. For example, toys from the 1950s are now considered valuable, especially if you kept their original boxes. Unfortunately, I threw away both the boxes and the toys!

**My Line of Work**

Four people talk about their jobs.

**Lisa - Exhibition Programmes Organiser, Science Museum**  
I organize temporary exhibitions. This means I plan and design the exhibition and promote it. I need to learn about the exhibition topic and talk to experts to understand the main themes and goals. I decide what objects and pictures to display and ensure the public can understand the exhibition. This involves planning interactive displays, workshops, and performances. I also work with engineers and electricians to ensure the exhibition is safe for visitors. Before the exhibition opens, I help create brochures and leaflets to inform people about it.

**Janet - Teacher of London Taxi Drivers**  
When I arrive at 7:30 a.m., I first check the accounts. Then, I see what new maps and documents we need for the taxi-driver test. By midday, about 50 students are in class, learning how to navigate the city. They find the most direct routes, considering one-way streets and turns. I step in when there are disagreements, like whether a right turn is allowed at a certain junction. As they prepare for the test, I give them a simple route but tell them they must take a different one because the road is closed. This forces them to think creatively about their routes.

**Sarah - Marine Conservationist**  
I live by the coast and work from home. My job involves answering phone inquiries, creating educational materials, and organizing training courses. Sometimes, I go to our main office, but I mostly work along the coast. I collaborate with schools and study centers, running courses for coastal managers and decision-makers about marine life. I take them out to sea to help them understand the underwater environment better, which often changes their perspectives. I feel fortunate because conservation is my passion, but since I work for a charity, I constantly seek funding and cannot always achieve everything I want.

**Chris - Map and Atlas Publisher**  
My job is quite diverse. I ensure our publishing program meets market needs and maintain a stock of about 300 books. We have high standards for information and content. We receive many letters from readers about issues like international boundaries, which require careful responses. I discuss future projects and current sales with co-publishers. I work with a passionate team, which makes the job enjoyable. However, like many jobs, there is too much administration, which takes time away from more interesting tasks like product development and design.

**No Title**

Every June, we traveled to Ireland. Since the four of us started going on holidays together, we spent the first two weeks of the month at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It is a large house by the sea, near the village of Ardbeag. The English couple, the Malseeds, who own the house, have made some additions, but they did it very tastefully. Strafe discovered Glencorn for us. He found an advertisement when the Malseeds still needed to promote their place. One evening, he suggested, "How about this?" and read the details. The summer before, we had gone to a hotel recommended by friends, but it was a disappointment because the food was terrible.

The four of us have been playing cards together for a long time: Dekko, Strafe, Cynthia, and me. They call me Milly, although my real name is Dorothy Milson. Dekko got his nickname at school; Dekko Deacon sounds nice, I guess. He and Strafe were schoolmates, which is probably why we call Strafe by his last name, like the teachers did. We are all about the same age and live close to the town where the Malseeds lived before moving from England to Ireland. We always think it’s a funny coincidence.

"How very nice," Mrs. Malseed said, welcoming us again this year with a smile. She seems to know when guests are arriving because she is usually waiting in the large hall that always smells of flowers. "Arthur, take the luggage up," she instructed the old porter. "Rose, Tulip, Lily, and Geranium," she named the rooms we would stay in. Instead of numbers, Mrs. Malseed painted flowers on the doors. In winter, when few guests come to Glencorn Lodge, she takes care of small details like that, while her husband handles repairs and redecorating.

"Well, well, well," Mr. Malseed said as he entered the hall from the kitchen. "A hundred thousand welcomes," he greeted us in the Irish way. He smiled widely, his dark brown eyes sparkling, making us feel like we were more than just another group of hotel guests. Everyone smiled, and I could sense that our holiday had truly begun. Nothing had changed at Glencorn; everything was perfect.

Kitty from the dining room came out to greet us. "You look younger every year, all four of you," she said, making everyone in the hall laugh again. Arthur led the way to our rooms, carrying as much luggage as he could and returning for the rest. After dinner, we played cards for a while, but we didn’t play too long because we were still tired from the journey. 

In the lounge, there was a man alone and a French couple. There were other guests at dinner, of course, because Glencorn Lodge is always full in June. From our table by the window, we could see some guests walking on the lawns and others taking the cliff path to the beach.
