In the morning, we would do the same: walk along the sands to Ardbeag and have coffee at the hotel there, returning in time for lunch. In the afternoon, we would drive somewhere. I knew this routine well because over the years, we had developed this pattern. Since we first came here, we had all fallen in love with the beautiful landscape in every season.

**Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**

Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex, shares her experiences as a chalet girl in Val d'Isere, France. This is her second year in this role, where she cooks and cleans for guests who come to ski and stay in wooden houses called chalets. Sarah graduated last summer from Oxford Brookes University with a degree in French and History of Art. She views being a chalet girl as a fun way to spend a year or two before starting a more permanent career. "It's a good way to make contacts. I meet successful people every week," she explains.

Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to work. After having her own breakfast, she prepares breakfast for the guests, which includes porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. By 9:30 a.m., after the guests have finished eating, she cleans up and either makes afternoon tea for the guests or cleans the rooms, which she finds to be the least enjoyable part of her job. By around 11 a.m., she is ready to ski herself, enjoying the slopes until about 4:30 p.m. 

After skiing, Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner. She takes a shower first but avoids sleeping, as she believes it would make her feel worse. Dinner, which is a three-course meal, is served at 8 p.m., and coffee is usually ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans the kitchen, as she dislikes coming back to a messy space the next morning. Sometimes she chats with the guests, but other times they prefer privacy. "Good guests can make a week wonderful," she says, recalling a fun breakfast experience, while noting that some weeks are not as enjoyable.

Sarah lives in a chalet with friends, and they often go out around 11 p.m. They usually start their night at a place called Bananas, then might go to G Jay's and finish at Dick's T-Bar. However, she makes sure not to stay out too late on Saturdays, as Sundays are her busiest days. "It's a tough day," she admits, "especially when you have to cook breakfast with a headache."

On Sundays, Sarah starts work earlier, preparing breakfast for guests leaving by 7 a.m. Once they leave, she cleans quickly, clearing breakfast, stripping beds, and getting everything ready for new guests. If she hasn't done the shopping on Saturday, she does it now. By around 3 p.m., after cleaning, she prepares tea for the new guests who arrive around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes they seem confused and have many questions, which she finds amusing.

Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests who need ski equipment by taking them to the ski shop and getting a ride back. Soon, it’s time for dinner again, and sometimes she enjoys a drink afterward, but often she is too tired and goes to bed early.

Miss Rita Cohen was a small, pale girl who looked much younger than Seymour's daughter, Marie, but she said she was six years older. One day, she visited his factory wearing overalls and large shoes, with messy hair framing her pretty face. Seymour found it hard to believe that she was studying at the University of Pennsylvania and researching the leather industry in New Jersey for her Master's degree. 

Several times a year, someone would contact Seymour to ask if they could visit his factory. Sometimes, he would help students by answering their questions over the phone or giving them a short tour if they seemed serious. Rita was almost as small as the children from Marie's third-grade class, who had visited the factory years ago to see how gloves were made. Seymour remembered how Marie had been fascinated by the steam-heated brass hands used to shape the gloves, which she called "pancake hands."

Rita asked, "How many pieces come in a shipment?" Seymour replied, "Between twenty and twenty-five thousand." She took notes and asked, "Do they come directly to your shipping department?" He explained, "They go to the tannery first. We buy the material, and they prepare it for us. My grandfather, father, and I all worked in the tannery here in town. Have you ever been inside one?" 

"Not yet," she said. 

"You should visit a tannery if you want to write about leather. I can arrange that for you. It's a basic place. The technology has improved, but it’s not very different from what it was hundreds of years ago. It's tough work. Tanning is one of the oldest industries; they found 6,000-year-old tanning artifacts in Turkey. The first clothing was just animal skins that were tanned by smoking them. It’s a fascinating subject. My father is a leather expert; you should talk to him. He can talk for two days about gloves. Glovemakers love their trade. 

"Have you ever seen anything being made, Miss Cohen?" 

"Not really," she replied. 

"Never seen anything manufactured?" 

"I saw my mother bake a cake when I was a child." 

Seymour laughed. She was innocent and eager to learn, reminding him of Marie, who was much taller than Rita but shared her spirit and intelligence. 

"I have an idea. We will take you through the entire glove-making process. Come on! We’re going to make you a pair of gloves, and you will watch them being made from start to finish. What size do you wear?"

**Is It a Tough Job?** Chris Arnot asks four people with dream jobs if they are as great as they seem.

**A. Raquel Graham**  
Raquel Graham calls from a taxi on her way to the airport. She cannot meet tomorrow because her boss needs her in Los Angeles. As a personal assistant to a pop star, she must travel around the world quickly. Raquel loves her job and has a good relationship with her boss. However, she has one small issue—she dislikes flying. "On a nine-hour flight to California, I usually take sleeping pills to help me relax," she admits. Her worst experience was flying on Concorde. "It felt so cramped with those tiny windows." When she is back on the ground, she works in offices in Manchester and London. She has to do some boring tasks like organizing schedules, attending meetings with lawyers and accountants, planning travel, and making more travel arrangements. She did not apply for this job; a chance meeting with a pop group’s manager led to her working behind the scenes. She also took a secretarial course in the evenings. Five years later, she was in the right place when her boss needed a personal assistant.

**B. David Brown**  
David Brown has worked as an accountant and a golf caddy, which is someone who carries a golfer's bags. Overall, he prefers caddying because golf is his passion. However, there are downsides. He earns a small flat fee plus a percentage of the winnings, which averages between £25,000 and £35,000, but much of that goes to travel and hotels. He started caddying for golfer Greg Norman when he was 31. "You’re not just carrying bags. You give advice, use your knowledge of the game, and try to understand the course," he explains. Recently, his accounting skills were recognized by European Tour Productions, and he became a statistical data administrator. He collects and analyzes statistics from the caddies, which are valuable for TV commentators, golf magazines, and the players.

**C. Martin Fern**  
Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' section of a daily newspaper, and one of his easier tasks is to taste food at the best restaurants. What does he think about restaurants with high prices? "For those who can afford it, it’s their choice," he says. "I’d rather spend £120 on a memorable meal than buy a microwave." His cooking talent led to a friend offering him a food column in a Saturday Review. At that time, he was the creative director of an advertising agency, and it provided him with extra income. When he was 42, another newspaper offered him a full-time job. "It meant a 50% cut in my guaranteed income," he says, "but it was a chance to turn my passion into a career." He still cooks at home and tries to stay fit by cycling a couple of miles to the nearest tube station.

**D. Dick Prince**  
"I started writing children's stories about 20 years ago," says Dick Prince, one of Britain’s most popular children's authors. "Before that, I loved words and enjoyed writing, but I mostly wrote poetry. Then I had an idea for a story. Having been a farmer, I knew about the problem of chickens being killed by a fox. So, I wrote a story called *The Fox Busters*, which became my first published children's book." Where do his ideas come from? "It’s not easy; I have to work hard at them," he says. "I usually do this in the mornings. I don’t wake up at dawn, unfortunately. After lunch, I spend a couple of hours typing what I wrote in the morning—all with one finger on an old portable typewriter instead of a laptop." He receives between 50 and 100 letters a week, which he enjoys the most about being a writer. He tries to answer them all, but now he has some secretarial help.

In the lumberyard by the lake, where trees were turned into boards for building, there was an old two-story brick building. Surrounding it were large piles of soft sawdust, creating golden mounds that extended to the blue lake. That afternoon, feeling bored, a group of boys followed Michael up the ladder to the roof of the old building. They sat with their legs hanging over the edge, looking out at the lake. Suddenly, Michael said, "I dare you to jump down." Without thinking, he jumped off the roof and landed in the sawdust, rolling around and laughing. "I dare you all!" he shouted. "You're all cowards," he teased, trying to get them to jump too.

Still laughing, he watched as they hesitated on the roof, looking scared. One by one, they jumped down, relieved to land safely. In the warm afternoon sun, they lay on the sawdust, telling jokes until one of them suggested going back up to the roof to jump again. Although they were not very excited, they climbed back up and jumped off in a determined manner until only Michael was left. The others called up to him, "Come on, Mike. What's wrong?"

Michael wanted to join them, but he stayed at the edge of the roof, nervously licking his lips and grinning foolishly, wondering why the jump had seemed easier the first time. For a while, they thought he was just joking, but then they noticed him clenching his fists. He tried to count to ten and jump, but when that didn’t work, he took a deep breath and closed his eyes. Eventually, the boys began to laugh at him, growing tired of waiting as dinner time approached. "Come on, you're a coward! Do you think we're going to sit here all night?" they shouted. When he still didn’t move, they started to leave, still teasing him.

"Who started this?" he called after them. But he remained on the edge of the roof, staring unhappily at the ground. He stayed there alone for nearly an hour while the sun set slowly over the lake. His clothes were damp from nervous sweat. Finally, he closed his eyes, jumped off the roof, and landed heavily in the sawdust, lying there for a long time. The yard was quiet; the workers had gone home. As he lay there, he wondered why he had been unable to jump earlier. Eventually, he got up slowly and walked home, feeling ashamed and wanting to avoid everyone.

He was so late for dinner that his stepmother said coldly, "You should be able to get home in time for dinner by now. If you won't come home, maybe you should stay out tonight." She was a strong woman with fair skin, a hint of grey in her hair, and a patient smile. Although she spoke firmly, Michael, with his dark, gloomy face, hardly heard her; he was still thinking about the boys' grinning faces and their laughter.

**Careers Advice**

Are you unhappy in your job and unsure how to change it? Kitty Doherty offers some helpful advice. Many people looking to change their careers seek help from a careers adviser. You will need to write a brief personal history and take several tests called 'psychometrics'. Afterward, you will receive a summary of the results, along with career suggestions and any retraining you might need.

I decided to try Career Analysts, one of the largest career advice organizations. Taking the career test felt like being back in a science exam. I was in a group of about ten people, answering questions under time pressure. I reminded myself that it wasn't about passing or failing. It was difficult to see how the psychometric tests could accurately represent me. The tests included tasks like finding mistakes in lists of names and numbers and matching similar shapes. 

After the tests, I had a long conversation with an adviser. Based on our discussion and the test results, he created a report with his observations and recommendations. I agreed with most of his conclusions, but I was a bit disappointed to learn that I had performed poorly in the scientific, technical, and practical tests. I’m sure many sick people are relieved I didn’t become a nurse! However, it was comforting to hear that I had made the right choices regarding journalism.

Changing your career doesn’t always mean a complete shift. Last March, after losing her job as a marketing manager at a large insurance company, 25-year-old Donna Laney sought help from Career Analysts. She said, "Losing my job was a great chance for me to reflect on my career. I wanted to reassess my skills and interests." Some of the results surprised her. "I didn’t realize I had a talent for design. But in the end, I had to weigh the cost of retraining in design against my financial responsibilities," she explained. Other suggestions included taking a year off to work in the Far East. Ultimately, she decided to use her existing skills and move into a field that suited her better than insurance. Now, she works as a Public Relations officer. She believes she could have reached this point without Career Analysts, but they helped her understand what she truly wanted to do. She has recommended the service to several friends, all of whom are satisfied.

Some people feel they would not have made significant changes without help. For example, 26-year-old Juliet Greene visited Career Counselling Services and made important life decisions. After six years at a major bank, she found her job boring and wanted a new challenge. She went to the counselling service with an open mind. The tests indicated she was interested in sciences. "I had four sessions with an adviser. The third session was recorded, which was helpful because you forget much of what you say. After the fourth meeting, I carefully considered the test results and decided to study geology. I plan to start a degree course later this year. I believe the advice from Career Counselling Services was worth the cost. I feel much happier and more positive now."

However, career advice does not work for everyone. Amanda Margetts, a 24-year-old sales representative, said, "I reached a point in my career where I felt lost. I thought a careers adviser might suggest something new. Although I received many ideas, I rejected them because they either required a significant pay cut or a lot of retraining. I didn’t learn anything new about myself. You have to share a lot of personal information with the adviser, and I felt that if I had told a friend the same things, they would have given me similar advice."

**Fun at the Dentist's?**

If you visit W. Lloyd Jerome's dental office in the center of Glasgow, you will notice bright, modern paintings on the walls and a stylish blue couch where patients sit while he examines their teeth. Jerome explains, "Fifty percent of people only go to the dentist when they are in pain instead of for regular check-ups. This is often because they are scared." To change this, he has worked to create a space where people feel comfortable. For example, he decided not to wear a white coat, as many people link it to pain. He believes that dental treatment should happen in a relaxing, interesting, and enjoyable environment.

This approach may surprise many, as most people associate dental visits with discomfort or clinical settings. Jerome states, "If people are relaxed, entertained, and treated well, they will forget their past negative experiences." One of his innovative relaxation methods is using virtual-reality headsets. "We were the first dental practice in Britain to use them, and they are very popular. During the initial check-up, the patient sits comfortably on the blue couch and watches a film about underwater wildlife while I examine their teeth. Then, the headset switches to a special camera that gives the patient a visual tour of their mouth."

Interestingly, most patients seem to enjoy this part of their dental visit. Another important aspect is that the office smells more like a perfume shop than a dentist's office. Today, it has a pleasant orange scent. Jerome explains, "When people enter, I want them to realize through all their senses that this is not a typical dentist's visit. Smell is very important. The usual dental smell can make someone anxious if they are afraid of dentists." I found the gentle scent in the office very nice.

Although Jerome is known as Glasgow's most stylish dentist, he emphasizes that he takes his work seriously. While relaxation techniques are important, the quality of treatment is the top priority. For instance, Jerome uses a special tool that sprays warm water on the teeth to clean them instead of scraping, which can feel strange at first but is not painful if the patient is relaxed.

Five years ago, Jerome traveled to the United States to study dental techniques. "One thing I learned is that making it easier for the patient also makes it easier for the dentist," he says. He believes his patient-focused approach is part of a gradual shift towards a more relaxed style in British dentistry.

At that moment, a patient arrives. Jerome quickly greets him, offers a cup of tea (herbal or regular), asks what video he would like to watch, and gently guides him to the chair. The patient seems to enjoy this luxurious treatment, and it’s easy to see why. The office feels more like an elegant beauty salon than a typical dental practice.

**Bitter Water Hits the Big Time**

Chocolate, which originated in South America, is now a multi-million pound global industry. During Easter, British people spend over £230 million on chocolate, accounting for eight percent of all chocolate sales. Only at Christmas do people consume more chocolate. 

Although large-scale chocolate production started in the last century, the cacao plant was first cultivated by the Aztec, Toltec, and Mayan civilizations in Central America over three thousand years ago. The cacao tree is a tropical evergreen found in Africa, South and Central America, the West Indies, and Southeast Asia. Its fruit is the size of a melon and contains 20 to 40 seeds. When dried, these seeds become cacao beans, which are used to make chocolate. In English-speaking countries, they are often incorrectly called cocoa beans, a mistake that dates back to the 17th century when they were also referred to as cacoa and cocao beans. 

The Aztecs used cocoa beans as currency and made a drink called xocoatl, which means "bitter water" in the Aztec language, Nahuatl. This drink was flavored with spices and served during ceremonies and to welcome guests. The Spanish found it more enjoyable when mixed with cinnamon and sugar, but this recipe did not reach the rest of Europe for another hundred years. 

In the late 17th century, chocolate houses opened in major European cities where people gathered to drink chocolate. Until the last century, the drink was made from solid chocolate blocks that had to be melted in hot water. In 1826, CJ van Houten from the Netherlands invented chocolate powder by removing most of the cocoa butter from crushed beans. The modern chocolate bar began in 1847 when a Bristol company, Fry and Sons, mixed cocoa butter with pure chocolate liquor and sugar to create a solid bar. A Swiss company later added milk solids, resulting in milk chocolate. 

At the turn of the century, the British chocolate market was largely controlled by French companies. In 1879, the English company Cadbury named their Birmingham factory Bournville, hoping to attract some French charm. However, Cadbury's Dairy Milk bar, originally called Dairymaid in 1905, became popular due to clever advertising that linked it to the health benefits of milk from the English countryside, making it a competitor to luxurious French brands. 

Currently, chocolate consumption in Britain has stabilized at about four bars per week, prompting manufacturers to find new ways to attract customers. One recent marketing strategy is the "extended line," where chocolate bars are transformed into ice cream, soft drinks, or desserts to appeal to chocolate lovers who are bored with traditional snacks. 

Meanwhile, cacao farmers are still struggling due to a drop in cocoa bean prices in the late 1980s. Many small-scale farmers went out of business. So, as you enjoy your next chocolate bar, consider the challenges faced by these farmers.

**THE SHELL ARTIST**

At 83 years old, Peter Cooke has become a skilled artist. He still wants to try new things, like making paper and working with feathers, but for now, he focuses on creating beautiful objects from shells. As he shows me his work in his apartment, he asks, "Am I boring you?" There is a fine line between being boring and being passionate, but Cooke is definitely passionate, thanks to his charm and the beauty of his creations.

He points to some shell-covered decorations above his fireplace. "I won’t mind if people don’t buy them because I love them," he says. He never intended to sell his work, but about five years ago, friends encouraged him to have an exhibition. They spoke to an art gallery owner, and he ended up having a successful exhibition in London, selling 70% of his pieces. His second exhibition just opened, featuring 86 items, with prices starting at £225 for a shell flower in a crystal vase. Cooke says he has no control over the prices and is open about them. He believes his work is unique, and the gallery owner told him that once he stops creating, people will want his pieces even more.

Cooke wishes he had started this art earlier in life, as he feels he could have made even more amazing things. Although he still has many ideas, he feels limited physically compared to when he began. However, his work is far from the typical shell crafts found in tourist shops. He describes himself as having a "miniature mind," which has led him to create boxes covered in thousands of tiny shells, detailed pictures made from shells, and baskets of incredibly realistic flowers.

He has developed his own techniques and uses materials he finds. For example, he uses cardboard from laundered shirts for flower bases, a special glue bought in bulk, and washing-up liquid to clean the shells. "I have an idea of what I want to do, and it just happens," he says about his creative process. Yet, the detail, color, and symmetry in his work are clearly intentional.

Cooke searches for beautiful, tiny shells not just on the beaches of Norfolk, but also in places like France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines. He insists that he only collects dead shells and defends himself against accusations of harming the environment. "When I collect shells, I see many people stepping on them much faster than I can gather them. The sea also breaks them down. I would never take shells with living creatures inside, but once they are empty, why shouldn’t I collect them?" His argument is strong, especially considering the beauty he creates from the shells he finds.

**The Schoolgirl Model**

Kira Langer is a 15-year-old girl who models and appears on magazine covers. When she is not working, she studies for her school exams. Jane Laidlaw shares more about her.

The receptionist at Kira's modeling agency told me she would be late. I thought about all the negative things I had read about models, like being difficult or vain. I worried she might not show up at all. But when Kira arrived, she was smiling, relaxed, and accompanied by her mother. She wore a simple black dress and trainers, showing no signs of being spoiled. Kira was friendly, tall, and pretty. 

Since Kira is under 16, she must have an adult with her for work. Her mother, who looked proud of her daughter, was just a regular mom. Kira seemed a bit confused by her sudden fame, which was unexpected. It was her older sister who encouraged her to enter a modeling competition. Kira initially said no, but her sister sent in some photos anyway. When Kira learned she was a finalist, she was at school. This achievement gave her the confidence to continue, and she won the competition easily. The Select model agency in London quickly offered her work.

Now, Kira finds it challenging to balance her two lives. Her friends and teachers are proud of her, but some classmates make rude comments about her success, saying she thinks too highly of herself. Kira finds this hard to handle, especially since she is not arrogant. She explains, "People think I’ve changed just because I’m a model, but the only change is that I’m more confident and can stand up for myself."

Being a busy model affects her social life. The agency can call her at any time for a job the next day. She cannot make plans with friends because her schedule is uncertain. However, her friends understand and do not complain about her modeling commitments.

Kira has the looks, talent, and support to have a successful career ahead of her, even before finishing her school exams. As I wrap up the interview, I ask her what she would do if she didn’t have her beauty. She pauses and replies, "I’d like to do what you’re doing."

**Father and Son Start Gold Rush**

Terence and Chris Madden have traveled from the cold north of Canada to the warm lands of Africa in search of valuable metals. This father and son team—one an explorer and the other a mineral expert—believe their mine on a Welsh mountain could hold up to 10,000 ounces of gold. After ten years of digging in the Welsh hills, they are sure they are very close to a gold vein worth five million dollars. Terence, 68, from Liverpool, said, "As we dig, we are finding high levels of gold; now we just need to dig a few more meters to where it is concentrated."

The pair have dedicated their lives to finding gold. Their search began when Terence read about gold worth millions hidden in the "Dolgellau gold belt," an area near the town of Dolgellau in Wales. While reading old mining journals and newspapers at the Welsh National Library in Aberystwyth, they chose the most promising land to explore. After clearing away plants and finding pieces of gold in the rocks, they spent the last ten years getting permission from landowners, taking soil samples, and removing old cars and trash. They dug out 150 tonnes of greenstone rock to create a tunnel and a 10-meter shaft.

Now, they are running low on money. Having spent their savings on this dream, they need to convince a backer to invest £50,000 to dig a few more meters to reach the gold. Chris Madden says, "Right now, this seems unlikely, but we have several people we can contact."

As news of their dig spread through the valleys last week, the allure of gold began to attract the attention of local residents as well as other gold diggers. Dolgellau depends on tourism, and locals are cautiously optimistic. Peter Woolven, manager of the Royal Ship Hotel, said, "If they are right, it would bring more visitors here, but if they find gold, I hope millions of people don’t come and disturb the hillside."

The Welsh gold industry has greatly declined since its peak in the late 1880s when thousands worked in many mines across the countryside. One of the last remaining mines, Clogau-St David's, which made wedding rings for the Queen and the Princess of Wales, closed a month ago. However, individual gold diggers are returning. George Hall, another prospector, plans to dig a tunnel deep into the hill on the other side of the ridge from the Maddens. Hall, 70, said, "Searching for gold is very emotional. It’s adventurous and exciting, the thrill of uncovering hidden treasure. Maybe I’ll be lucky this time."

**IN HOT WATER**

Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and researches marine geochemistry, which involves studying the chemical processes in the sea. Rachel is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she is not teaching, she descends into a small steel vehicle designed for underwater exploration, diving three kilometers down to study underwater volcanoes. 

Inside the vehicle, space is very limited, and she can touch the two pilots. They are accustomed to these cramped conditions, where they cannot stand or move freely, and they must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last up to 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface. If there is an emergency and they need to ascend quickly, they can press a panic button. This releases a small escape vessel that rises quickly to the surface, similar to a ping-pong ball in water. "No one has tested it yet, but I don't think it would be a pleasant experience," she says.

Rachel recalls her first time in the vehicle, which was on a ship's deck. An instructor guided her through emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They were assessing how she would react in such a confined space. Now, Rachel has completed six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew to a site five days west of the Canary Islands, where there is a large area of underwater volcanoes emitting black smoke. The Russian team was dropping off scientific equipment to study the impact of a multinational program that would create a hole 150 meters through a volcano.

When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. "Two-thirds of my salary comes from teaching, which I enjoy, but I do it to support my research on the 'black smokers,'" she explains. This term refers to underwater volcanoes that release water that looks like black smoke at a rate of one meter per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees Celsius.

Rachel shares a frightening experience from her first dive with an American team. They were towing equipment with a 50-meter rope when there was a sudden explosion. The shock waves hit their vehicle, and she thought, "I'm going to die." They waited in silence, and when nothing happened, they were overwhelmed with relief— they were still alive!

"Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is an incredible adventure. Every time I look out of the porthole and see those chimneys, I feel a sense of wonder. Here I am at the bottom of the sea, and no one else on this planet has ever seen them before. I studied the black smokers for three years for my PhD, and seeing them in person was an amazing experience."

I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and a bit sunburned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body was exhausted, and my mind was tired of dealing with foreign schedules, currencies, and languages. "Never again," I told myself as I returned home. I repeated this every year after. All I needed was one train ticket, and since I was under twenty-five, I could travel anywhere in Europe for a whole month. 

Once you learn to sleep in a train corridor, regular beds feel different. Carrying all your belongings in a backpack makes you travel simply and can lead to wasteful habits, like burning socks that smell bad or throwing away finished books. However, this carefree attitude is part of the Inter-Rail experience, where common sense can be forgotten along with your paperback and socks. All it takes is one of those tickets in your hand. 

A system that allows young people to travel through multiple countries in a day is special. On my first trip, my friends and I didn’t realize the full potential of this train ticket. We thought it was just a cheap way to reach our campsite in southern France. But the idea of traveling non-stop was too appealing, as there was always another country just beyond the border. And the extra miles? They cost us nothing. 

We were not completely uninterested in culture, but this was our first holiday without parents, like many other Inter-Railers. In planning our own schedule, we focused only on the most accessible sights. It was a chance to escape guided tours and do something different. I took pride in the fact that sometimes all I wanted to see was the view from the train station. We were just trying to get by and enjoy ourselves, just like most other Inter-Railers with whom we shared train corridors, food, money, and music. 

The thrill of travel comes from arriving in a place that was once just a name. It feels like the city didn’t exist until the train arrives, and you see it with your own tired eyes for the first time. Only by experiencing Europe, watching the changing landscapes, and noticing different attitudes and lifestyles can you truly understand the continent. Everyone knows what is there, but it means nothing until you see it yourself. This is why other people's holiday photos can be dull. While the train journey may not reveal new discoveries in the world, it is a valuable personal experience. Europe is vast, and Inter-Rail offers the best chance to appreciate this, even if it didn’t happen for us right away.

Text: 'Arriving at an airport in another country only to find that your luggage is missing can be very disappointing. You might have to wear the same clothes for hours or even days until the airline returns your bags. If you are in a different climate, you may have to wear clothes that are not suitable for the weather. Airlines do not often share how many bags they lose, but it is common for travelers to experience this at some point. Even the best airlines can make mistakes, and it is not always possible for them to ensure that your checked luggage travels on the same flight, especially if you have to change planes.

Airlines require passengers to check in early to give enough time for luggage to be processed and loaded onto the plane. Minimum connecting times (MCTs) are the shortest time needed to switch between flights, and these times are often extended to help with baggage transfers. Usually, this system works well, but extra security checks and air traffic issues can lead to flight delays, which may cause problems with luggage handling. Human error can also occur, such as when a destination label gets lost. These issues can be more serious at large airports, known as 'hubs', where many bags are processed. For instance, last year, London’s Heathrow airport served over 41 million passengers, with nine million transferring to other flights. British Airways alone managed two million transfer passengers at Heathrow, most of whom had to walk a mile between Terminal 1 (for domestic and European flights) and Terminal 4 (for long-haul flights).

Even efficient airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich can have bad days. The chance of losing luggage during a plane change is higher at certain airports. In the United States, Miami airport is known for losing bags when passengers make quick connections to Latin America. To reduce the risk of losing your luggage, choose direct flights when you can and check in early. If you must change planes, try to fly with the same airline for all legs of your journey. Allow extra time for connections by taking an earlier flight, and make sure to label your luggage with your home and holiday addresses, including flight numbers.

If your luggage does go missing, contact the airline staff in the baggage area and fill out a property irregularity report (PIR) before leaving the airport.'

**The Kingfisher**

Wildlife photographer Charlie James is an expert on the kingfisher, a beautiful blue-green bird that lives near streams and rivers and feeds on fish. Old trees hang over the stream, providing some shade to the shallow water. The main colors in this scene are soft greens, muddy browns, and various shades of yellow from the sunlight, all as gentle as the sound of water in the breeze. The kingfisher moves quickly and gracefully, like a flash of light, so striking that you can almost feel its presence. It disappears in an instant, but the image stays in your mind, its impact much greater than its small size.

Charlie James fell in love with kingfishers when he was young. His deep affection for this little bird is shown by his uncertainty about what exactly attracts him to it. The kingfisher is part of many legends. In Greek mythology, it is a moon goddess transformed into a bird. Another story says that the kingfisher flew so high that its upper body became the blue of the sky, while its underside was burned by the sun. There is some truth to this tale. Despite the many shades of blue in their feathers, kingfishers do not have blue pigment. Instead, the structure of their feathers scatters light, reflecting blue. This is why a kingfisher can seem to change from bright blue to deep emerald green with just a slight change in light.

It is no surprise that many wildlife photographers are passionate about kingfishers. Their vibrant colors, combined with the fact that kingfishers are shy but can be observed easily from a hidden spot, create a perfect opportunity for a lifelong interest. Charlie's first hideout was an old blanket he draped over himself while waiting near a kingfisher's favorite area. The bird returned within minutes and sat just a meter away. However, it took him another four years to capture his first good photograph. During this time, the European kingfisher became a central part of his life. He spent as much time as possible by a stream rich with kingfishers, but school limited his time with the birds. He missed classes and considered himself an "academic failure." Nevertheless, his passion for this widespread kingfisher, the only one of its family that breeds in Europe, was noticed. At 16, he was hired as an advisor for a nature magazine, then became an assistant to the editor, and eventually worked as a freelance wildlife film cameraman.

Now, he dreams of making the ultimate kingfisher film: "No speech, just beautiful images that convey everything," he says. "I am drawn to simplicity. I enjoy photographing parts of kingfisher wings..." His voice trails off as he thinks about the colors of the bird he has spent more than half his life observing, which still captivate him. His photographs express some of his feelings, but Charlie knows that there is much more to his connection with the kingfisher than his work can ever reveal.

**Conducting an Orchestra: Insights from New Conductors**

Giving directions to an orchestra is challenging. Anne Inglis interviews five new conductors about their experiences.

**A. Anne Manson**  
Anne Manson, 30, asked to attend conductor Claudio Abbado's practice sessions in Vienna. She unexpectedly filled in for an absent assistant and was later invited to help with another opera. "I had to lead the first orchestral rehearsal for Abbado. I wasn't nervous; I have always felt confident in front of an orchestra." Manson, originally from America, works with a well-known opera company in London that focuses on modern works. She is also gaining recognition in other European countries, thanks to support from the British Arts Council. Since her first experience, she has assisted Abbado on several projects.

**B. Andrew Constantine**  
Andrew Constantine, 31, believes the hardest part of being a conductor is finding the right opportunities. He won a major competition in 1991 after two unsuccessful attempts. Looking back, he feels fortunate about the timing: "If it had happened earlier, I might have been forgotten." The competition opened many doors for him, including a position as an assistant to a famous conductor. However, he struggles with being labeled as a competition winner: "If in three years my name is still linked to the competition, I will be concerned." Fortunately, orchestras like the English Chamber Orchestra, which hired him after the competition, are inviting him back. If this doesn't continue, his career could suffer.

**C. Wasfi Kani**  
Wasfi Kani, who founded Pimlico Opera, enjoys the long rehearsal periods that come with opera productions. "The music deserves four weeks of focus," she says. Kani began conducting seriously in her late twenties. After university, she worked in London's commercial sector until Pimlico Opera became fully professional two years ago. Taking lessons with Sian Edwards was a turning point for her. "I saw her conduct and realized she was my size, unlike the larger conductors I had learned from before, which made a big difference." She appreciates the complexity of opera: "There are many conflicts, and you have to consider the personalities of the singers."

**D. Roger Vignoles**  
Roger Vignoles, 48, says, "Conducting surprised me, but it fascinates me." His career path is not unusual; he began as a resident musician at an opera house and worked with skilled conductors. Last year, he was asked to direct Handel's *Agrippina* from the piano at a festival, something he had never done before. "It was easier than I expected. I knew the music well and what I wanted it to sound like. I did my best to achieve that. Thankfully, people respect my overall musical ability. I learn from every experience, both in musical style and performance. Now, I am open to any opportunities to discover what I enjoy."

**E. Wayne Marshall**  
In 1986, conductor Simon Rattle noticed Wayne Marshall, a young assistant conductor, and informed his agent about him. Now 32, Marshall quickly found himself conducting a musical in London on short notice, which was a tough start. He even had to manage some relaxed professional musicians who were reading newspapers during the performance: "I was firm with them. I always kept a clear beat and aimed for the best outcome. Many orchestral musicians I’ve seen don’t seem to need much guidance from a conductor. But I’m never afraid to express my needs. If people see you’re anxious, it only makes things worse. I have never formally studied conducting, and no book teaches you how to do it, but people have been supportive. I am determined and know what I like."

**Variations on a Theme**

If you are considering taking children to a theme park, there are many options in Britain. We asked five families to review some of the best parks.

**Fun Island - The Burns Family**  
Last year, we visited a large theme park in the US and thought Fun Island might be boring in comparison. However, we were pleasantly surprised. The park is designed for younger children, so our three-year-old felt included. The kids enjoyed the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There is also a special dodgems ride for very young kids, which was a big hit. For older children, there are more thrilling rides, like Splash Out, where you jump into a pool! After five hours, Steve and I were ready to leave, but the children wanted to stay because they were having so much fun. Our only complaint is that the park could use more atmosphere and better scenery. However, the staff were very helpful, and we found the park to be clean, well-organized, and focused on safety.

**Wonderland - The McMillan Family**  
None of us had been to a theme park before, so we were unsure what to expect. We thought Oscar might be too young, but he loved it. He enjoyed the Mountain Train and especially liked Little Land, which has small models of famous buildings that he could explore! The older children liked the ferris wheel and driving toy cars on a real road layout. We spent six hours there and appreciated the places to relax. The landscaping was beautiful, and the staff were friendly and helpful. There was something for everyone, including adults.

**Adventure World - The Jeffree Family**  
After seven hours, we still felt there was more to see. The children loved the Big Top Circus, which had an amazing trapeze act that kept us excited. We tried the Terror Line, and although the girls were scared and kept their eyes closed, they said they enjoyed it. Their favorite ride was Running River, where you think you will get wet, but you don’t. Toy Land is also a lot of fun for younger children. The kids looked at the new ride, Fear Factor, but we were relieved when they realized they were too small to go on it! The park is so well designed that even waiting in line for rides is not boring. It was very clean, and the staff were excellent. When I couldn’t sit with both girls on one ride, a staff member kindly offered to sit with one of them.

**The Great Park - The Langridge Family**  
We arrived at one o'clock and were disappointed that the park closed at 5 p.m. This is a great theme park for younger children because the rides are not too scary. I am quite timid, but I still had fun. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts slowly and then becomes very exciting. We waited for half an hour for Lightning River, and it was over too quickly! I wouldn’t try the Big Leap, but it looked fun for those who are brave. If the children had been a bit older, they might have found it less exciting, but they were the right age and loved it.

**Fantasy World - The Break-all Family**  
According to the park's advertising, there is "No Limit to the Fun," and we certainly felt that was true. Europe's tallest roller coaster, the Rocket, stands out in the park, and Ben thought it was the scariest ride, while Jennie found the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 meters above the ground, even scarier! There are about a dozen main rides, which the older children went on several times. Sarah was too small for some rides but enjoyed the Long Slide. We noticed that the staff's attitudes varied. Some were great with younger children, but the welcome was not always warm. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World, and we wouldn’t have dared tell the kids we were leaving early.

**Running a Business in the Countryside**

Five women share their experiences of starting a business in the countryside.

A. **Christine Hogan** runs a computer-aided design business that earns over £200,000 a year and has four full-time employees. She says, "My customers are friends." Christine and her husband moved from London to the countryside when their children were young. She wanted a job she could do from home. Since she had experience with computers, her husband encouraged her to start this business. It required a lot of money, and the beginning was tough. However, she was careful with her spending and kept the bank informed. Working from home saves money, and she can work in the evenings if needed. Her business remains small, and most customers pick up their orders directly.

B. **Maggy Sasanow** is a greetings card designer who works from home. She studied art at university and initially wanted to work in a museum. After moving to the countryside, where such jobs were unavailable, she decided to start her own business. She creates a collection of 50 greetings cards that she sells to museums. Maggy works in a large room upstairs. One downside of working from home is that there are always chores to do, like mowing the lawn. She relies on word-of-mouth for business and does not advertise. Customers from London choose her because she is more affordable than other artists. Although she misses sharing ideas with others, she finds more benefits than drawbacks in her situation.

C. **Delia Turner** runs a curtain-making business that has faced ups and downs. She started her business eight years ago when the market was growing, and her income increased from £24,000 to £80,000 in two years. At one point, she managed six full-time workers, but due to an economic downturn, she had to let them go, which was difficult since jobs are scarce in her area. Now, she makes curtains at home with her husband’s help and collaborates with women who work from their homes. Delia must be ready to lower her prices when needed and explore new opportunities.

D. **Tessa Strickland** operates a children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. She moved to the countryside three years ago for financial reasons and because she loves the rural lifestyle. Tessa enjoys the flexibility of working when she wants. A large part of her income comes from international deals, so she often takes calls at unusual hours. The challenge is maintaining discipline to separate work from home life. She publishes children's books that reflect various cultures, collaborating with authors and artists. Initially, she felt isolated since her professional experience was in London.

E. **Meg Rivers** runs a cakes-by-post business and a shop that earns £250,000 a year and employs six people, some part-time. She started her business ten years ago at home, focusing on health by making fruit cakes with high-quality ingredients. Requests from friends and family led her to send cakes across the country. Seven years ago, she rented a small building where everything is made, employing a baker and a cake decorator. Meg no longer bakes herself, as she manages the business side. Her biggest challenge has been the financial aspect, as she started with limited funds.

**Meet the Amazing Watkins Family**

The Watkins family is special because they are all involved in music. The sons are composers and award-winning musicians, while their father makes musical instruments. 

John and Hetty Watkins, who are schoolteachers in South Wales, wanted to buy a cello for their ten-year-old son, Paul, but found it too expensive. John thought about making one himself. He discovered the Welsh School of Instrument Making nearby and took evening classes for about three years. 

After trying to make violins and violas, John successfully created his first cello. Paul, now 28, remembers that it turned out well. John made another cello for Paul later, which he used until recently. John has now retired from teaching to focus on making instruments full-time, creating up to twelve violins each year. One of his violins was even sold to the famous American musician Jaime Laredo, which was a great achievement for him.

Paul and his younger brother, Huw, were encouraged to play music from a young age. Paul started with the piano: "As soon as I could reach the keys, I played," he recalls. However, he soon became interested in the cello. His parents wanted him to play the violin because John played the viola and needed another violin for his music group. Paul tried the violin for a short time but preferred the cello after being inspired by a cellist in his father's group.

Huw, now 22, also found his own path in music as a pianist and composer. He appreciated that his parents were supportive without being pushy. Instead of feeling jealous of Paul's achievements, he saw them as motivation.

Paul has had great success with the cello his father made. He won the string final of the BBC Young Musician of the Year competition and became the principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra at just 20 years old, still using his father's cello until last year. Now, he plays a Francesco Rugeri cello, which is on loan from the Royal Academy of Music. 

Paul jokes that his father's cello might need 50 to 100 years to gain the same power as his new one, which is already 304 years old. Soon, he will perform on television with the Rugeri cello in Elgar's Cello Concerto. He believes that his performance style will always be his own, regardless of the cello's history.

However, Paul won't be able to watch his performance on TV because he will be playing at the Cheltenham Festival that same night. Huw will also be busy, as his String Quartet will premiere in London at the Wigmore Hall. John and Hetty will have to be very organized to keep up with all their sons' musical events in the coming weeks.

**Looking After the Countryside: The National Trust**

The National Trust is an organization that aims to protect the British countryside. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and speaks with Gareth Roberts, a warden who works for the Trust to care for its beautiful areas.

According to Gareth, a National Trust Warden needs common sense and good people skills. "You are always interacting with farmers, visitors, conservationists, and construction companies," he explains. Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm until he got married. About 80 people applied for the warden position, but Gareth's local knowledge and farming experience helped him get the job, even though he did not have formal training.

Gareth finds it useful to still farm with his parents, as it allows him to relate to farmers and understand their challenges. He also has the physical strength needed for the job, which includes tasks like building fences, planting trees, and constructing walls. Since joining the Trust, Gareth has learned more about nature conservation. He remembers collecting flowers, butterfly larvae, and birds' nests as a child and now wonders where he would find those things today. He realizes that farming has changed the countryside, but he believes it is not the farmers' fault; they were following government advice.

When Gareth started his job, farmers and conservationists often disagreed. However, they are now communicating and understanding each other's perspectives. "We are at a turning point, and it only takes a small step to bring them together," Gareth says. His work involves conservation, allowing public access to Trust land, planting trees, and working with tenant farmers. "My job is to ensure tasks are completed efficiently and with minimal fuss. I enjoy seeing projects finished, although I spend about half my time on reports and paperwork."

Gareth is passionate about his job and enjoys every moment, especially interacting with the public. However, he finds some visitors frustrating. "Some people come in, demand everything, and leave as if they have a right to it. Being polite to them can be annoying!" But Gareth believes that common sense is key. If you have plenty of common sense and enjoy outdoor work, you might consider applying to be a warden like Gareth. Just be aware that there may not be a position available on the Lleyn Peninsula for a long time!

**The Netball Captain**

In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slowinski. Kendra leads the England netball team. When I met her, she was having a typical day as she prepared for the World Championships next month. She taught at a local school and then trained in a supermarket car park. 

I asked her, "Don't you get strange looks?" She replied, "I'm so focused on my movements and my feet that I don’t notice anything else. I might see cars slow down out of the corner of my eye, but that’s it."

Kendra said, "My whole life is about being my best for the Championships. I follow a strict schedule to get fit." This will be her fourth World Championships, and it will be the largest yet, with 27 countries participating. "We will have home support, which is very special," she said. "It’s important to improve the reputation of netball in this country. Playing at home means there will be more pressure than usual. The crowd will have expectations and will support us more. People want us to start the tournament with a strong game."

Their first match is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. "As far as I know, we have always beaten them, but they will be exciting to play against. They have a lot of talent." The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world. However, Kendra warns that the World Championships will be challenging. "You have to push yourself to play every day. There’s no break between games like in a series. You can still win a series if you lose the first game, but the Championships are different. You only have one chance, and you must be ready to take it."

In the fifteen years she has played at a high level, the sport has become tougher and faster. Players are more aggressive on the court. "You don’t train hard to lose," Kendra said. "But once the game is over, we become friends again."

Netball is also using more scientific methods for fitness testing. "It’s essential that we think and train like world-class players," Kendra explained. "As captain, I believe it’s important to have a strong mindset and lead by example. I see my role as supporting and encouraging my teammates."

Kendra added, "From the start of my netball career, everything has been carefully planned. I decided a while ago that this competition would be my last as a player." She will likely coach young players in the future, but for now, she is focused on her final big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she may very well have tears in her eyes.

**SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS**

How can parents support a child with exceptional musical talent? It can be challenging to know how to nurture their abilities. Some parents may not recognize their child's needs until frustration leads to difficult behavior. While most schools can help academically gifted children, musically talented children often need special attention that regular schools may not provide, especially if music is not prioritized.

Children who show musical talent, especially those encouraged by parents or teachers, can benefit from attending a specialist music school. In Britain, there are five such schools, which have been established relatively recently. These schools create a supportive environment for gifted children aged seven to eighteen, allowing them to develop their skills under the guidance of professional musicians.

At specialist music schools, students spend a significant part of their day—between one third and one half—engaged in musical activities. This includes individual lessons (up to three hours a week for their main instruments), participation in orchestras and chamber groups, voice training, conducting, and music theory. They also practice in well-equipped private rooms, sometimes with a teacher. The remainder of their time is dedicated to a limited academic curriculum, focusing on essential subjects like English, math, basic sciences, and languages, although students can request to study more subjects.

All five British specialist music schools are independent, with smaller class sizes and a high teacher-to-student ratio. Most students live at the school, which allows them to spend their formative years with peers who share similar goals and interests.

However, there are some disadvantages. The cost of attending these schools is high, ranging from £12,000 to £17,000 per year for boarders. Each school tries to help families with scholarships and financial aid for exceptionally talented children. Additionally, not all parents want to send their children to boarding school, especially at a young age. Many directors of these schools have concerns about admitting children as young as seven into such a demanding environment. They emphasize that their goal is to develop well-rounded individuals.

Separating musically gifted children from a young age can create stress. Some early signs of musical talent may fade during the teenage years, and the pressure to succeed can lead to feelings of failure. However, specialist schools closely monitor each student's progress and provide support when needed. 

While many former students feel they gained a lot from the high-quality music education, some worry about the limited academic focus, which often takes a back seat to music. Many musically talented young people are also very intelligent and can handle academic challenges, so they may feel frustrated if their intellectual needs are not met. 

For these reasons, it might be better to wait until a child is older and can make their own choices before pursuing a specialist education. Children who are also academically gifted may thrive in a less specialized setting, such as a school with a strong music program or by combining regular schooling with music training at junior departments of music colleges. These colleges offer Saturday morning lessons with excellent teachers, along with orchestral and chamber music experiences. However, this option may not be feasible for families living far from London or other major cities.

**An Eye for Detail**

Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings, which are inspired by the large garden around her house. This garden is filled with her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread throughout the garden. The two long flower borders along the paved path that runs from east to west are beautifully arranged in terms of color, shape, and structure. This beauty is partly due to the previous owners, who were passionate gardeners and left behind plants that Susan loves. She also kept the gardener, Danny. "In fact, it was really his garden," she says. "We got along very well. At first, he would say, 'Oh, it's not worth it' about some of the things I wanted to add, but when I told him I wanted to paint them, he understood my vision."

Susan prefers to paint detailed studies of individual plants rather than the entire garden. Sometimes, she paints a group of plants in their natural setting, but usually, she picks them and takes them to her studio. "I don't set everything up at once," she explains. "I take one flower out and paint it, which can take a few days, and then I bring in another one to continue the painting. Sometimes, it can take a couple of years to finish."

Her busiest time is in spring and early summer when the tulips bloom, followed by the poppies. "They all bloom together, and you're so busy," she says. However, she also finds beauty in the gradual decay of flowers. For example, with tulips, "you bring them in and put them in water, then leave them for a day, and they change shape. They open up and look amazing. At first, they seem dull, but they keep changing with twists and turns."

Susan has always loved plants. "I studied botany in school and used to collect wildflowers from the countryside," she recalls. "I wasn't really interested in gardening back then; in fact, I didn't like garden flowers because they reminded me of fake ones sold in florists. To me, only wildflowers were real. I was fascinated by how they could grow in tough places, like cracks in rocks or on cliffs."

Today, her garden features many plants from distant lands, and they thrive just as well as they do in their native countries like China or the Himalayas. She has a relaxed attitude towards her garden, similar to a caring aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause serious trouble. With two upcoming exhibitions to prepare for and plenty of inspiration right outside her door, finding time to work in the garden has been challenging. She now hires an extra gardener, but she knows that to stay connected to her art, "you have to get your hands dirty."

**Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**

Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex, shares her experiences as a chalet girl in Val d'Isère, France. This is her second year in this role, where she cooks and cleans for guests who come to ski and stay in traditional wooden houses called chalets. Sarah graduated last summer from Oxford Brookes University with a degree in French and History of Art. She views being a chalet girl as a fun way to spend a year or two before starting a more permanent career. "It's a good way to make contacts. I meet successful people every week," she explains.

Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to work. After having her own breakfast, she prepares breakfast for the guests, which includes porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. By 9:30 a.m., after the guests have finished eating, she cleans up and either prepares afternoon tea or cleans the rooms, which she finds to be the least enjoyable part of her job. By around 11 a.m., she is ready to ski herself, enjoying the slopes until about 4:30 p.m.

After skiing, Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner. She takes a shower first but avoids sleeping, as she believes it would make her feel worse. Dinner, which is a three-course meal, is served at 8 p.m., and coffee is usually ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans the kitchen, as she dislikes coming back to a messy space the next morning. Sometimes she chats with the guests, but other times they prefer privacy. "Good guests can make a week wonderful," she says, noting that some weeks are not as enjoyable.

Sarah lives in a chalet with friends, and they often go out around 11 p.m. They usually start their night at a place called Bananas, then might go to G Jay's and finish at Dick's T-Bar. However, she makes sure not to stay out too late on Saturday nights because Sundays are her busiest days. "It's a tough day," she admits, "when you really don’t want to cook breakfast feeling tired."

On Sundays, Sarah starts work earlier, with breakfast for guests needing to be ready by 7 a.m. Once the guests leave, she cleans quickly, clearing breakfast, stripping beds, and preparing for the next group. If she hasn’t done the shopping on Saturday, she does it now. By around 3 p.m., after finishing the cleaning, she prepares tea for the new guests who arrive around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes they seem confused and have many questions, which Sarah finds amusing.

Between tea and dinner, she helps guests who need ski equipment by taking them to the ski shop and getting a ride back. Soon, it’s time for dinner again, and she might chat with friends, but sometimes she is too tired and goes to bed early.

**Changing Lives with a Stranger**

Mandie Currie, a zookeeper, spent a day at the magazine Marie Claire. "Choosing my outfit for Marie Claire was difficult because I usually wear a uniform at work. First, I went to a photo studio, then to press previews, all before lunch. The zoo is a calm place, and here I was rushing around when I could have been quietly cuddling an animal. Some fashion team members seemed stressed, but my job is not very stressful. During a fashion shoot in the afternoon, I laughed at the thought that I would normally be cleaning cages or handling rats. I find it interesting to see how magazines operate, but I really love my job at the zoo, so I will stay there."

Alice Cutler, a fashion assistant at Marie Claire, spent a day at London Zoo. "I arrived at the zoo in my leather boots and dark blue trousers. The zoo gave me a green polo shirt to wear, which was good because I got very dirty. While petting an elephant, I thought Mandie was probably packing clothes in a cupboard. By five o'clock, I smelled bad, but I had a fantastic day. When I retire from fashion, I could see myself working with elephants, maybe in Africa."

Karen Hodson, a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital, worked with the television gardening show Ground Force. "I was very excited to meet the team, and Alan Titchmarsh, the presenter, was very nice. I enjoyed being outside because I sometimes don’t see daylight due to my shifts. Even though it was hard work, it was a lot of fun. I thought I was strong, but I felt weak compared to the team. My idea of gardening didn’t include hard physical work or careful planning. I’m more enthusiastic than effective at gardening, so I don’t plan to leave my nursing job."

Charlie Dimmock, a landscape gardener on Ground Force, worked a shift at Hammersmith Hospital. "I made beds and handed out medicine. I thought I would feel faint during some tasks, but I surprised myself by handling it well. The friendship among the nurses was great, and it felt very 'girlie' compared to my usual male environment. I feel my job is less meaningful compared to nursing. My day at the hospital wasn’t pleasant, but it gave me a great sense of satisfaction."

Lucy Harvey, a personal trainer, spent a day with Ryanair as cabin crew. "I changed into the uniform, and as soon as I put it on, I felt different—people looked up to me. Before the flight, our supervisor talked about safety and what to do if someone had a heart attack, which I knew from my fitness training. When passengers boarded the flight to Paris, I handed out magazines. Everyone stared at me, and I felt very self-conscious. On the return flight, we had 80 schoolchildren who wouldn’t sit still. I wished I was back in the gym with one sensible adult to manage them."

Sonia McDermott, an air hostess with Ryanair, spent a day as a personal trainer in a gym. "I was nervous about this swap because I don’t exercise. I was surprised by how much attention you give to one person. In my job, I meet 130 passengers four times a day. At lunch, I was surprised to see that some trainers didn’t eat very healthily, but they all drank a lot of water. I wouldn’t change my job for this, but it has inspired me to join a gym and try to be healthier."

**On the Rails: Five Celebrities Share Their Favorite Train Memories**

**Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I fell in love with the south of France a long time ago and try to visit as often as I can. There is a local train from Cannes that travels along the coast and crosses into Italy. It takes you past stunning sea views. No matter the weather or the season, the journey is always magical. Out of the other window, you can see beautiful gardens and homes of the wealthy. It feels like you are peeking into the lives of the rich and famous. The passengers are always lively, a mix of tourists and locals, all enjoying the breathtaking scenery.

**Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I have had many wonderful train journeys, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express, which travels through the northern Sudan desert. When I was young in South Africa, I missed a family train trip from Cape Town to Kruger National Park because I was considered too young and troublesome. I was sent to stay with an aunt instead. When I moved to England as a teenager, I had never been on a train. London Waterloo was the first real train station I saw, and its large glass dome amazed me.

**Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
I am grateful to one train in particular: the Blue Train, which took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. On that train, my husband gave me a pink dress, which I loved. Someone said that pink is good for the brain, and I have worn it ever since. The journey itself was lovely, traveling through France and then by boat up the Nile. It was the perfect way to relax after all the wedding planning.

**Martin Brown - Journalist**  
We were working on articles about a round-the-world trip and needed to cross a desert in Africa. There was no road, so we took the Desert Express. The schedule was unpredictable; we were just told to be ready on a certain day. We heard that the driver would wait for days if he knew people were still coming. When the train finally arrived, many people rushed to get on, even climbing onto the roof for free. At night, the train passed through some of the most beautiful landscapes I have ever seen. It felt like a dream, like traveling across the moon.

**Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
Most people form their favorite memories of trains as children, but that’s not my story. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where I saw very few trains. It wasn’t until I was a teenager that trains became important in my life. I made a film that featured a railway in Yorkshire. Most of the filming was on an old, unused part of the line that volunteers had carefully maintained. That’s where my love for steam trains began. When we weren’t filming, we took every chance to ride the train, and when I returned last year, it felt like time had stopped. Everything was still the same, even the gas lights on the station platform!

Text: 'Are you trying to get your story published? If you’re unsure where to send it, our expert Margaret Stubbs has some helpful advice. Many readers of this magazine ask, "I have written a story/book. Who should I send it to?" One important thing to remember is that you need to research your options and learn about publishers while also improving your writing skills. Turning your writing into something that can be sold requires a good understanding of the publishing world. 

No matter what type of writing you do, it’s essential to know the markets you want to target. You can do this in several ways, but the best method is to read as much as you can about relevant topics. Visit your local library and explore nearby bookstores and newsagents. Reading widely will help you understand what types of writing publishers are currently accepting. 

As time passes, you should keep updating your knowledge because new publications are always emerging—editors change jobs, and magazines shift their focus. Publishers are always looking for fresh talent, so as writers, we must provide what they want. 

If you’re unsure about what to write, let’s say you want to write short love stories. First, find out which magazines publish love stories, as this market is quite limited today, and gather recent copies. Familiarize yourself with the types of stories they buy and understand their readers' expectations. The editor’s goal is to meet the needs of these readers.

Writers often ask me, "This has been rejected three times—am I wasting my time? Do I have a chance?" As a former teacher, I would never discourage anyone, but it’s likely that the work isn’t ready for publication. Many new writers are too eager to submit their work before they are prepared. If you’ve only written one story or article, it’s very unlikely to be published. This rarely happens. When you hear about someone’s success, they often have years of experience in publishing or journalism behind them.

When you finally send out your work for the first time, keep writing while you wait for a response. Write ten more stories, or even twenty. Each one will improve your skills, and you will start to see yourself as a writer, which will boost your confidence. Instead of discarding any of your work, focus on improving it. 

I also recommend not sharing your work with others in the early stages. Remember, every successful writer has faced many rejections before achieving success. Do everything you can to advance your writing career. Look for a creative writing course nearby, or consider joining a local writers' group to gain ideas and confidence from other aspiring writers. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day if possible.'

**No Title**

On the last day of a difficult year, I was leaning against a pillar in the Baltimore train station, waiting for the 10:10 train to Philadelphia. There were more people waiting than I had expected. The usual bright and clean atmosphere of the station was gone. Elderly couples with matching luggage filled the benches, and groups of college students had left their bags all over the floor. A grey-haired man was walking around, talking to different strangers one by one. He looked well-off: he had tanned skin, a nice sweater, and a soft beige coat. He approached a woman sitting alone and asked her a question. Then he came over to a girl near me. She had long blond hair, and I thought I wouldn’t mind talking to her myself. The man asked, "Are you traveling to Philadelphia?" 

"Well, I’m going north, yes," she replied. "But to Philadelphia?" 

"No, I’m going to New York, but I’ll be..." 

"Thanks anyway," he said, moving on to the next bench. Now he had my full attention. "Ma'am," I heard him ask an old lady, "are you traveling to Philadelphia?" When she replied, "Wilmington," he didn’t say anything and continued down the row to a couple with matching luggage. I straightened up from my pillar and moved closer, pretending to look at the platform as if I was focused on the train. I was going to Philadelphia. He could have asked me, but I understood why he didn’t. I probably seemed unreliable to him. He glanced at me quickly and then turned to the other end of the waiting area. By now, he looked very stressed. 

"Please!" he said to a woman reading a book. "Tell me you’re going to Philadelphia!" She looked up from her book. She was in her thirties, maybe thirty-five—older than me. She looked like a school teacher. "Philadelphia?" she said. "Yes, I am." 

"Then could I ask you a favor?" I stood a few feet away, pretending to check my left wrist (even though I didn’t own a watch). I could tell she was becoming cautious. The man must have noticed too, because he said, "Nothing too difficult, I promise!" They were announcing my train now. People started moving toward Gate E, older couples pulling their wheeled bags behind them like pets on leashes. 

Next, I heard the man speaking. "My daughter is flying out this afternoon for a study year abroad, leaving from Philadelphia. I put her on a train this morning, stopped for groceries afterward, and came home to find my wife upset. She hardly said 'hello' to me. My daughter forgot her passport. She called from the station in Philadelphia and didn’t know what to do." The woman nodded sympathetically. I would have stayed quiet and waited to see where this was going. 

"So I told her to stay put. Stay right there in the station, I said, and I would get someone to bring her passport." It sounded suspicious! Why didn’t he go himself if it was such an emergency? "Why don’t you go yourself?" the woman asked. 

"I can’t leave my wife alone for that long. She’s in a wheelchair." This seemed like a weak excuse to me. Also, it was too much bad luck for one family. I glanced at them. The man was holding a packet, not a plain envelope, but a padded one the size of a paperback book. Aha! Padded! So you couldn’t feel what was inside! And from where I stood, it looked stapled shut too. Be careful, lady, I thought silently.

**Gary and Me**

John Moore, the owner of a restaurant, shares his story about his son Gary, who is a well-known TV chef. John believes that everyone has a chance in life. For him, that chance was to run a restaurant, while Gary's chance was to cook. When John learned about a restaurant for sale, he quickly went to see it, even though it was in poor condition. He thought it was perfect for his plans.

Running the restaurant reminded John of his childhood. He remembered feeling sad when his mother went to work in a factory and left him alone. This made him want to ensure his family had time together. His wife took care of their children and managed the finances while John ran the restaurant. They lived above the restaurant and always made it a priority to have meals together. This focus on family helped their children, Gary and Joe, grow up confident. From a young age, they would talk to the restaurant's regular customers, which gave them a good start in life.

Gary was an energetic child. When he was about seven, he tried to jump into a corner bath like it was a swimming pool and accidentally knocked himself out. As he grew older, he earned pocket money by doing small jobs. By the age of ten, he was working in the kitchen every weekend, which meant he always had money at school. He was disciplined and often woke up before his father. In a family business, everyone helps out, and John enjoyed seeing Gary contribute.
