Text: 'Experience the Edinburgh Festival! Each year, many people visit Edinburgh, the capital of Scotland, to enjoy the Edinburgh Festival. For three weeks in August and September, the city is filled with performers and artists from around the globe. They gather in Edinburgh for the largest arts festival in Britain. During this time, the streets are vibrant with music and dance from morning until night. You can even watch artists create paintings on the streets. A highlight of the Festival is the 'Fringe', where students perform comedy shows in small venues and cafes. Many tourists attend the Festival to watch new films, plays, and listen to music from well-known musicians. This year, there will be over five hundred performances featuring actors from more than forty countries. Tickets for these shows are quite affordable, and it is often easier to see your favorite stars in Edinburgh than in London. So, plan to visit Edinburgh next summer, but keep in mind that finding accommodation can be challenging, so consider booking your hotel in advance!'

**ICE FISHING**

If you drive north from Toronto for three hours, you will reach Lake Nipissing. In winter, the lake freezes, and many Canadian fishermen go there every weekend. They build small wooden houses on the ice and paint them in bright colors. Inside these houses, they try to catch fish that swim beneath the ice.

Bob Marvisch has been coming here for twenty-five years during this season. He says, "You need clothes that are light but warm: two pairs of socks, gloves, several thin sweaters, and a snow suit on top. Catching fish is easy." 

To catch fish, you first break the ice to make a small round hole. Then, you take a fishing line, put some bread on it, and lower it through the hole into the water. You pull the line up when the fish eat the bread. The fish are usually between ten and twenty centimeters long. Some people enjoy eating them, but after I catch three or four fish, I prefer to have some chocolate or another snack! Today, I have caught twenty-five! It's a fun sport, and you can meet nice people here!

Madame Tussaud's

One well-known attraction for tourists in London is the Madame Tussaud's museum. In this museum, visitors can see wax figures of famous individuals. Madame Tussaud was born in France in 1761. Her uncle, who was a doctor, created wax figures and opened a museum in Paris. Marie assisted him with this work. In 1789, during the French Revolution, Marie was imprisoned. While in prison, she had to create wax models of famous people who had died, including Queen Marie Antoinette. In 1795, Marie married Francois Tussaud, and in 1802, she moved to London with her wax figures. She opened a museum there, and her figures can still be seen today.

BICYCLES

Bicycles are an affordable and environmentally friendly way to travel. The first bicycle was created around 150 years ago. Initially, bicycles were quite expensive, so only wealthy individuals could afford them. These early models looked very different from modern bicycles. Over time, as bicycles became more affordable, many people began to buy them. They started using bicycles for commuting and leisure activities. 

Today, cars are more commonly used than bicycles because they are faster and keep you dry in the rain. However, some people still choose to ride bicycles to work. They argue that there are too many cars in city centers, making it difficult to find parking.

The Elephant Show by Daniel Allsop, age 14

Last summer, I went to Thailand for a beach holiday with my family. One day, we visited a park near our hotel. The park had beautiful flower gardens, but we were excited to see the elephant show. We went to a large area with seats on three sides. Three elephants entered with their keepers and stood in front of a big piece of white card. Each elephant was given a paintbrush and began to paint on its own card. Occasionally, the keepers would give a new brush filled with paint to each elephant and take away the old one. Slowly, following their keepers' instructions, the elephants created pictures on the cards. I was amazed by what I saw! One picture showed a river, another a tree, and the third a bunch of flowers. When the keepers displayed the paintings, everyone wanted to buy one. We also gave the elephants the bananas we had brought for lunch. Twenty years ago, elephants worked in the forest. Now, they do not work there anymore, but the smartest elephants live in special centers where visitors can watch them.

**Big Cats**

There are many types of cats, and they vary in size, appearance, and behavior. Tigers are the largest cats, measuring up to 3.7 meters from head to tail. While most cats avoid water, tigers often enjoy lying in pools when it is hot. Lions are unique because they live in large family groups. These groups often work together to hunt for food. Lions typically inhabit flat, open areas where they can see far and track other animals easily. All cats require good eyesight to catch smaller animals for food. They also need to be fast and strong.

**THE OSTRICH**

The ostrich is the largest bird in the world, and an adult can weigh over 90 kilograms. Most wild ostriches are found in southern Africa, but their numbers are decreasing. Like all birds, ostriches have wings, but they cannot fly. They use their wings to help them change direction while running. Ostriches can run very fast, reaching speeds of 65 to 90 kilometers per hour, making it hard for predators to catch them. Baby ostriches are about the same size as chickens and take around three years to grow into adults. They eat plants and can survive for many days without water.

Victoria Jamieson, a 23-year-old snowboarder from Britain, began snowboarding at the age of 20. She has achieved success in many competitions. Recently, we interviewed her at a snowboarding event in Switzerland and asked why she chose this sport. She explained, "I have always enjoyed sports, especially skiing, so snowboarding felt like a natural choice. It’s easy to learn, and you can become quite skilled in just a few months."

We inquired about her practice routine. She replied, "During winter, I snowboard in the mountains every day from 8:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. I also enjoy running and biking. I truly love all of it! Competing and being in the mountains is wonderful. However, free-riding—doing what you want outside of competitions—is the best part for me."

When we asked her about learning to snowboard, she said, "You can learn quickly, but taking lessons is essential. Having the right clothing is also important to stay dry, especially since beginners often fall a lot!"

**Mount Kilimanjaro**

Mount Kilimanjaro is the tallest mountain in Africa. Many people, from a seven-year-old boy to an 87-year-old man, have climbed it. There are several routes to the summit. The Marangu route, which is five kilometers long, is considered the easiest and takes about five days. It is very popular among tourists. However, only half of those who attempt to climb Kilimanjaro reach the summit. This is often due to sudden changes in the weather. At the start, it can be hot and rainy, but at the top, climbers encounter ice and snow, and temperatures can drop below 20 degrees Celsius. Therefore, climbers should bring both sunglasses and warm clothing!

Otters

Not many people have seen an otter. These animals live near rivers and build their homes using small pieces of wood. They usually come out at night. Otters are excellent swimmers and can swim faster than 10 kilometers per hour. They have thick brown fur that keeps them warm in the water. An otter can close its ears and nose, allowing it to stay underwater for several minutes. 

Twenty years ago, there were very few otters in Great Britain. The rivers were so polluted that many fish and insects died, leaving otters without food. However, today there is plenty of food for them because the rivers have become clean again.

**Buildings**

People have always created buildings. We need houses to stay warm and dry, and we build stadiums to watch football games and concerts. Other buildings, like museums, are used to display beautiful items. Many people work together to construct a building. The architect decides how the building will look and creates drawings to share their ideas. Engineers ensure that the building is strong and safe. Then, workers carefully construct it.

The Sydney Opera House is a well-known modern building with a beautiful roof. However, the building is attractive from all angles, not just from above. Another famous roof is on the Olympic Stadium in Munich. This unique building resembles a tent made of glass.

The Cerne Giant

Sherborne and Dorchester are two towns in southern England that are close to each other. Between these towns, there are many green hills and fields. On one of these hills, there is a large image of a man. This man is called the Cerne Giant because the nearby village is named Cerne. The exact time when the Cerne Giant was created is unknown, but it is believed to be very ancient. You can walk from Cerne to get closer to the image. If you visit on May 1st at sunrise, you will see the villagers dancing around the giant on the hill.

Gail Rollins is one of the best runners in Edinburgh. This summer, she plans to compete in the 10,000 metres and possibly the 5,000 metres at the European Championships. In the past, Gail was known for finishing second in major competitions. However, she always smiled and laughed, which made her popular in her hometown. Everything changed in 2004 when she participated in her first half-marathon, a long road race. She won with an impressive time, the fastest of any British woman that year.

Gail's manager and husband, Mike Rollins, used to race when he was younger, but he had to stop due to an injury to his right leg. He can still run a little and sometimes trains with Gail, but it’s not enjoyable for him when she runs ahead and he can't keep up. Gail trains hard, doing a long run in the morning and fast runs in the afternoon. She always takes Sundays off from running. Mike says, "I am with her all the time. Sometimes I ask, 'Are you sure you should be eating that?' It's usually cakes, but she can eat almost anything."

**Piano Players - Their Early Years**

**Ivan Petrov**  
Ivan was born on a farm in Russia. From the age of twelve to eighteen, he studied in Poland. His first music teacher could not play the piano but taught him and his sister songs from operas. His mother started teaching him the piano when he was six years old. By the age of ten, he wanted to write music and began working on his first song.

**Oleg Gagarin**  
Oleg was the youngest of five children. When he was four, his father, who enjoyed playing the piano, taught him some traditional Russian music. At six, he began taking lessons from a piano teacher in his city. Oleg quickly started winning prizes for his piano skills. At fourteen, he attended a music college in Austria for two years before returning to Russia.

**Josef Heptmann**  
Josef's father was German and taught music in Poland, where Josef was born. The family moved to Germany when Josef was two, and he began playing the piano a year later. He gave his first concert at six years old. At ten, he performed fifty-two concerts in two months during a trip to England! Josef loved music but was also interested in physics and languages. Although he is very busy now, he hopes to write his own music one day.

**Bill Prince-Smith**

Bill Prince-Smith was a farmer, a teacher, and a dentist before he became a writer of children's books at the age of 60. Now, thirteen years later, he has written over 80 books. Every day, he goes to his office to write. In the evening, he gives his work to his wife to read. "She tells me when she doesn't like something," says Bill. His ten grandchildren do not live nearby, but they also read his stories and give their opinions on them. This feedback has helped Bill understand what young children enjoy reading.

Bill writes about life in his village and the farms around it. His favorite book is his fifth one, called *The Sheepdog*, which tells the story of a farmer and the dog that helps him. "I have always liked animals," says Bill, "and dogs are very smart; they learn quickly." Last year, this book was made into a film with real animals and actors. The filmmakers used advanced computer technology to make it seem like the animals were talking. Bill was very happy with the film. "Sometimes filmmakers change books, but they didn't change mine, and I love the film."

**POSTCARDS**

Today, many people enjoy sending postcards to their friends and family. These postcards usually feature images of beaches, mountains, or castles, and you can write a message on the back. Many individuals send postcards while on holiday because they are inexpensive, and the images are often more appealing than personal photos. The first postcard was sent at the end of the nineteenth century, and it displayed a picture of a seaside town. Over time, postcards began to show images related to current events, such as accidents or visits from important people. People appreciated these postcards because newspapers at that time did not include pictures.

Dinosaurs

No one has ever seen a dinosaur because the last one died about 60 million years ago, long before humans existed. The exact reason for their extinction is still unknown. Birds are the closest living relatives of dinosaurs. 

Dinosaurs were not all the same; there were over 5,000 different types. Some were very small, while others were enormous. The largest dinosaurs were bigger than any land animals that have ever lived. For instance, the Brontosaurus was twenty meters long and primarily ate plants. The Tyrannosaurus Rex was smaller but much stronger, with sharp teeth for eating meat. It could also run quickly due to its long back legs.

**Bears**

Bears can be dangerous animals. An adult bear is very strong and can potentially kill a person. They are skilled climbers and can run quickly. However, bears do not have good eyesight; like many animals, they rely on their sense of smell to find food. 

There are seven species of bears. The largest is the polar bear, which can grow to nearly three meters tall. There are two types of black bears: one inhabits the forests of North America, while the other is found in Southeast Asia. Interestingly, not all black bears are actually black; they can also be dark brown or reddish-brown. 

The black and white panda bear, native to China, is beloved by many. Unfortunately, there are not many pandas left in the wild today because they struggle to find enough food.

CROCODILES

Crocodiles are found in tropical regions around the world, such as Africa, South America, and Northern Australia. They usually live in slow-moving water but can swim quickly and move fast on land. You often see them in large groups. Crocodiles eat a variety of things, including fish, birds, and small animals. Occasionally, they may also attack larger animals or even humans. There are over ten different species of crocodiles, all of which have very sharp teeth. Although they frequently lose teeth, they quickly grow new ones. Typically, crocodiles are about 3.5 meters long, but some can be much larger. They have long lifespans; the oldest crocodile in a zoo lived to be 66 years old.

A HISTORY OF AIR TRAVEL

In 1783, two French brothers created the first balloon that could carry people into the sky. One hundred and twenty years later, in 1903, the Wright brothers invented the first powered airplane and successfully flew it in the United States. In 1918, the US Post Office started the first airmail service. Over the next thirty years, airplanes underwent significant changes. In the 1950s, they became much faster due to the introduction of jet engines. In 1976, Concorde was developed in the UK and France. It is the fastest passenger airplane in the world, capable of flying at 2,500 kilometers per hour, which allows the trip from London to New York to take only four hours. Today, millions of people travel by airplane, making it hard to imagine a world without them.

The Globe Theatre

Visiting the theatre in London 400 years ago was very different from today. The building was round and had no roof, so people would get cold and wet if it rained. The queen enjoyed going to the Globe Theatre, located by the River Thames, to watch the plays of William Shakespeare. At that time, all the actors were men. Visitors would eat, chat with friends, walk around during the performance, and some even threw things at the actors! Today, you can still visit the Globe Theatre. A new theatre has been built in the same location by the river. You can enjoy a Shakespeare play there or learn about life in the seventeenth century.
